results.title: Entanglement-Informed Translations Between AQC and QAOA
results.chunk_text: . Similar translations will be made for AQC, where QAOA paths will inform diabatic variants of AQC. This project will exploit the significant recent progress of quantum many-body physics to elucidate connections between two extensively studied models for quantum computation. Albeit intimately related, little is known about the correspondence between AQC and QAOA in regards to computational hardness and algorithmic design. Our study will provide important, broadly relevant details about these properties by (1) using entanglement growth as a proxy for problem hardness and (2) focusing on a computational problem class of practical relevance. Our work has the potential to impact quantum approaches to solving scientific problems of interest to DOE. The knowledge gained from this study can be used to inform the design and training of variational algorithms more generally, thus, extending the applicability to the variational quantum eigensolver and electronic structure calculations. In addition, our work could assist in circumventing barren plateaus, where optimal AQC schedules are used to provide near-optimal initial conditions when training large variational algorithms. More broadly, our work can supply intuition into the potential utility of a particular quantum computing model based on the specifications of the computational problem. As a result, the need for extensive empirical benchmarking utilizing costly classical and quantum computational resources could be reduced.

results.public_abstract: This project will determine translations between adiabatic quantum computing (AQC) and the quantum approximate optimization algorithm (QAOA) through the study of entanglement generation and its relation to computational hardness and optimal algorithmic design. The objective of this study is to draw on our team's expertise in out-of-equilibrium quench dynamics, entanglement in ground states of Hamiltonians, and optimal control to establish connections between quantum problem hardness in QAOA and AQC and develop effective ways to translate optimal controls between these computational models. The project will be split into two thrust areas focusing on quantifying entanglement in QAOA and AQC and establishing translations of optimal computation across these models. Thrust 1 will focus on identifying universal properties of entanglement growth in QAOA by examining the dynamics of bipartite entanglement entropy. We will investigate the dependence of entanglement entropy on the choice of ansatze as well as its growth during training and after optimization. Our study will utilize numerical simulation and analytical techniques drawn from out-of-equilibrium quench dynamics to shed light on entanglement growth and its relationship to the specifications of the computational problem of interest; our focus will be on Maximum Satisfiability, where the clause density directly relates to the classical computational hardness of the problem. This problem class will further facilitate studies of interplay between classical and quantum hardness, entanglement growth, and computational models. The results of Thrust 1 will inform the design of optimal QAOA parameter selection and AQC schedules in Thrust 2. Using our team’s extensive knowledge in control theory, we will develop guiding principles to translate between optimal AQC and QAOA based on the desired entanglement dynamics of the algorithm. Furthermore, we will exploit characteristics of each algorithm to inform the design of optimized controls for the other, e.g., AQC runtime will inform the QAOA depth and the optimized AQC path will be examined as an initialization for QAOA. Similar translations will be made for AQC, where QAOA paths will inform diabatic variants of AQC. This project will exploit the significant recent progress of quantum many-body physics to elucidate connections between two extensively studied models for quantum computation. Albeit intimately related, little is known about the correspondence between AQC and QAOA in regards to computational hardness and algorithmic design. Our study will provide important, broadly relevant details about these properties by (1) using entanglement growth as a proxy for problem hardness and (2) focusing on a computational problem class of practical relevance. Our work has the potential to impact quantum approaches to solving scientific problems of interest to DOE. The knowledge gained from this study can be used to inform the design and training of variational algorithms more generally, thus, extending the applicability to the variational quantum eigensolver and electronic structure calculations. In addition, our work could assist in circumventing barren plateaus, where optimal AQC schedules are used to provide near-optimal initial conditions when training large variational algorithms. More broadly, our work can supply intuition into the potential utility of a particular quantum computing model based on the specifications of the computational problem. As a result, the need for extensive empirical benchmarking utilizing costly classical and quantum computational resources could be reduced.

results.title: FAR-Qu: Fundamental Algorithmic Research toward Quantum Utility
results.chunk_text: Recent empirical demonstrations pointing toward quantum advantage have fueled excitement and growth in the field. However, many high-profile demonstrations suggesting quantum advantage have prompted improvements in classical algorithm design (e.g., tensor-network methods) and enlist additional classical resources (e.g., supercomputing) with surprising progress in closing quantum-advantage gaps. While quantum-inspired classical improvements are a healthy benefit of quantum-computing research, to ultimately realize quantum utility it is important to systematically identify, understand, and publicize sources of quantum advantage that are unlikely to be diminished as classical computing progresses. A demonstration of quantum utility may conjure the image of a plot indicating that a quantum computer performs better (with respect to some metric) than the best-known classical counterparts. This basic concept of quantum utility raises natural questions. Soundness: What evidence do we have that a quantum computer will continue to be the best way to solve this problem as input instances grow larger or more complex? Cost-effectiveness: Will a quantum computer be the most cost-effective way to solve the problem? Resource efficiency: Will some other resource considerations, such as energy to solution, rule out practical adoption of the quantum computing solution? While well-conceived notions of quantum utility have been suggested, none, to our knowledge, simultaneously take all of the above into account. Our goal is to identify sources of sustainable quantum utility, those that are sound, cost effective, and resource efficient. We believe that sustainable quantum utility is the best candidate for realizing the promise of quantum computing. We aim to discover examples of sustainable quantum utility through three guiding perspectives: (1) sustainable quantum utility should be backed by strong evidence or proof of asymptotic advantage — in other words, there should be some feature of quantum mechanics that continues to provide an advantage in a reasonably predictable manner as problem instances grow in size or complexity, (2) an array of resources beyond execution time should be considered to ensure that quantum advantages are indeed practical and that we are not overlooking unconventional quantum advantages, and (3) we should focus on developing quantum advantages for fundamental problems in broad domains such as simulation, optimization, and machine learning, that can be tailored to yield sustainable quantum utility for new and existing applications. While a major barrier to sustainable quantum utility is the current lack of mature, scalable, and error-resilient quantum computing hardware, sustainable quantum utility is also hampered by equally formidable fundamental algorithmic challenges

(2) We will develop and demonstrate kernels for quantum simulation that exploit mid-circuit measurements as new algorithmic tools for improved efficiency and robustness to hardware errors. This work directly addresses the call to “advance the research towards achievement and demonstration of quantum utility by developing new algorithms.” It does so by developing algorithms for DOE application-inspired computational kernels for near-term quantum systems and by estimating quantum resources for those algorithms. Significantly, this work will deliver successes for quantum computing while the technology matures, justifying continued Department of Energy (DOE) investments in quantum computing. These efforts will help DOE leverage quantum computing as a useful scientific tool as early as possible, with potential benefits to diverse applications such as the discovery of materials and processes for clean energy and the design and optimization of resilient distributed energy networks.

results.public_abstract: Catalyzing Workforce Diversity in Photocatalytic Energy Science Dr. Kristy L Mardis1, Associate Provost Co-PI(s): Dr. Jens Niklas2, Dr. Sunshine Silver3, Dr. Rakhim Rakhimov4 1: Chicago State University, Chicago, IL 60628 2: Argonne National Laboratory, Lemont, IL 60439 3: Elmhurst University, Elmhurst, IL 60126 4: Norfolk State University, Norfolk, VA 23504 This project brings together researchers and trainees from Chicago State University (CSU), a Predominantly Black Institution (PBI), Norfolk State University (NSU), a Historically Black College and University (HBCU), Elmhurst University (EU), a Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI), and the Solar Energy Conversion Group at Argonne National Laboratory (ANL). Working collaboratively, this project seeks to increase the number of historically underrepresented groups in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) fields while broadening the understanding of solar driven chemical reactions. The project will strengthen the research and scientific opportunities at the three MSIs in collaboration with ANL and provide 12 students annually opportunities to engage in high-impact research focused on questions surrounding artificial and biohybrid photosynthesis. Through a year-round training program, weekly group meetings, and an annual week-long full group meeting at ANL, participants will be provided with ample networking opportunities, culturally responsive mentoring, and professional development. By engaging students in a collaborative research project and culturally responsive mentoring, faculty will work to improve the sociocultural environment and remove obstacles for the advancement of a diverse workforce in the photochemical sciences. This project builds on complementary techniques to understand and improve hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalysts for solar fuel production. Nickel and cobalt molecular catalysts offer a promising opportunity for the development of new materials for solar fuel production as they are inexpensive, readily synthesized, and can be chemically modified to tune their properties. Computational modeling techniques will be utilized to understand the effect of structural changes on the catalysts. These results will aid in the design of improved biohybrid systems. Electron Paramagnetic Resonance spectroscopy will be utilized to characterize the charge-transfer events and electronic structure of the transition metal complexes and the biohybrid complexes. It is anticipated that the dual approach of an immersive inter-institutional research experience and culturally responsive mentoring as a means of effecting systemic change to support a diverse group of participants will lead to higher retention and persistence of a more diverse workforce. Weber4, Dr. Kelly Rowland4 1: Morgan State University, Baltimore, MD 21251 2: Towson University, Towson, MD 21252 3: Hood College, Frederick, MD 21701 4: Lawrence Berkeley National Lab, Berkeley, CA 94720 Abstract The commitment of the Department of Energy (DOE) to advancing cutting-edge technologies, including artificial intelligence (AI) and high-performance computing (HPC), is critical for maintaining the nation’s competitive edge in science and industry. However, the United States (US) faces significant challenges: many graduating students, particularly those from underrepresented groups, enter the workforce without the necessary skills, hands-on experience, and research expertise in AI and HPC. The lack of adequately trained graduates impedes the nation’s ability to drive innovation and achieve strategic objectives. To address the challenges, this project aims to build a regional AI community through collaborative research and traineeship with Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (LBNL), to provide students with comprehensive training in AI with HPC, equipping them with the technical expertise and practical experience needed to excel in these fields. This project has seven key objectives: (i) Establish a regional community for sustainable traineeship collaboration between Maryland institutions and the DOE lab, including shared infrastructure, cross-mentored research projects, and integrated educational resources; (ii) Train and prepare students for the future AI workforce by providing students with hands-on research experience with DOE Lab’s AI projects, fostering practical skills, expertise in real-world applications, and the ability to collaborate effectively within team settings; (iii) Provide students with opportunities to engage in meaningful research projects, guided by experienced faculty and DOE scientists; (iv) Facilitate students’ professional development through workshops, seminars, hackathons, and training sessions that equip students with the latest AI technologies, industry-standard tools, and ethical considerations; (v) Enhance course contents and design new course modules at the participating institutions to reflect the latest advancements in AI and incorporate practical experiences that align with industry needs; (vi) Recruit and support students from underrepresented groups to participate in the program, promoting diversity and inclusivity in the AI field and ensuring a wide range of perspectives in AI development; (vii) Establish long-term research collaborations between students, faculty, and DOE scientists to address critical AI challenges and advance scientific knowledge. The student participants will receive comprehensive financial support throughout the academic year and summer. This sustainable model ensures the long-term continuation of AI education excellence, aligning with the evolving needs in AI and HPC, as well as the DOE’s mission. Students will learn about DOE labs, internships, and career opportunities, developing the skills and professional connections needed to apply for these opportunities with confidence. The success of this program will enhance student retention by building students’ confidence in conducting AI-related research. results.public_abstract: From forests to floodplains to functioning watersheds: Catalyzing collaborative research and inclusive training partnerships between Western Colorado University and DOE’s National Laboratory system Jonathan Coop, Western Colorado University (Principal Investigator) Kristin Boye, SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory (Co-Investigator) Amy Ellwein, Western Colorado University (Co-Investigator) David Marchetti, Western Colorado University (Co-Investigator) Vincent Noël, SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory (Co-Investigator) Micah Russell, Western Colorado University (Co-Investigator) Madelon van de Kerk, Western Colorado University (Co-Investigator) Ken Williams, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (Co-Investigator) Changing climate and disturbance regimes are driving major changes to forest ecosystems and watershed function. Improving our understanding of the causes and consequences of these ecosystem changes, and what kinds of actions would improve outcomes, requires new collaborations that bring together researchers in physical and biological sciences to test hypotheses with landscape-scale experiments. Over a four year timeframe, we will develop a suite of synergistic research activities linking current and planned DOE research in watershed function with Western’s growing expertise in ecological and environmental sciences and engagement with land management agencies planning large-scale interventions. The initiatives we propose will advance critical science questions and provide inclusive training for students who would not otherwise have access to such opportunities. These in turn will facilitate the development of long-term partnerships between DOE and a rural university, to link the next generation of diverse, innovative scientists to fulfilling career opportunities addressing environmental challenges.

results.title: Resilience to Growing Extreme Natural Hazards: Developing a Northeast Hazards Workforce
results.chunk_text: We propose a holistic and inclusive research and training program to the Department of Energy’s Reaching a New Energy Sciences Workforce initiative (DOE RENEW) to provide students and early career scientists with opportunities to gain in-depth experience in understanding extreme natural hazards and solving the associated and expanding societal challenges caused by these events. The project aims to improve the knowledge of extreme natural hazards by quantifying and understanding the properties of floods, landslides, heatwaves, and multi-hazard impacts in the Greater New York metropolitan area. A synergistic approach that blends Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning with traditional computational methods will be used to create more robust, scalable, and dynamic climate-informed natural hazard risk management tools for the next generation of energy science workforce. The project intends to prepare and promote well-trained, diverse graduates and postdoctoral scientists who will become part of the next generation in government, industry, and academia. The trainees will gain the skillsets necessary to immediately contribute to ongoing resilience and adaptation projects in a cost and schedule-driven environment and an increasingly AI-driven workplace. The project brings together a team of multidisciplinary researchers, including civil, environmental, and electrical engineering, climate, atmospheric, and ecosystem science, data science, as well as education and workforce training specialists. The team will work together to prepare a hazards-ready workforce in the Greater New York metropolitan area, one of the densest urban regions in the country and home to nearly 25 million people.

results.public_abstract: Extracting uranium from uranium-bearing mining wastewater remedies the ecosystem and helps address uranium security for the nation's needs. Current uranium separation processes, which are primarily based on adsorption, have limited separation capacity, poor selectivity against competing ions such as sodium and magnesium, and high processing costs. In contrast, electrochemical intercalation chemistry, which allows high capacity and reversibility of cation separations using battery electrodes via a faradaic process, is an energy-efficient recovery technology. While electrochemical separations are energy-efficient, extraction capacity and selectivity limit the electrochemical separation of uranium ions from wastewater. To address these limitations, project objectives focus on understanding and controlling interactions between layered metal oxide battery electrodes and uranium-bearing wastewater to achieve high-capacity and selective separation of uranyl ions. Specifically, a series of electrochemical, chemical, and mechanical processes that involve uranium ion intercalation, uranium oxide deposition, and mechanical deformation of metal oxide host materials are used to investigate how disordered metal oxide layered materials interact with uranium ions. Complementary methods, including wet-chemistry synthesis, electrochemical experiments, in situ strain/stress measurements, in situ synchrotron X-ray total scattering analysis, and electron microscopy are used to gain fundamental insights into molecular and material drivers in separation processes and reproducibility. The iterative Electro-Chemo-Mechanical process feedback loop enables a comprehensive understanding of high-capacity, selective, and stable uranium recovery using intercalative battery electrodes. The knowledge gained could impact how uranium is recovered, thus benefiting the broad chemical science community and advancing an eco-friendly critical material recovery approach.

results.title: Understanding Flow Cell Porous Electrodes as Active Materials for Electrochemical Transformations
results.chunk_text: The objective of this research program is to fundamentally understand flow cell porous electrodes -- such as those used in fuel cells, flow batteries, electrolyzers, and desalination systems -- as active composite materials for the electrochemical transformation of flowing liquid electrolytes. The microstructural features of macroscopically homogeneous porous electrodes will be varied and their influence on mass and charge transport processes will be visualized, measured, and analyzed. With the resulting insight, new theories and models will be developed to describe the behavior of these materials across multiple length scales. With guidance from these models, new porous electrode structures with hierarchical architectures that exhibit functionality unattainable in today’s macroscopically homogeneous electrodes will be developed. This unique scientific program is made possible by several technical advances. An extrusion-based 3D printing method, known as direct ink writing, will be used to fabricate electrode structures composed of periodic mesoscale lattices as well as those with programmed types and strengths of heterogeneities, or hierarchies across multiple length scales. The mapping of molecular concentrations and flow velocities with high spatial and temporal resolution using fluorescence microscopy will be extended from two to three spatial dimensions. Numerical solutions to the equations governing flow, diffusion, migration, advection, electrochemical conversion, and electronic conduction at the individual fiber and pore scale will be developed using a new method that permits large scale simulations at fine spatial resolution. This research program will lead to a deep fundamental understanding of electrolyte-filled porous electrodes. The scientific insights gained will enable the flow cell community to design high-performance electrodes from the bottom up, based solely on knowledge of the physical, chemical, and electrochemical properties of the electrolytes. Ultimately, this will lead to higher efficiencies and power densities, reduced costs, and increased competitiveness of electrochemical devices that rely on electrolyte-filled porous electrodes.

results.title: Electrically Driven Catalysis with Supercharged Reducing Agents
results.chunk_text: Electron transfer is a central feature of chemistry. Electrons are the world’s energy currency, and the development of sustainable reduction-oxidation (redox) processes is paramount for a world where energy management is key to a stable and secure future. To this end, the development of redox-active molecular systems that facilitate the transfer of high-energy electrons has widespread applications in fuel cell systems, flow batteries, and organic electrosynthesis. However, many reduction reactions requiring high-energy electron inputs (such as alkali metals) are not catalytic, and there has been little progress in designing redox catalysts that deliver potent electrons due to challenges with catalyst stability, characterization, and storage. This program leverages the use of new “supercharged” molecular redox agents for catalytically reducing carbon dioxide (CO2), a C1 atmospheric pollutant, into oxalate (C2O42-) – a commonly used industrial C2 reagent for actinide purification, textile processing, and wood bleaching, to name a few. This program distinguishes itself from most other CO2 research programs because the reduction of CO2 into C2 products with homogeneous (soluble) catalysts remains in its infancy. Therefore, a fundamental understanding of the molecular mechanism of CO2-to-oxalate production is necessary to gain deeper insights into more general design principles for synthesizing C2 products directly from CO2 via carbon-carbon coupling reactions. Within the purview of the DOE-FAIR framework, this research project led by Rutgers University-Newark in collaboration with Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) will: (1) pinpoint the essential structural and electronic features that facilitate CO2 reduction catalysis with manganese (Mn) molecules; (2) utilize the advanced spectro-electrochemical equipment and expertise available at PNNL; (3) advance the understanding of Mn-based redox agents transfer electrons to CO2 by modulating reaction temperatures and pressures via specialized spectroscopic equipment available at PNNL; (4) use experimental and quantum chemical methodologies to map the energy landscapes of elementary reaction steps during the reactions involving Mn, CO2, and electrons. Unlocking new modes of reactivity with CO2 in this research program will contribute to a clean and secure energy future, cementing the United States as a global leader in sustainable chemistry and catalysis.

results.title: Leveraging Macrocyclic Chelators for Rare Earth Element Separations
results.chunk_text: Significant technological advances in and growing commercial demand for batteries, permanent magnets, wind turbines, liquid crystal displays, and portable electronics have driven a need for an increased domestic supply of the rare earth elements. The rare earth elements, which are elements residing near the bottom of the periodic table, are naturally abundant in various ore deposits across the globe, including the United States. Despite their domestic availability, these elements are most often obtained from foreign nations, a consequence of the environmental harm that is caused by their extraction. A significant contributing factor to the costliness and environmental damage of their harvest from natural ores lies within their chemical separation from one another. The rare earth elements occur in nature together, yet need to be separated in their pure elemental form to be used for various technological applications. The chemical similarities of these elements make this separation energy inefficient and environmentally harmful. This project is focusing on developing new strategies to separate the rare earth elements in more efficient and environmentally benign ways. The approach taken by this work is to design new synthetic receptors for the rare earth elements, called chelators. These chelators, which form direct chemical bonds with metal ions, are being synthesized and modified to attain distinct affinity patterns for the different rare earth elements. By tuning these selectivity patterns, we are able to use the chelators to achieve rare earth element separations. Toward this overall goal, the project is divided into several objectives. The first objective is focused on designing chelators that have a unique selectivity pattern that enables them to bind to both small and large rare earth elements with equal affinity, while exhibiting poor affinity for those of intermediate size. These chelators are being optimized so that they can be used to achieve unique separations to selectively afford rare earth elements within the middle of the series. In the second objective of this project, we are designing chelators that can alter the “outer-sphere” of the rare earth elements. The outer-sphere represents the surrounding solvent and ions in solutions, and thus provide secondary types of interactions that are not afforded by conventional chelators. These chelators are being designed in order to fine-tune rare earth element selectivity patterns to enable novel separations. In the third objective, we are exploring the use of chelators with other small metal-binding compounds to form what are known as ternary complexes. The addition of secondary metal-binding units provides another means to achieve distinct rare earth separations

results.title: Developing Novel Electrolytes to Suppress Transition Metal Dissolution in Battery Cathodes Using Multimodal Characterization (- View Less)
results.chunk_text: Developing Novel Electrolytes to Suppress Transition Metal Dissolution Using Multimodal Characterization Lead PI: Dr. Tao Li1, Associate Professor Co-PI(s): Dr. Luxi Li2, Beamline Scientist 1: Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL 60115 2: Argonne National Laboratory, Lemont, IL 60439 Abstract: This research aims to develop innovative electrolyte formulations that prevent the dissolution of transition metals from lithium-ion battery cathodes, a key factor in battery performance degradation. By systematically varying electrolyte composition and concentration, the project seeks to understand and control the solvation structures of lithium ions. These solvation structures—how lithium ions are stabilized by surrounding molecules—are critical to how the electrolyte interacts with the cathode surface. Insights into these interactions will inform the rational design of next-generation electrolytes that minimize transition metal loss, enhancing battery stability and longevity. The research will employ a combination of advanced characterization techniques, including X-ray scattering, X-ray fluorescence microscopy, and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy. These tools will be used to investigate the atomic-level changes at the electrolyte-cathode interface, as well as map the distribution of transition metals within the battery. Understanding these dynamics will be crucial for developing electrolytes that effectively inhibit transition metal dissolution during battery operation. The collaboration between Northern Illinois University and Argonne National Laboratory combines expertise in chemistry and materials science with state-of-the-art experimental resources. This partnership will enable a comprehensive investigation of how electrolyte formulations impact battery performance, contributing to the broader goal of advancing energy storage technologies. By addressing one of the critical challenges in lithium-ion batteries, this research will help improve the performance and lifespan of energy storage systems used in electric vehicles and renewable energy applications. The outcomes will have significant implications for the development of more sustainable and efficient batteries, aligning with national priorities to reduce carbon emissions and promote energy independence. Additionally, our scientific training and outcome will be integrated into educational programs to promote STEM education and raise public awareness about energy storage.

results.title: Leveraging Macrocyclic Chelators for Rare Earth Element Separations
results.chunk_text: Significant technological advances in and growing commercial demand for batteries, permanent magnets, wind turbines, liquid crystal displays, and portable electronics have driven a need for an increased domestic supply of the rare earth elements. The rare earth elements, which are elements residing near the bottom of the periodic table, are naturally abundant in various ore deposits across the globe, including the United States. Despite their domestic availability, these elements are most often obtained from foreign nations, a consequence of the environmental harm that is caused by their extraction. A significant contributing factor to the costliness and environmental damage of their harvest from natural ores lies within their chemical separation from one another. The rare earth elements occur in nature together, yet need to be separated in their pure elemental form to be used for various technological applications. The chemical similarities of these elements make this separation energy inefficient and environmentally harmful. This project is focusing on developing new strategies to separate the rare earth elements in more efficient and environmentally benign ways. The approach taken by this work is to design new synthetic receptors for the rare earth elements, called chelators. These chelators, which form direct chemical bonds with metal ions, are being synthesized and modified to attain distinct affinity patterns for the different rare earth elements. By tuning these selectivity patterns, we are able to use the chelators to achieve rare earth element separations. Toward this overall goal, the project is divided into several objectives. The first objective is focused on designing chelators that have a unique selectivity pattern that enables them to bind to both small and large rare earth elements with equal affinity, while exhibiting poor affinity for those of intermediate size. These chelators are being optimized so that they can be used to achieve unique separations to selectively afford rare earth elements within the middle of the series. In the second objective of this project, we are designing chelators that can alter the “outer-sphere” of the rare earth elements. The outer-sphere represents the surrounding solvent and ions in solutions, and thus provide secondary types of interactions that are not afforded by conventional chelators. These chelators are being designed in order to fine-tune rare earth element selectivity patterns to enable novel separations. In the third objective, we are exploring the use of chelators with other small metal-binding compounds to form what are known as ternary complexes. The addition of secondary metal-binding units provides another means to achieve distinct rare earth separations

results.title: Ultranano, Single-Atom Catalysts for Chemical Transformations
results.chunk_text: The core objective of this DOE project is to advance understanding of molecular-scale dynamics at surfaces containing ultranano (< 2 nm) scale oxide particles. The ultimate goal is to generate a molecular-level picture of interactions and transformations to support rational modification of the surface and ultimately to control the products. Ultrasmall particles are more like large molecules than extended solids; data indicates that they are extremely stable – a prime requirement for sustainability. Reducing the particle size thus solves a joint grand challenge of nanoscience: reproducible synthesis and catalyst longevity. One of the consequences of having on the order of a hundred formula units, is that minimization of energy dictates particle morphology. The same energy principles enable placement of a single defect atom in a small-area, high-energy face. The resulting engineered defect can be leveraged to capture and anchor a single noble (or not so noble) metal atom resulting in a robust, highly effective catalyst for targeted chemical transformations. One theme of this project is evolving parameters constraining identity of both the defect and the captured atom to satisfy requirements for targeted transformations. Due to their small size, it can be challenging to probe ultranano particle surfaces, particularly under reaction conditions, yet a molecular-scale probe is required to develop a picture of surface dynamics. This project addresses this challenge not only by advancing a recently invented instrument to push the frontiers for nonlinear, ultrafast spectroscopy but also by creating a novel difference phase interference, DPI, mode to track charge transport and reactivity in situ under reaction conditions. Ultrafast DPI is expected to be a generally applicable tool hence is expected to impact multiple problems involving dynamic, soft, nanoscale or irregular interfaces The specific transformation targeted in this project is reduction of CO2 to value added products. Precedent suggests that the dopant-captured metal combination determines whether the product is a one-carbon reduction, or a carbon-carbon coupled product. More specifically, reduction of CO2 requires both energy input and a source of hydrogen atoms. Sunlight is an attractive energy source; water is the most desirable hydrogen atom source. Thus, this project seeks to photochemically reduce CO2 in aqueous solution. Probing this process at the molecular level begins with particle assembly. This project seeks to develop a novel THz Raman probe to detect the nascent seed and growth process as well as the metal capture mechanism

results.title: Probing Short-Range Structure and Magnetism In Next-Generation Energy Conversion Materials
results.chunk_text: Next-generation materials will play a crucial role in transformative technologies that can address critical societal issues, such as the need to harness, store, and convert energy in a sustainable way. Many candidate materials for technological application derive their exceptional properties from the complex interplay between their atomic and magnetic structures on short, nanometer length scales. However, probing structural features on such a short length scale has historically been a difficult undertaking because conventional methods lack the required sensitivity. This project overcomes that challenge by using advanced neutron scattering methods and other complementary techniques to study three classes of materials with significant technological potential: (1) Magnetic thermoelectrics, in which magnetic properties can enhance the ability to convert thermal gradients into electrical energy via the thermoelectric effect; (2) magnetocalorics, which enable magnetic control of thermal energy; and (3) multiferroics, characterized by the ability to control electrical properties by magnetic means and vice versa. Experiments will be done at Department of Energy user facilities to reveal the connection between the observed properties and the short-range atomic and magnetic correlations in these materials, with the aim of transforming our understanding of the origin of the functional properties and guiding future materials discovery and optimization efforts. As a natural byproduct, the research will also aid in the development of cutting-edge neutron scattering techniques. The project features prominent involvement of undergraduate and graduate students, who will go on to fill important needs in the national STEM workforce.

With guidance from these models, new porous electrode structures with hierarchical architectures that exhibit functionality unattainable in today’s macroscopically homogeneous electrodes will be developed. This unique scientific program is made possible by several technical advances. An extrusion-based 3D printing method, known as direct ink writing, will be used to fabricate electrode structures composed of periodic mesoscale lattices as well as those with programmed types and strengths of heterogeneities, or hierarchies across multiple length scales. The mapping of molecular concentrations and flow velocities with high spatial and temporal resolution using fluorescence microscopy will be extended from two to three spatial dimensions. Numerical solutions to the equations governing flow, diffusion, migration, advection, electrochemical conversion, and electronic conduction at the individual fiber and pore scale will be developed using a new method that permits large scale simulations at fine spatial resolution. This research program will lead to a deep fundamental understanding of electrolyte-filled porous electrodes. The scientific insights gained will enable the flow cell community to design high-performance electrodes from the bottom up, based solely on knowledge of the physical, chemical, and electrochemical properties of the electrolytes. Ultimately, this will lead to higher efficiencies and power densities, reduced costs, and increased competitiveness of electrochemical devices that rely on electrolyte-filled porous electrodes.

results.title: Nanoelectrochemical characterization of heterogeneous photoelectrocatalysts
results.chunk_text: Nanoelectrochemical characterization of heterogeneous photoelectrocatalysts. Semiconductor nanomaterials, including 2D nanosheets and microscopic single crystals have important technological applications ranging from fuel production to electrosynthesis. The photocatalytic activity is known to be highly heterogeneous both in an ensemble of nanomaterials and within a single particle. results.public_abstract: Semiconductor nanomaterials, including 2D nanosheets and microscopic single crystals have important technological applications ranging from fuel production to electrosynthesis. The photocatalytic activity is known to be highly heterogeneous both in an ensemble of nanomaterials and within a single particle. Despite significant research activity, the understanding of photocatalytic heterogeneity remains incomplete. We propose to use nanoelectrochemical techniques in combination with mathematical modeling to carry out quantitative, spatially resolved photoelectrochemical experiments aimed at measuring photo(electro)catalytic activity and characterizing heterogeneity of a wide range of semiconductor nanomaterials. We will perform extensive experimental studies and computer modeling aimed at probing photochemical and photoelectrochemical water splitting at single semiconductor particles. Scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) will be employed to measure hydrogen and oxygen fluxes generated at single semiconductor micro/nanocrystals. A recently developed experimental setup for photo-SECM measurements at the nanoscale, in which a glass-sealed tip simultaneously serves as a nanoelectrode and a light guide, will be used to evaluate local rates of water splitting processes on different facets and near facet edges of doped BiVO4 microcrystals and map oxygen and hydrogen evolution reaction (OER and HER) rates on Al-doped SrTiO3 cubes modified with RhxCryOz. A novel methodology will be developed for photo-electrochemical experiments at a single microcrystal attached to a nanoelectrode. Heterogeneous photoelectrocatalytic reactivity of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenide (MoS2 and others) exfoliated nanoflakes and monolayers will be mapped using two modes of photo-SECM. The generation/collection mode with small nanotips will be used to map HER active sites, and mathematical modeling and finite-element simulations will be performed to extract quantitative kinetic information from the experimental data. The tunneling mode of photo-SECM will be developed and used for ultrahigh resolution imaging of surface reactivity of 2D materials. The anticipated results will contribute to the understanding of factors influencing the activity and stability of 2D photoelectrocatalysts and help to improve these properties. We will employ nanoelectrochemical approaches to put forward new strategies for development of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis. Photo-SECM will be used to map active sites on heterogeneous photo(electro)catalytic surfaces. A new concept of voltage-driven molecular photoelectrocatalysis will be explored in which a molecular catalyst is directly (i.e., without a spacer) attached to the electrode surface, and the applied potential contributes to the driving force for the catalytic reaction. The proposed experimental studies and modeling will contribute to the molecular-level understanding of charge-transfer processes in nanostructured photoelectrocatalytic systems, which is essential for the progress in solar energy conversion, fuel generation, and energy-efficient synthesis. The expected major products of the proposed research are (1) new methodology for spatially resolved, quantitative studies of HER and OER processes at single semiconductor microcrystals; (2) nanoscale maps of photocatalytic reactivities and active sites on 2D photo(electro)catalytic surfaces; and (3) new experimental approaches to the development and characterization of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis. The anticipated results will impact the important BES technologies, including the photo(electro)catalytic splitting of water, and contribute to research efforts of other groups within Solar Photochemistry program.

The research portion of the training program will investigate the development of new compounds for binding and sequestering uranium, a key nuclear fuel. The isolation of uranium and other nuclear fuels is essential for non-carbon based energy independence. Isoindolines are inexpensive and non-toxic compounds that are frequently used to make dyes and pigments. This chemistry has not been appreciably investigated with actinide elements such as uranium. Additionally, the electrochemical properties of the resultant compounds will be investigated since electrochemical separation is often used to isolate different actinide elements from mixtures. Promising sequestration candidates will be shared with Oak Ridge National Laboratory for further evaluation. The training component of the program seeks to increase workers in both nuclear chemistry and related fields, as well as prepare students for matriculation into chemistry graduate programs. The program will use a tiered mentoring system that will utilize interactions between the faculty mentors, graduate students, and the undergraduate cohort. The training curriculum will last a year, starting in January and lasting through December, and there will be two training periods during the exploratory program. In addition to regular research during the spring and fall semesters, there will be scheduled group meetings (covering conduct of science, scientific writing and presentations, and usage of the scientific literature), career and graduate school mentoring, and presentation of research data by students at university, regional, and national meetings. During the summer, the student cohort research will continue; participants will be supported with a stipend for a six-week research period and will participate in a trip to Oak Ridge National Laboratory. The goals for the program are that 75% of participants will either seek employment in nuclear chemistry or related careers or will continue their education in graduate programs.

results.title: Leveraging Macrocyclic Chelators for Rare Earth Element Separations
results.chunk_text: Significant technological advances in and growing commercial demand for batteries, permanent magnets, wind turbines, liquid crystal displays, and portable electronics have driven a need for an increased domestic supply of the rare earth elements. The rare earth elements, which are elements residing near the bottom of the periodic table, are naturally abundant in various ore deposits across the globe, including the United States. Despite their domestic availability, these elements are most often obtained from foreign nations, a consequence of the environmental harm that is caused by their extraction. A significant contributing factor to the costliness and environmental damage of their harvest from natural ores lies within their chemical separation from one another. The rare earth elements occur in nature together, yet need to be separated in their pure elemental form to be used for various technological applications. The chemical similarities of these elements make this separation energy inefficient and environmentally harmful. This project is focusing on developing new strategies to separate the rare earth elements in more efficient and environmentally benign ways. The approach taken by this work is to design new synthetic receptors for the rare earth elements, called chelators. These chelators, which form direct chemical bonds with metal ions, are being synthesized and modified to attain distinct affinity patterns for the different rare earth elements. By tuning these selectivity patterns, we are able to use the chelators to achieve rare earth element separations. Toward this overall goal, the project is divided into several objectives. The first objective is focused on designing chelators that have a unique selectivity pattern that enables them to bind to both small and large rare earth elements with equal affinity, while exhibiting poor affinity for those of intermediate size. These chelators are being optimized so that they can be used to achieve unique separations to selectively afford rare earth elements within the middle of the series. In the second objective of this project, we are designing chelators that can alter the “outer-sphere” of the rare earth elements. The outer-sphere represents the surrounding solvent and ions in solutions, and thus provide secondary types of interactions that are not afforded by conventional chelators. These chelators are being designed in order to fine-tune rare earth element selectivity patterns to enable novel separations. In the third objective, we are exploring the use of chelators with other small metal-binding compounds to form what are known as ternary complexes. The addition of secondary metal-binding units provides another means to achieve distinct rare earth separations

results.public_abstract: The objective of this research program is to fundamentally understand flow cell porous electrodes -- such as those used in fuel cells, flow batteries, electrolyzers, and desalination systems -- as active composite materials for the electrochemical transformation of flowing liquid electrolytes. The microstructural features of macroscopically homogeneous porous electrodes will be varied and their influence on mass and charge transport processes will be visualized, measured, and analyzed. With the resulting insight, new theories and models will be developed to describe the behavior of these materials across multiple length scales. With guidance from these models, new porous electrode structures with hierarchical architectures that exhibit functionality unattainable in today’s macroscopically homogeneous electrodes will be developed. This unique scientific program is made possible by several technical advances. An extrusion-based 3D printing method, known as direct ink writing, will be used to fabricate electrode structures composed of periodic mesoscale lattices as well as those with programmed types and strengths of heterogeneities, or hierarchies across multiple length scales. The mapping of molecular concentrations and flow velocities with high spatial and temporal resolution using fluorescence microscopy will be extended from two to three spatial dimensions. Numerical solutions to the equations governing flow, diffusion, migration, advection, electrochemical conversion, and electronic conduction at the individual fiber and pore scale will be developed using a new method that permits large scale simulations at fine spatial resolution. This research program will lead to a deep fundamental understanding of electrolyte-filled porous electrodes. The scientific insights gained will enable the flow cell community to design high-performance electrodes from the bottom up, based solely on knowledge of the physical, chemical, and electrochemical properties of the electrolytes. Ultimately, this will lead to higher efficiencies and power densities, reduced costs, and increased competitiveness of electrochemical devices that rely on electrolyte-filled porous electrodes.

results.title: Probing Short-Range Structure and Magnetism In Next-Generation Energy Conversion Materials
results.chunk_text: Next-generation materials will play a crucial role in transformative technologies that can address critical societal issues, such as the need to harness, store, and convert energy in a sustainable way. Many candidate materials for technological application derive their exceptional properties from the complex interplay between their atomic and magnetic structures on short, nanometer length scales. However, probing structural features on such a short length scale has historically been a difficult undertaking because conventional methods lack the required sensitivity. This project overcomes that challenge by using advanced neutron scattering methods and other complementary techniques to study three classes of materials with significant technological potential: (1) Magnetic thermoelectrics, in which magnetic properties can enhance the ability to convert thermal gradients into electrical energy via the thermoelectric effect; (2) magnetocalorics, which enable magnetic control of thermal energy; and (3) multiferroics, characterized by the ability to control electrical properties by magnetic means and vice versa. Experiments will be done at Department of Energy user facilities to reveal the connection between the observed properties and the short-range atomic and magnetic correlations in these materials, with the aim of transforming our understanding of the origin of the functional properties and guiding future materials discovery and optimization efforts. As a natural byproduct, the research will also aid in the development of cutting-edge neutron scattering techniques. The project features prominent involvement of undergraduate and graduate students, who will go on to fill important needs in the national STEM workforce.

results.title: Developing Novel Electrolytes to Suppress Transition Metal Dissolution in Battery Cathodes Using Multimodal Characterization (- View Less)
results.chunk_text: Developing Novel Electrolytes to Suppress Transition Metal Dissolution Using Multimodal Characterization Lead PI: Dr. Tao Li1, Associate Professor Co-PI(s): Dr. Luxi Li2, Beamline Scientist 1: Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL 60115 2: Argonne National Laboratory, Lemont, IL 60439 Abstract: This research aims to develop innovative electrolyte formulations that prevent the dissolution of transition metals from lithium-ion battery cathodes, a key factor in battery performance degradation. By systematically varying electrolyte composition and concentration, the project seeks to understand and control the solvation structures of lithium ions. These solvation structures—how lithium ions are stabilized by surrounding molecules—are critical to how the electrolyte interacts with the cathode surface. Insights into these interactions will inform the rational design of next-generation electrolytes that minimize transition metal loss, enhancing battery stability and longevity. The research will employ a combination of advanced characterization techniques, including X-ray scattering, X-ray fluorescence microscopy, and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy. These tools will be used to investigate the atomic-level changes at the electrolyte-cathode interface, as well as map the distribution of transition metals within the battery. Understanding these dynamics will be crucial for developing electrolytes that effectively inhibit transition metal dissolution during battery operation. The collaboration between Northern Illinois University and Argonne National Laboratory combines expertise in chemistry and materials science with state-of-the-art experimental resources. This partnership will enable a comprehensive investigation of how electrolyte formulations impact battery performance, contributing to the broader goal of advancing energy storage technologies. By addressing one of the critical challenges in lithium-ion batteries, this research will help improve the performance and lifespan of energy storage systems used in electric vehicles and renewable energy applications. The outcomes will have significant implications for the development of more sustainable and efficient batteries, aligning with national priorities to reduce carbon emissions and promote energy independence. Additionally, our scientific training and outcome will be integrated into educational programs to promote STEM education and raise public awareness about energy storage.

results.public_abstract: Lattice instabilities and emergent collective phases and behavior rooted in the quantum world PI: Valeri Petkov, Department of Physics, Central Michigan University The remarkable properties of quantum materials result from strong interactions among their electronic, lattice and spin degrees of freedom and the rich variety of ordered electronic phases that emerge as a consequence, often in a close proximity to each other. If understood and controlled at atomic level, their properties could revolutionize virtually every aspect of science and technology. A fundamental feature of many quantum materials is the locally broken crystal symmetry and presence of lattice distortions due to lattice instabilities. The properties of such materials are difficult to understand because local lattice distortions are difficult to assess using traditional crystallographic techniques. This project aims to advance through fundamental research the atomic-level understanding of collective electronic phases and behavior emerging in quantum materials exhibiting local lattice distortions. Our hypothesis is that, in many quantum materials, lattice distortions are not induced by changes in the electronic structure but appear as an independent degree of freedom that bridges electronic phases the materials may exhibit. To verify the hypothesis, we will employ resonant total x-ray scattering coupled to atomic pair distribution function analysis and large-scale 3D modeling to study the interaction between lattice distortions, electronic and magnetic degrees of freedom in charge density wave and Mott insulating systems exhibiting competing superconducting, electronic and magnetic orders. Since emergent phenomena are very sensitive to external stimuli, we will study the interaction as important physical parameters such as temperature, chemical composition and/or magnetic field are varied in a controlled manner. An integral part of our effort is the further development of resonant total x-ray scattering as a tool to study the local atomic structure of materials exhibiting any type of structural distortions with both high real-space resolution and chemical specificity. In particular, taking advantage of the improved capabilities of 4th generation synchrotron radiation sources, such as the Advanced Photon Source at the Argonne National laboratory, we will implement single-photon, two-dimensional detectors to facilitate the acquisition of experimental data, enabling in-situ studies. We will also develop improved experimental data processing and modeling procedures, including user-friendly software. Results from the research will elucidate the basic physics behind fascinating phenomena in quantum materials, creating opportunities to leverage their enormous technological potential. Also, they will benefit a large community of scientists using advanced x-ray scattering techniques to study materials exhibiting structural distortions, ranging from electrolytes, glasses and nanoparticles to multiferroics, topological insulators, charge density wave systems and superconductors.

During the summer, the student cohort research will continue; participants will be supported with a stipend for a six-week research period and will participate in a trip to Oak Ridge National Laboratory. The expansion of output from geothermal well sites will be an important part of the US and world energy future in order to maintain a growing base load while minimizing carbon emissions. To maximize the output and lifespan of a geothermal well, it is beneficial to monitor several parameters, including mass flow rate of both steam and water of the geofluid in real-time. This allows operators to detect changes in well health and to optimize output. Current methods are not sufficiently accurate, cannot be done in real- time, or are cost prohibitive to use for each well individually. This project proposes to develop a real-time flow measurement system that can provide the mass flow rate, liquid/vapor fraction, and the energy content, or enthalpy, to plant operators. A laboratory scale prototype flow measurement system was constructed and installed in a lab test fixture that simulated the flow of steam and water in a geothermal plant. The prototype system performed extremely well, providing real-time flow rate results with accuracy generally within 5%. This is a significant increase over the current flow measurement methods, which have errors as high as 20% and do not provide data real-time. Several prototypes will be developed at full scale and tested both in a laboratory and in actual operating geothermal wells. The field test will prove out the system under real world conditions and showcase the benefits of real-time, accurate data to plant operators. The success of this project will provide a new and unique flow meter for geothermal systems. The data from the measurement system will allow plant operators to track the heat energy from individual wells in real-time, which will provide greater insight on the evolution of geothermal reservoirs over time to maximize efficiency and production potential. Operators will be able to pinpoint the high and low production wells and achieve greater overall production capacity from each geothermal plant.

results.title: Development of Durable Superhydrophobic Coated Proppants for Enhanced Geothermal Systems (EGS) to Mitigate Mineral Scaling and Improve Fracture Longevity (- View Less)
results.chunk_text: Enhanced Geothermal Systems (EGS) face challenges with mineral scaling, which reduces system efficiency and increases maintenance costs. Current superhydrophobic coatings, while effective in mitigating mineral scaling, have limitations in mechanical durability, thermal resistance, and chemical stability when exposed to the extreme conditions found in geothermal environments. Addressing these issues is crucial for the widespread adoption of these coatings in EGS applications. To overcome these limitations, a novel superhydrophobic proppant coating technology is being developed using a specific ceramic nanoparticle integrated into a polymeric matrix. This approach aims to improve durability, thermal stability, and chemical resistance, making the coating more suitable for the harsh geothermal conditions. The enhanced proppants will contribute to reducing mineral scaling and improving the efficiency and operational lifespan of EGS. The Phase I project will focus on optimizing the ceramic-polymer coating for sand particles used in EGS. In collaboration with the University of Utah team, resourced by the FORGE project, the coated proppants will be rigorously tested for thermal stability, mechanical durability, and mineral scaling resistance under simulated geothermal conditions. The University of Utah’s expertise and advanced facilities will support comprehensive performance evaluations, ensuring the proposed technology meets the demands of geothermal applications. An economic feasibility analysis will be conducted to determine potential cost savings and efficiency gains, followed by regular reporting and stakeholder engagement to ensure successful project execution and knowledge dissemination. The developed superhydrophobic proppants can be used in geothermal energy production and hydraulic fracturing to prevent mineral scaling, maintain fracture permeability, and improve energy extraction efficiency. This technology extends the lifespan of geothermal wells, reduces maintenance costs, and lowers the Levelized Cost of Energy. Public benefits include more sustainable and cost-effective energy production, reduced environmental impact due to decreased use of chemical treatments, and lower greenhouse gas emissions. The enhanced efficiency of geothermal systems supports broader adoption of clean energy, contributing to energy security and a more sustainable energy future.

results.institution: The Trustees of Princeton University, Princeton, NJ
results.public_abstract: This project focuses on liquid water, a critical material shaping geochemistry and life on our planet. The overarching goal is to understand how water adopts distinct properties when placed in contact with different surfaces. Key surfaces examined are clay minerals and related solids (e.g., mica) that play central roles in soil health and subsurface energy, including in soil resilience to erosion and drought, geologic CO2 sequestration, nuclear waste isolation, and enhanced geothermal energy. The approach followed in the project uses high-performance computing, supported by atomistic-level experimental characterization, to elucidate the nanoscale properties of water in clay interlayer nanopores and in adsorbed water films on mica and silica surfaces. In particular, molecular dynamics (MD) simulations are used to reveal the behavior of individual atoms in complex systems (where spectroscopic and other experimental methods probe the average behavior of large numbers of atoms or molecules) and the manner in which the collective properties of assemblages of millions of water molecules emerge from atomistic-level interactions. A first major focus of the project is on understanding the selective transport properties of water-filled nanopores. In other words, how do nanopores selectively transport water vs. salt, or cations vs. anions? A second major focus is on understanding the stability of adsorbed water films on mineral surfaces. Finally, a third focus is on advancing MD simulation capabilities by combining simulations with synchrotron X-ray reflectivity and Terahertz spectroscopy experiments. The research relies on simulations carried out at the National Energy Research Scientific Computing Center (NERSC), a US Department of Energy facility located at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (LBNL), and on Princeton University’s high-performance computing clusters. The project involves collaborations with scientists at the Argonne National Laboratory (ANL), the Sandia National Laboratories (SNL), and the University of Ruhr-Bochum. A key projected outcome is the critical re-examination of existing models and theories used to describe the properties of water in nanopores and thin films, including models of water and solute transport in nanopores and models of disjoining pressure in adsorbed water films. Beyond the Geosciences, this research aims to generate fundamental scientific knowledge relevant to nanofiltration and reverse osmosis membranes; wettability and multiphase flow; chemical synthesis using interfacial or confined water as a green solvent; and other scientific areas. Finally, the project aims to accelerate the development of advanced nanogeochemical experimental approaches for the characterization of geologic media and processes, including Terahertz spectroscopy and synchrotron X-ray reflectivity experiments.

results.title: MXene-Engineered Superhydrophobic Nanosheets and Nanocomposites: Advanced Anti-Scaling Solutions for Enhanced Geothermal Systems (- View Less)
results.chunk_text: Mineral scaling in Enhanced Geothermal Systems (EGS) represents a significant challenge, where solid deposits from geothermal brines (e.g., the temperature- or pressure-induced precipitation of silicates, carbonates, sulfates, and other mineral species) critically impair the efficiency of heat extraction and energy production. These deposits obstruct fluid flow, diminish heat exchange efficiency, potential equipment failures, and necessitate frequent maintenance interventions, leading to operational inefficiencies and increased costs. Numerous de-scaling strategies, including chemical inhibitors, mechanical removal, thermal management, etc., have been proposed and implemented; however, each of these methods presents practical limitations, especially when applied within the harsh environment of EGS. The major obstacle for these methods is the requirement for regular system shutdowns to perform maintenance, recalibration, or cleaning, exacerbating operational disruptions and economic burdens. Therefore, there is a critical need for innovative approaches to continuously and effectively inhibit mineral scaling, ensuring the long-term viability of the equipment and the cost-effectiveness of the EGS. This research aims to develop a novel class of functionalized MXenes nanocomposite (dubbed as HydroShield-X) with superhydrophobic properties as a descaling agent in EGS systems. MXene nanosheets, known for their stability under extreme conditions, will be transformed from hydrophilic to superhydrophobic using optimal surface functionalizations identified through atomistic-level simulations. These coatings will be tested in laboratory setups mimicking geothermal conditions, including high temperatures (~350°C) and pressures (~20 MPa), to validate their antiscaling performance and durability. Initial lab-scale development in Phase I will be followed by commercial-scale production in Phase II and field testing potentially at the DOE-funded Frontier Observatory for Research in Geothermal Energy (FORGE) site at Utah. HydroShield-X offers a cost-effective and environmentally friendly alternative to traditional methods, enhances the longevity of the equipment, reduces maintenance downtime, and is scalable to various operational conditions. This product is expected to provide a transformative solution for industries facing scaling issues, such as geothermal, oil and gas, and other geo-energy sectors, e.g., underground hydrogen storage. Additionally, in Phase I, as part of the PIER plan, MetaScape will hire a graduate student as a summer intern from University of Utah. The intern will be selected from minority groups and/or marginalized populations and will receive rigorous training on simulation models for complex material development and interpersonal skills

results.title: Chemical Kinetic Data of Benchmark Accuracy through Multi-Scale Informatics Strategies
results.chunk_text: The reliability of predictive simulations for clean energy conversion devices depends on the availability of accurate data for thermochemistry, chemical kinetics, and transport. In that regard, accurate data are critically important for both their direct use in predictive simulations and for benchmarking improved theoretical methodologies that can similarly produce accurate data for predictive simulations. The use of informatics-based strategies for the determination of accurate thermochemical data with well-defined uncertainties, i.e. the Active Thermochemical Tables (ATcT), has revolutionized the field of thermochemistry—ATcT provides thermochemical data of unprecedented accuracy for direct use in predictive simulation and has served as a key enabler of ab initio electronic structure methodologies of equally impressive accuracy. In this program, we are developing an analogous active database for chemical kinetics to establish high-accuracy kinetic data for predictive simulation and to evaluate emerging ab initio theoretical kinetics methods, using novel multiscale informatics strategies we are developing. Particular emphasis is placed on reaction systems for which non-thermal kinetic sequences arise and/or for which combining theoretical and experimental data is necessary to unravel complex reaction data into chemical information, where this program advances the state of the art in computational methodologies for those purposes. By improving understanding of reaction dynamics, energy flow, and non-equilibrium kinetics, this program contributes insights for ultrafast chemistry, reaction pathways in diverse environments, and systems chemistry of broad impact to Chemical Sciences, Geosciences, & Biosciences (CSGB).

results.title: Assessing the relative contributions of fluid pressure and elastic stress perturbations to induced seismic energy release (- View Less)
results.chunk_text: Assessing the relative contributions of fluid pressure and elastic stress perturbations to induced seismic energy release Thomas H. Goebel, University of Memphis (Principal Investigator) The complexity of induced seismicity mechanisms significantly hampers seismic hazard assessment around injection wells. The largest magnitude events are commonly thought to be controlled by the size of the injection-affected area. However, what controls the size of this area and how important are regional tectonic structures? We propose to unravel the dominant mechanisms that promote far-reaching induced stress perturbations and earthquakes. While both pressure and elastic stress effects may trigger induced events at large distances from wells, the relative contribution of these effects to total seismic-moment-release remains to be understood. A key component in determining the importance of pressure vs. elastic stress effects are more robust constraints on crustal hydrology. We will study the processes that govern fault hydrology and slip using a multi-scale approach. We will measure fault-slip-induced permeability changes in a densely instrumented geothermal reservoir in Nevada. We will use rock-cores from this reservoir to perform earthquake-analog experiments and to examine the physical mechanisms of permeability changes. Based on insights from reservoir and lab studies, we will be able to model the extent of fluid migration from injection sites and compute the seismic energy released as a result of direct pressure vs. elastic stress effects. Insights from this study are expected to improve the understanding of coupled fault slip and hydrology as well as the overall hydraulic connectivity of upper crustal regimes. We will explore conditions that encourage slip-induced permeability enhancement and investigate implications for injection-induced seismic hazard.

results.chunk_text: Mineral scaling in Enhanced Geothermal Systems (EGS) represents a significant challenge, where solid deposits from geothermal brines (e.g., the temperature- or pressure-induced precipitation of silicates, carbonates, sulfates, and other mineral species) critically impair the efficiency of heat extraction and energy production. These deposits obstruct fluid flow, diminish heat exchange efficiency, potential equipment failures, and necessitate frequent maintenance interventions, leading to operational inefficiencies and increased costs. Numerous de-scaling strategies, including chemical inhibitors, mechanical removal, thermal management, etc., have been proposed and implemented; however, each of these methods presents practical limitations, especially when applied within the harsh environment of EGS. The major obstacle for these methods is the requirement for regular system shutdowns to perform maintenance, recalibration, or cleaning, exacerbating operational disruptions and economic burdens. Therefore, there is a critical need for innovative approaches to continuously and effectively inhibit mineral scaling, ensuring the long-term viability of the equipment and the cost-effectiveness of the EGS. This research aims to develop a novel class of functionalized MXenes nanocomposite (dubbed as HydroShield-X) with superhydrophobic properties as a descaling agent in EGS systems. MXene nanosheets, known for their stability under extreme conditions, will be transformed from hydrophilic to superhydrophobic using optimal surface functionalizations identified through atomistic-level simulations. These coatings will be tested in laboratory setups mimicking geothermal conditions, including high temperatures (~350°C) and pressures (~20 MPa), to validate their antiscaling performance and durability. Initial lab-scale development in Phase I will be followed by commercial-scale production in Phase II and field testing potentially at the DOE-funded Frontier Observatory for Research in Geothermal Energy (FORGE) site at Utah. HydroShield-X offers a cost-effective and environmentally friendly alternative to traditional methods, enhances the longevity of the equipment, reduces maintenance downtime, and is scalable to various operational conditions. The expansion of output from geothermal well sites will be an important part of the US and world energy future in order to maintain a growing base load while minimizing carbon emissions. This allows operators to detect changes in well health and to optimize output. Current methods are not sufficiently accurate, cannot be done in real- time, or are cost prohibitive to use for each well individually. This project proposes to develop a real-time flow measurement system that can provide the mass flow rate, liquid/vapor fraction, and the energy content, or enthalpy, to plant operators. A laboratory scale prototype flow measurement system was constructed and installed in a lab test fixture that simulated the flow of steam and water in a geothermal plant. The prototype system performed extremely well, providing real-time flow rate results with accuracy generally within 5%. This is a significant increase over the current flow measurement methods, which have errors as high as 20% and do not provide data real-time.
