The field test will prove out the system under real world conditions and showcase the benefits of real-time, accurate data to plant operators. The success of this project will provide a new and unique flow meter for geothermal systems. The data from the measurement system will allow plant operators to track the heat energy from individual wells in real-time, which will provide greater insight on the evolution of geothermal reservoirs over time to maximize efficiency and production potential. Operators will be able to pinpoint the high and low production wells and achieve greater overall production capacity from each geothermal plant.

results.title: Development of Durable Superhydrophobic Coated Proppants for Enhanced Geothermal Systems (EGS) to Mitigate Mineral Scaling and Improve Fracture Longevity (- View Less)
results.chunk_text: Enhanced Geothermal Systems (EGS) face challenges with mineral scaling, which reduces system efficiency and increases maintenance costs. Current superhydrophobic coatings, while effective in mitigating mineral scaling, have limitations in mechanical durability, thermal resistance, and chemical stability when exposed to the extreme conditions found in geothermal environments. Addressing these issues is crucial for the widespread adoption of these coatings in EGS applications. To overcome these limitations, a novel superhydrophobic proppant coating technology is being developed using a specific ceramic nanoparticle integrated into a polymeric matrix. This approach aims to improve durability, thermal stability, and chemical resistance, making the coating more suitable for the harsh geothermal conditions. The enhanced proppants will contribute to reducing mineral scaling and improving the efficiency and operational lifespan of EGS. The Phase I project will focus on optimizing the ceramic-polymer coating for sand particles used in EGS. In collaboration with the University of Utah team, resourced by the FORGE project, the coated proppants will be rigorously tested for thermal stability, mechanical durability, and mineral scaling resistance under simulated geothermal conditions. The University of Utah’s expertise and advanced facilities will support comprehensive performance evaluations, ensuring the proposed technology meets the demands of geothermal applications. An economic feasibility analysis will be conducted to determine potential cost savings and efficiency gains, followed by regular reporting and stakeholder engagement to ensure successful project execution and knowledge dissemination. The developed superhydrophobic proppants can be used in geothermal energy production and hydraulic fracturing to prevent mineral scaling, maintain fracture permeability, and improve energy extraction efficiency. This technology extends the lifespan of geothermal wells, reduces maintenance costs, and lowers the Levelized Cost of Energy. Public benefits include more sustainable and cost-effective energy production, reduced environmental impact due to decreased use of chemical treatments, and lower greenhouse gas emissions. The enhanced efficiency of geothermal systems supports broader adoption of clean energy, contributing to energy security and a more sustainable energy future.

results.title: Assessing the relative contributions of fluid pressure and elastic stress perturbations to induced seismic energy release (- View Less)
results.chunk_text: Assessing the relative contributions of fluid pressure and elastic stress perturbations to induced seismic energy release Thomas H. Goebel, University of Memphis (Principal Investigator) The complexity of induced seismicity mechanisms significantly hampers seismic hazard assessment around injection wells. The largest magnitude events are commonly thought to be controlled by the size of the injection-affected area. However, what controls the size of this area and how important are regional tectonic structures? We propose to unravel the dominant mechanisms that promote far-reaching induced stress perturbations and earthquakes. While both pressure and elastic stress effects may trigger induced events at large distances from wells, the relative contribution of these effects to total seismic-moment-release remains to be understood. A key component in determining the importance of pressure vs. elastic stress effects are more robust constraints on crustal hydrology. We will study the processes that govern fault hydrology and slip using a multi-scale approach. We will measure fault-slip-induced permeability changes in a densely instrumented geothermal reservoir in Nevada. We will use rock-cores from this reservoir to perform earthquake-analog experiments and to examine the physical mechanisms of permeability changes. Based on insights from reservoir and lab studies, we will be able to model the extent of fluid migration from injection sites and compute the seismic energy released as a result of direct pressure vs. elastic stress effects. Insights from this study are expected to improve the understanding of coupled fault slip and hydrology as well as the overall hydraulic connectivity of upper crustal regimes. We will explore conditions that encourage slip-induced permeability enhancement and investigate implications for injection-induced seismic hazard.

results.public_abstract: The objective of this research program is to fundamentally understand flow cell porous electrodes -- such as those used in fuel cells, flow batteries, electrolyzers, and desalination systems -- as active composite materials for the electrochemical transformation of flowing liquid electrolytes. The microstructural features of macroscopically homogeneous porous electrodes will be varied and their influence on mass and charge transport processes will be visualized, measured, and analyzed. With the resulting insight, new theories and models will be developed to describe the behavior of these materials across multiple length scales. With guidance from these models, new porous electrode structures with hierarchical architectures that exhibit functionality unattainable in today’s macroscopically homogeneous electrodes will be developed. This unique scientific program is made possible by several technical advances. An extrusion-based 3D printing method, known as direct ink writing, will be used to fabricate electrode structures composed of periodic mesoscale lattices as well as those with programmed types and strengths of heterogeneities, or hierarchies across multiple length scales. The mapping of molecular concentrations and flow velocities with high spatial and temporal resolution using fluorescence microscopy will be extended from two to three spatial dimensions. Numerical solutions to the equations governing flow, diffusion, migration, advection, electrochemical conversion, and electronic conduction at the individual fiber and pore scale will be developed using a new method that permits large scale simulations at fine spatial resolution. This research program will lead to a deep fundamental understanding of electrolyte-filled porous electrodes. The scientific insights gained will enable the flow cell community to design high-performance electrodes from the bottom up, based solely on knowledge of the physical, chemical, and electrochemical properties of the electrolytes. Ultimately, this will lead to higher efficiencies and power densities, reduced costs, and increased competitiveness of electrochemical devices that rely on electrolyte-filled porous electrodes.

Current superhydrophobic coatings, while effective in mitigating mineral scaling, have limitations in mechanical durability, thermal resistance, and chemical stability when exposed to the extreme conditions found in geothermal environments. Addressing these issues is crucial for the widespread adoption of these coatings in EGS applications. To overcome these limitations, a novel superhydrophobic proppant coating technology is being developed using a specific ceramic nanoparticle integrated into a polymeric matrix. This approach aims to improve durability, thermal stability, and chemical resistance, making the coating more suitable for the harsh geothermal conditions. The enhanced proppants will contribute to reducing mineral scaling and improving the efficiency and operational lifespan of EGS. The Phase I project will focus on optimizing the ceramic-polymer coating for sand particles used in EGS. In collaboration with the University of Utah team, resourced by the FORGE project, the coated proppants will be rigorously tested for thermal stability, mechanical durability, and mineral scaling resistance under simulated geothermal conditions. The University of Utah’s expertise and advanced facilities will support comprehensive performance evaluations, ensuring the proposed technology meets the demands of geothermal applications. An economic feasibility analysis will be conducted to determine potential cost savings and efficiency gains, followed by regular reporting and stakeholder engagement to ensure successful project execution and knowledge dissemination. The developed superhydrophobic proppants can be used in geothermal energy production and hydraulic fracturing to prevent mineral scaling, maintain fracture permeability, and improve energy extraction efficiency. This technology extends the lifespan of geothermal wells, reduces maintenance costs, and lowers the Levelized Cost of Energy. Public benefits include more sustainable and cost-effective energy production, reduced environmental impact due to decreased use of chemical treatments, and lower greenhouse gas emissions. The enhanced efficiency of geothermal systems supports broader adoption of clean energy, contributing to energy security and a more sustainable energy future.

results.title: MXene-Engineered Superhydrophobic Nanosheets and Nanocomposites: Advanced Anti-Scaling Solutions for Enhanced Geothermal Systems (- View Less)
results.chunk_text: Mineral scaling in Enhanced Geothermal Systems (EGS) represents a significant challenge, where solid deposits from geothermal brines (e.g., the temperature- or pressure-induced precipitation of silicates, carbonates, sulfates, and other mineral species) critically impair the efficiency of heat extraction and energy production. These deposits obstruct fluid flow, diminish heat exchange efficiency, potential equipment failures, and necessitate frequent maintenance interventions, leading to operational inefficiencies and increased costs. Numerous de-scaling strategies, including chemical inhibitors, mechanical removal, thermal management, etc., have been proposed and implemented; however, each of these methods presents practical limitations, especially when applied within the harsh environment of EGS. The major obstacle for these methods is the requirement for regular system shutdowns to perform maintenance, recalibration, or cleaning, exacerbating operational disruptions and economic burdens. Therefore, there is a critical need for innovative approaches to continuously and effectively inhibit mineral scaling, ensuring the long-term viability of the equipment and the cost-effectiveness of the EGS. This research aims to develop a novel class of functionalized MXenes nanocomposite (dubbed as HydroShield-X) with superhydrophobic properties as a descaling agent in EGS systems. MXene nanosheets, known for their stability under extreme conditions, will be transformed from hydrophilic to superhydrophobic using optimal surface functionalizations identified through atomistic-level simulations. These coatings will be tested in laboratory setups mimicking geothermal conditions, including high temperatures (~350°C) and pressures (~20 MPa), to validate their antiscaling performance and durability. Initial lab-scale development in Phase I will be followed by commercial-scale production in Phase II and field testing potentially at the DOE-funded Frontier Observatory for Research in Geothermal Energy (FORGE) site at Utah. HydroShield-X offers a cost-effective and environmentally friendly alternative to traditional methods, enhances the longevity of the equipment, reduces maintenance downtime, and is scalable to various operational conditions. This product is expected to provide a transformative solution for industries facing scaling issues, such as geothermal, oil and gas, and other geo-energy sectors, e.g., underground hydrogen storage. Additionally, in Phase I, as part of the PIER plan, MetaScape will hire a graduate student as a summer intern from University of Utah. The intern will be selected from minority groups and/or marginalized populations and will receive rigorous training on simulation models for complex material development and interpersonal skills

results.institution: The Trustees of Princeton University, Princeton, NJ
results.public_abstract: This project focuses on liquid water, a critical material shaping geochemistry and life on our planet. The overarching goal is to understand how water adopts distinct properties when placed in contact with different surfaces. Key surfaces examined are clay minerals and related solids (e.g., mica) that play central roles in soil health and subsurface energy, including in soil resilience to erosion and drought, geologic CO2 sequestration, nuclear waste isolation, and enhanced geothermal energy. The approach followed in the project uses high-performance computing, supported by atomistic-level experimental characterization, to elucidate the nanoscale properties of water in clay interlayer nanopores and in adsorbed water films on mica and silica surfaces. In particular, molecular dynamics (MD) simulations are used to reveal the behavior of individual atoms in complex systems (where spectroscopic and other experimental methods probe the average behavior of large numbers of atoms or molecules) and the manner in which the collective properties of assemblages of millions of water molecules emerge from atomistic-level interactions. A first major focus of the project is on understanding the selective transport properties of water-filled nanopores. In other words, how do nanopores selectively transport water vs. salt, or cations vs. anions? A second major focus is on understanding the stability of adsorbed water films on mineral surfaces. Finally, a third focus is on advancing MD simulation capabilities by combining simulations with synchrotron X-ray reflectivity and Terahertz spectroscopy experiments. The research relies on simulations carried out at the National Energy Research Scientific Computing Center (NERSC), a US Department of Energy facility located at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (LBNL), and on Princeton University’s high-performance computing clusters. The project involves collaborations with scientists at the Argonne National Laboratory (ANL), the Sandia National Laboratories (SNL), and the University of Ruhr-Bochum. A key projected outcome is the critical re-examination of existing models and theories used to describe the properties of water in nanopores and thin films, including models of water and solute transport in nanopores and models of disjoining pressure in adsorbed water films. Beyond the Geosciences, this research aims to generate fundamental scientific knowledge relevant to nanofiltration and reverse osmosis membranes; wettability and multiphase flow; chemical synthesis using interfacial or confined water as a green solvent; and other scientific areas. Finally, the project aims to accelerate the development of advanced nanogeochemical experimental approaches for the characterization of geologic media and processes, including Terahertz spectroscopy and synchrotron X-ray reflectivity experiments.

results.title: Geothermal Flow Rate and Liquid/Vapor Fraction Measurement System
results.chunk_text: Electricity production via geothermal energy has zero emissions and can run 24/7 with little down time. The expansion of output from geothermal well sites will be an important part of the US and world energy future in order to maintain a growing base load while minimizing carbon emissions. To maximize the output and lifespan of a geothermal well, it is beneficial to monitor several parameters, including mass flow rate of both steam and water of the geofluid in real-time. This allows operators to detect changes in well health and to optimize output. Current methods are not sufficiently accurate, cannot be done in real- time, or are cost prohibitive to use for each well individually. This project proposes to develop a real-time flow measurement system that can provide the mass flow rate, liquid/vapor fraction, and the energy content, or enthalpy, to plant operators. A laboratory scale prototype flow measurement system was constructed and installed in a lab test fixture that simulated the flow of steam and water in a geothermal plant. The prototype system performed extremely well, providing real-time flow rate results with accuracy generally within 5%. This is a significant increase over the current flow measurement methods, which have errors as high as 20% and do not provide data real-time. Several prototypes will be developed at full scale and tested both in a laboratory and in actual operating geothermal wells. The field test will prove out the system under real world conditions and showcase the benefits of real-time, accurate data to plant operators. The success of this project will provide a new and unique flow meter for geothermal systems. The data from the measurement system will allow plant operators to track the heat energy from individual wells in real-time, which will provide greater insight on the evolution of geothermal reservoirs over time to maximize efficiency and production potential. Operators will be able to pinpoint the high and low production wells and achieve greater overall production capacity from each geothermal plant.

results.title: Assessing the relative contributions of fluid pressure and elastic stress perturbations to induced seismic energy release (- View Less)
results.chunk_text: Assessing the relative contributions of fluid pressure and elastic stress perturbations to induced seismic energy release Thomas H. Goebel, University of Memphis (Principal Investigator) The complexity of induced seismicity mechanisms significantly hampers seismic hazard assessment around injection wells. The largest magnitude events are commonly thought to be controlled by the size of the injection-affected area. However, what controls the size of this area and how important are regional tectonic structures? We propose to unravel the dominant mechanisms that promote far-reaching induced stress perturbations and earthquakes. While both pressure and elastic stress effects may trigger induced events at large distances from wells, the relative contribution of these effects to total seismic-moment-release remains to be understood. A key component in determining the importance of pressure vs. elastic stress effects are more robust constraints on crustal hydrology. We will study the processes that govern fault hydrology and slip using a multi-scale approach. We will measure fault-slip-induced permeability changes in a densely instrumented geothermal reservoir in Nevada. We will use rock-cores from this reservoir to perform earthquake-analog experiments and to examine the physical mechanisms of permeability changes. Based on insights from reservoir and lab studies, we will be able to model the extent of fluid migration from injection sites and compute the seismic energy released as a result of direct pressure vs. elastic stress effects. Insights from this study are expected to improve the understanding of coupled fault slip and hydrology as well as the overall hydraulic connectivity of upper crustal regimes. We will explore conditions that encourage slip-induced permeability enhancement and investigate implications for injection-induced seismic hazard.

results.public_abstract: Understanding Degradation Mechanisms and Rates in Acidic Metal Oxide Oxygen Evolution Electrocatalysts Dr. Christopher Rhodes1, Professor Dr. Shaun Alia2 1: Texas State University, San Marcos, TX 78666 2: National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, 80401 Green hydrogen, produced from splitting water with renewable electricity, is the most critical, not fully demonstrated technology necessary to enable a clean, sustainable energy system aligned with the DOE mission. Proton-exchange membrane (PEM) electrolysis is the favored pathway currently for green hydrogen but has significant fundamental scientific challenges in terms of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalyst used due to the complexity of materials and reactions involved. Our limited understanding of catalyst degradation, which involves surface reconstruction and metal dissolution under the highly oxidizing potentials and corrosive environments encountered during oxygen evolution under acidic conditions, remains a bottleneck to the development of improved catalysts. The project objectives are to develop new research capabilities at Texas State University, in partnership with the National Renewable Energy Laboratory, and to understand how surface reconstruction affects metal dissolution rates and degradation mechanisms in metal oxide OER electrocatalysts. The research scope involves the evaluation of how metal substituents, crystal structure, and defects affect surface reconstruction and degradation. Through this collaborative effort, the project will help advance understanding of surface structure-activity-degradation relationships and inform the development of highly active, durable OER electrocatalysts for lower cost, highly durable PEM electrolyzers while expanding knowledge and infrastructure that can applied to numerous electrocatalytic reactions. The project will also expand research capabilities at Texas State University, one of the largest Hispanic Serving Institutions in the U.S., with a large population of students from underrepresented groups and first-generation college students. results.title: Nanoelectrochemical characterization of heterogeneous photoelectrocatalysts
results.chunk_text: Semiconductor nanomaterials, including 2D nanosheets and microscopic single crystals have important technological applications ranging from fuel production to electrosynthesis. The photocatalytic activity is known to be highly heterogeneous both in an ensemble of nanomaterials and within a single particle. Despite significant research activity, the understanding of photocatalytic heterogeneity remains incomplete. We propose to use nanoelectrochemical techniques in combination with mathematical modeling to carry out quantitative, spatially resolved photoelectrochemical experiments aimed at measuring photo(electro)catalytic activity and characterizing heterogeneity of a wide range of semiconductor nanomaterials. We will perform extensive experimental studies and computer modeling aimed at probing photochemical and photoelectrochemical water splitting at single semiconductor particles. Scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) will be employed to measure hydrogen and oxygen fluxes generated at single semiconductor micro/nanocrystals. A recently developed experimental setup for photo-SECM measurements at the nanoscale, in which a glass-sealed tip simultaneously serves as a nanoelectrode and a light guide, will be used to evaluate local rates of water splitting processes on different facets and near facet edges of doped BiVO4 microcrystals and map oxygen and hydrogen evolution reaction (OER and HER) rates on Al-doped SrTiO3 cubes modified with RhxCryOz. A novel methodology will be developed for photo-electrochemical experiments at a single microcrystal attached to a nanoelectrode. results.public_abstract: Semiconductor nanomaterials, including 2D nanosheets and microscopic single crystals have important technological applications ranging from fuel production to electrosynthesis. The photocatalytic activity is known to be highly heterogeneous both in an ensemble of nanomaterials and within a single particle. Despite significant research activity, the understanding of photocatalytic heterogeneity remains incomplete. We propose to use nanoelectrochemical techniques in combination with mathematical modeling to carry out quantitative, spatially resolved photoelectrochemical experiments aimed at measuring photo(electro)catalytic activity and characterizing heterogeneity of a wide range of semiconductor nanomaterials. We will perform extensive experimental studies and computer modeling aimed at probing photochemical and photoelectrochemical water splitting at single semiconductor particles. Scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) will be employed to measure hydrogen and oxygen fluxes generated at single semiconductor micro/nanocrystals. A recently developed experimental setup for photo-SECM measurements at the nanoscale, in which a glass-sealed tip simultaneously serves as a nanoelectrode and a light guide, will be used to evaluate local rates of water splitting processes on different facets and near facet edges of doped BiVO4 microcrystals and map oxygen and hydrogen evolution reaction (OER and HER) rates on Al-doped SrTiO3 cubes modified with RhxCryOz. A novel methodology will be developed for photo-electrochemical experiments at a single microcrystal attached to a nanoelectrode. Heterogeneous photoelectrocatalytic reactivity of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenide (MoS2 and others) exfoliated nanoflakes and monolayers will be mapped using two modes of photo-SECM. The generation/collection mode with small nanotips will be used to map HER active sites, and mathematical modeling and finite-element simulations will be performed to extract quantitative kinetic information from the experimental data. The tunneling mode of photo-SECM will be developed and used for ultrahigh resolution imaging of surface reactivity of 2D materials. The anticipated results will contribute to the understanding of factors influencing the activity and stability of 2D photoelectrocatalysts and help to improve these properties. We will employ nanoelectrochemical approaches to put forward new strategies for development of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis. Photo-SECM will be used to map active sites on heterogeneous photo(electro)catalytic surfaces. A new concept of voltage-driven molecular photoelectrocatalysis will be explored in which a molecular catalyst is directly (i.e., without a spacer) attached to the electrode surface, and the applied potential contributes to the driving force for the catalytic reaction. The proposed experimental studies and modeling will contribute to the molecular-level understanding of charge-transfer processes in nanostructured photoelectrocatalytic systems, which is essential for the progress in solar energy conversion, fuel generation, and energy-efficient synthesis. The expected major products of the proposed research are (1) new methodology for spatially resolved, quantitative studies of HER and OER processes at single semiconductor microcrystals; (2) nanoscale maps of photocatalytic reactivities and active sites on 2D photo(electro)catalytic surfaces; and (3) new experimental approaches to the development and characterization of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis. results.chunk_text: . Our work plan will include varying the synthesis techniques and parameters, including chemical and electrochemical routes and use of different precursors, with different nitrogen groups and chemical structures. We plan to use selective poisons and site blockers to help identify and quantify active sites and design doping (P, B, O, halogen) strategies to enhance the CNx activity/selectivity by changing the electronic structure around the active sites. We also plan to integrate a range of new in situ/operando experimental characterization techniques, consisting of near ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (NAP-XPS), IR and Raman spectroscopy, and near-edge X-ray absorption fine-structure (NEXAFS) spectroscopy. To enable operando characterization, we will use custom built electrochemical cells designed in our labs to explore the surface restructuring under operating conditions. DFT will be used to assist in interpreting the spectroscopy by predicting XPS binding energy shifts along with adsorbate vibrational spectroscopy. Electrocatalytic activity and selectivity testing combined with DFT predictions of activity for specific CNx models will establish refined structure-activity relationships. Our previous work on CNx materials as electrocatalysts have shown promising activity for many low-temperature applications in acidic media, such as ORR catalysts in proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells, direct methanol fuel cells (DMFC), as OER catalysts in regenerative fuel cells, and as oxygen depolarized cathodes in hydrochloric acid or bromic acid electrolysis. Although CNx materials as electrocatalysts have been studied for some time, there are widely differing views on the active sites and the mechanistic steps in ORR and OER. And to the best of our knowledge, other than our preliminary work, there are no reports on using CNx for BER. Any electrocatalytic system that can have multi-functional characteristics is of great practical interest. The relevance to the DOE-BES mission lies in the need to acquire a fundamental understanding of the catalytic and electrocatalytic phenomena involved in oxygen reduction, oxygen evolution and halide evolution reactions. While the questions to be addressed in the study and the approaches to be taken to answer them are fundamental, the results will have far-reaching implications for the energy future.

results.title: Atomic Level Compositional Complexity for Electrocatalysis (Atomic-C2E)
results.chunk_text: Atomic Level Compositional Complexity for Electrocatalysis (Atomic-C2E) Dr. Gangli Wang1, Professor of Chemistry Co-PIs: Drs. Samer Gozem1, Nadine Kabengi1, Xuefei Li1, Rongchao Jin2, Guoxiang Hu3, Sheng Dai4, Zac Ward4, Valeria Molinero5, Henry White5 1: Georgia State University, Atlanta, GA, 30302; 2: Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburg, PA, 15213; 3: Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, 30332; 4: Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, 37830; 5: University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, 84112 Electrocatalytic conversions of CO2 into value-added chemical fuels and hydrogen production via water electrolysis are essential avenues with enormous potentials to fulfill the goals of zero net carbon emission and reduced environmental impacts, while meeting the energy demand and improving the quality of life. In a research environment where diversity is valued, equity is ingrained, and inclusion is integral, the center of Atomic Level Compositional Complexity for Electrocatalysis, Atomic -C2E, will integrate fundamental electrochemistry, ab initio quantum chemical and multi-scale simulations, and materials chemistry to develop a mechanistic understanding of the CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) and the limiting step/s during water electrolysis in O2 evolution reaction (OER). Acquiring this knowledge will directly support the goals of the Hydrogen and Carbon Negative DOE Energy Earthshots. The elucidated fundamental insights will address technological bottlenecks challenging current electrocatalysts, such as high cost, poor stability, limited efficiency and/or selectivity of value-added products. Three interconnected thrusts will be pursued with a focus on achieving an atomic-level understanding. The thrusts’ aims are to 1) Elucidate the effects of high compositional heterogeneity in electrocatalytically active surfaces, specifically high entropy oxides for OER in acidic environments. This thrust will investigate how strong compositional heterogeneity can be used to promote robust electrocatalytically active surfaces; 2) Correlate the compositional and structural rigor and tunability with CO2RR electrocatalytic activity and selectivity, i.e., the relative kinetics and proximity effects in atomically precise nanoclusters

results.title: An Integrated Electrochemical Approach to the Precision Synthesis of Sustainable Catalyst Materials
results.chunk_text: An Integrated Electrochemical Approach to the Precision Synthesis of Sustainable Catalyst Materials Michelle L. Personick, University of Virginia (Principal Investigator) Platinum group elements (PGE) such as platinum, palladium, and rhodium are key components in many energy storage technologies, including fuel cells and the sustainable production of liquid fuels using renewable electricity. However, the relative scarcity of these elements creates problems for scale up and implementation of sustainable energy technologies due to the high prices of these elements and uncertainty in their sourcing. This instability in the supply chain can also cause problems for national security. Consequently, it is imperative to replace these critical materials with more abundant materials such as copper, iron, nickel, or cobalt in these energy applications. Replacing PGE with more sustainable metals is a non-trivial challenge, in part because making materials with these other compositions requires disruptively different synthetic approaches than those used for PGE. This proposal addresses a significant fundamental knowledge gap in the synthesis of non-PGE nanoparticles with well-defined shapes. Building mechanistic understanding in this area is crucial to the establishment of catalytic structure-activity relationships that will enable non-PGE to replace and reduce the use of PGE in these important applications. The integrated electrochemical approach to be employed in this work introduces unique flexibility in synthetic design that will enable both enhanced fundamental insight into non-PGE metal nanoparticle growth mechanisms and the development of innovative synthesis approaches that move beyond the classic conditions employed in the field. Using real-time electrochemical measurements, our integrated approach allows us to define desired parameters for the selection of novel reaction conditions for nanoparticle synthesis, thus breaking the boundaries of literature precedent. In addition, we will probe the mechanistic roles of components such as surfactants and shape-directing agents in ways that are not possible using colloidal synthesis development approaches, providing a more complete understanding of the critically important role of these additives in colloidal growth. Finally, our electrochemical synthesis makes it possible to precisely tune the reaction conditions at each step of nanoparticle growth while also providing real-time insight into the impact of changing reaction conditions. It is thus a powerful tool for the precision design and implementation of nanoparticle syntheses that control the dynamics of reaction chemistry in a way that is well outside the limits of what is possible with existing methods

results.public_abstract: Semiconductor nanomaterials, including 2D nanosheets and microscopic single crystals have important technological applications ranging from fuel production to electrosynthesis. The photocatalytic activity is known to be highly heterogeneous both in an ensemble of nanomaterials and within a single particle. Despite significant research activity, the understanding of photocatalytic heterogeneity remains incomplete. We propose to use nanoelectrochemical techniques in combination with mathematical modeling to carry out quantitative, spatially resolved photoelectrochemical experiments aimed at measuring photo(electro)catalytic activity and characterizing heterogeneity of a wide range of semiconductor nanomaterials. We will perform extensive experimental studies and computer modeling aimed at probing photochemical and photoelectrochemical water splitting at single semiconductor particles. Scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) will be employed to measure hydrogen and oxygen fluxes generated at single semiconductor micro/nanocrystals. A recently developed experimental setup for photo-SECM measurements at the nanoscale, in which a glass-sealed tip simultaneously serves as a nanoelectrode and a light guide, will be used to evaluate local rates of water splitting processes on different facets and near facet edges of doped BiVO4 microcrystals and map oxygen and hydrogen evolution reaction (OER and HER) rates on Al-doped SrTiO3 cubes modified with RhxCryOz. A novel methodology will be developed for photo-electrochemical experiments at a single microcrystal attached to a nanoelectrode. Heterogeneous photoelectrocatalytic reactivity of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenide (MoS2 and others) exfoliated nanoflakes and monolayers will be mapped using two modes of photo-SECM. The generation/collection mode with small nanotips will be used to map HER active sites, and mathematical modeling and finite-element simulations will be performed to extract quantitative kinetic information from the experimental data. The tunneling mode of photo-SECM will be developed and used for ultrahigh resolution imaging of surface reactivity of 2D materials. The anticipated results will contribute to the understanding of factors influencing the activity and stability of 2D photoelectrocatalysts and help to improve these properties. We will employ nanoelectrochemical approaches to put forward new strategies for development of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis. Photo-SECM will be used to map active sites on heterogeneous photo(electro)catalytic surfaces. A new concept of voltage-driven molecular photoelectrocatalysis will be explored in which a molecular catalyst is directly (i.e., without a spacer) attached to the electrode surface, and the applied potential contributes to the driving force for the catalytic reaction. The proposed experimental studies and modeling will contribute to the molecular-level understanding of charge-transfer processes in nanostructured photoelectrocatalytic systems, which is essential for the progress in solar energy conversion, fuel generation, and energy-efficient synthesis. The expected major products of the proposed research are (1) new methodology for spatially resolved, quantitative studies of HER and OER processes at single semiconductor microcrystals; (2) nanoscale maps of photocatalytic reactivities and active sites on 2D photo(electro)catalytic surfaces; and (3) new experimental approaches to the development and characterization of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis. The anticipated results will impact the important BES technologies, including the photo(electro)catalytic splitting of water, and contribute to research efforts of other groups within Solar Photochemistry program.

results.title: An Integrated Electrochemical Approach to the Precision Synthesis of Sustainable Catalyst Materials
results.chunk_text: An Integrated Electrochemical Approach to the Precision Synthesis of Sustainable Catalyst Materials Michelle L. Personick, University of Virginia (Principal Investigator) Platinum group elements (PGE) such as platinum, palladium, and rhodium are key components in many energy storage technologies, including fuel cells and the sustainable production of liquid fuels using renewable electricity. However, the relative scarcity of these elements creates problems for scale up and implementation of sustainable energy technologies due to the high prices of these elements and uncertainty in their sourcing. This instability in the supply chain can also cause problems for national security. Consequently, it is imperative to replace these critical materials with more abundant materials such as copper, iron, nickel, or cobalt in these energy applications. Replacing PGE with more sustainable metals is a non-trivial challenge, in part because making materials with these other compositions requires disruptively different synthetic approaches than those used for PGE. This proposal addresses a significant fundamental knowledge gap in the synthesis of non-PGE nanoparticles with well-defined shapes. Building mechanistic understanding in this area is crucial to the establishment of catalytic structure-activity relationships that will enable non-PGE to replace and reduce the use of PGE in these important applications. The integrated electrochemical approach to be employed in this work introduces unique flexibility in synthetic design that will enable both enhanced fundamental insight into non-PGE metal nanoparticle growth mechanisms and the development of innovative synthesis approaches that move beyond the classic conditions employed in the field. Using real-time electrochemical measurements, our integrated approach allows us to define desired parameters for the selection of novel reaction conditions for nanoparticle synthesis, thus breaking the boundaries of literature precedent. In addition, we will probe the mechanistic roles of components such as surfactants and shape-directing agents in ways that are not possible using colloidal synthesis development approaches, providing a more complete understanding of the critically important role of these additives in colloidal growth. Finally, our electrochemical synthesis makes it possible to precisely tune the reaction conditions at each step of nanoparticle growth while also providing real-time insight into the impact of changing reaction conditions. It is thus a powerful tool for the precision design and implementation of nanoparticle syntheses that control the dynamics of reaction chemistry in a way that is well outside the limits of what is possible with existing methods

results.title: Ultranano, Single-Atom Catalysts for Chemical Transformations
results.chunk_text: The core objective of this DOE project is to advance understanding of molecular-scale dynamics at surfaces containing ultranano (< 2 nm) scale oxide particles. The ultimate goal is to generate a molecular-level picture of interactions and transformations to support rational modification of the surface and ultimately to control the products. Ultrasmall particles are more like large molecules than extended solids; data indicates that they are extremely stable – a prime requirement for sustainability. Reducing the particle size thus solves a joint grand challenge of nanoscience: reproducible synthesis and catalyst longevity. One of the consequences of having on the order of a hundred formula units, is that minimization of energy dictates particle morphology. The same energy principles enable placement of a single defect atom in a small-area, high-energy face. The resulting engineered defect can be leveraged to capture and anchor a single noble (or not so noble) metal atom resulting in a robust, highly effective catalyst for targeted chemical transformations. One theme of this project is evolving parameters constraining identity of both the defect and the captured atom to satisfy requirements for targeted transformations. Due to their small size, it can be challenging to probe ultranano particle surfaces, particularly under reaction conditions, yet a molecular-scale probe is required to develop a picture of surface dynamics. This project addresses this challenge not only by advancing a recently invented instrument to push the frontiers for nonlinear, ultrafast spectroscopy but also by creating a novel difference phase interference, DPI, mode to track charge transport and reactivity in situ under reaction conditions. Ultrafast DPI is expected to be a generally applicable tool hence is expected to impact multiple problems involving dynamic, soft, nanoscale or irregular interfaces The specific transformation targeted in this project is reduction of CO2 to value added products. Precedent suggests that the dopant-captured metal combination determines whether the product is a one-carbon reduction, or a carbon-carbon coupled product. More specifically, reduction of CO2 requires both energy input and a source of hydrogen atoms. Sunlight is an attractive energy source; water is the most desirable hydrogen atom source. Thus, this project seeks to photochemically reduce CO2 in aqueous solution. Probing this process at the molecular level begins with particle assembly. This project seeks to develop a novel THz Raman probe to detect the nascent seed and growth process as well as the metal capture mechanism

results.title: Electrically Driven Catalysis with Supercharged Reducing Agents
results.chunk_text: Electron transfer is a central feature of chemistry. Electrons are the world’s energy currency, and the development of sustainable reduction-oxidation (redox) processes is paramount for a world where energy management is key to a stable and secure future. To this end, the development of redox-active molecular systems that facilitate the transfer of high-energy electrons has widespread applications in fuel cell systems, flow batteries, and organic electrosynthesis. However, many reduction reactions requiring high-energy electron inputs (such as alkali metals) are not catalytic, and there has been little progress in designing redox catalysts that deliver potent electrons due to challenges with catalyst stability, characterization, and storage. This program leverages the use of new “supercharged” molecular redox agents for catalytically reducing carbon dioxide (CO2), a C1 atmospheric pollutant, into oxalate (C2O42-) – a commonly used industrial C2 reagent for actinide purification, textile processing, and wood bleaching, to name a few. This program distinguishes itself from most other CO2 research programs because the reduction of CO2 into C2 products with homogeneous (soluble) catalysts remains in its infancy. Therefore, a fundamental understanding of the molecular mechanism of CO2-to-oxalate production is necessary to gain deeper insights into more general design principles for synthesizing C2 products directly from CO2 via carbon-carbon coupling reactions. Within the purview of the DOE-FAIR framework, this research project led by Rutgers University-Newark in collaboration with Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) will: (1) pinpoint the essential structural and electronic features that facilitate CO2 reduction catalysis with manganese (Mn) molecules; (2) utilize the advanced spectro-electrochemical equipment and expertise available at PNNL; (3) advance the understanding of Mn-based redox agents transfer electrons to CO2 by modulating reaction temperatures and pressures via specialized spectroscopic equipment available at PNNL; (4) use experimental and quantum chemical methodologies to map the energy landscapes of elementary reaction steps during the reactions involving Mn, CO2, and electrons. Unlocking new modes of reactivity with CO2 in this research program will contribute to a clean and secure energy future, cementing the United States as a global leader in sustainable chemistry and catalysis.

results.title: Developing a molecular level understanding of carbon monoxide dehydrogenase/acetyl coenzyme A synthase through model metalloenzymes (- View Less)
results.chunk_text: This project will provide mechanistic insight into the bifunctional metalloprotein complex, carbon monoxide dehydrogenase (CODH)/acetyl coenzyme A synthase (ACS). CODH/ACS is the cornerstone enzyme in the Wood-Ljungdahl metabolic pathway, enabling autotrophic growth in anaerobic bacteria, methanogenesis in archaea, and numerous other processes. From a biochemical standpoint, the CODH/ACS metalloenzyme catalyzes the selective reduction of carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide and generation of new energetic carbon-carbon and carbon-sulfur bonds from one-carbon precursors. Thus, in addition to the central role that CODH/ACS plays in carbon fixation and energy conservation across diverse microorganisms, these reactions represent valuable targets for carbon dioxide utilization and the selective synthesis of liquid fuels from CO2. However, due to the complexity and extremely sensitive nature of the CODH/ACS enzyme, we lack a fundamental understanding of how these enzymes work, which has hindered efforts to synthesize catalysts that take advantage of similar strategies. In this project, we will develop and characterize protein-based models of CODH and ACS as structural, functional, and mechanistic mimics to reveal the biochemical principles by which CODH and ACS operate. In Aim 1, a robust ferredoxin scaffold will be used to construct a site-differentiated nickel-iron-sulfur cluster-containing model. Detailed electronic structure characterization will be pursued using complementary spectroscopic tools, and function will be assessed using solution-phase and electrochemical experiments. Aim 2 will build from prior work within the group that demonstrated electronic and mechanistic parallels between a modified nickel-substituted azurin model and ACS. New variants will be pursued to develop functional models of ACS, allowing resolution of the key protein-derived factors influencing reactivity. Specific contributors to substrate channeling will be investigated in Aim 3. The development of functional, robust enzymes that catalyze CO2 reduction and carbon-carbon bond formation will provide catalyst design guidelines for sustainable generation of liquid fuels from CO2, addressing one of the fundamental priority research opportunities for solar fuels identified by the DOE.

results.title: Atomic Level Compositional Complexity for Electrocatalysis (Atomic-C2E)
results.chunk_text: Atomic Level Compositional Complexity for Electrocatalysis (Atomic-C2E) Dr. Gangli Wang1, Professor of Chemistry Co-PIs: Drs. Samer Gozem1, Nadine Kabengi1, Xuefei Li1, Rongchao Jin2, Guoxiang Hu3, Sheng Dai4, Zac Ward4, Valeria Molinero5, Henry White5 1: Georgia State University, Atlanta, GA, 30302; 2: Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburg, PA, 15213; 3: Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, 30332; 4: Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, 37830; 5: University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, 84112 Electrocatalytic conversions of CO2 into value-added chemical fuels and hydrogen production via water electrolysis are essential avenues with enormous potentials to fulfill the goals of zero net carbon emission and reduced environmental impacts, while meeting the energy demand and improving the quality of life. In a research environment where diversity is valued, equity is ingrained, and inclusion is integral, the center of Atomic Level Compositional Complexity for Electrocatalysis, Atomic -C2E, will integrate fundamental electrochemistry, ab initio quantum chemical and multi-scale simulations, and materials chemistry to develop a mechanistic understanding of the CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) and the limiting step/s during water electrolysis in O2 evolution reaction (OER). Acquiring this knowledge will directly support the goals of the Hydrogen and Carbon Negative DOE Energy Earthshots. The elucidated fundamental insights will address technological bottlenecks challenging current electrocatalysts, such as high cost, poor stability, limited efficiency and/or selectivity of value-added products. Three interconnected thrusts will be pursued with a focus on achieving an atomic-level understanding. The thrusts’ aims are to 1) Elucidate the effects of high compositional heterogeneity in electrocatalytically active surfaces, specifically high entropy oxides for OER in acidic environments. This thrust will investigate how strong compositional heterogeneity can be used to promote robust electrocatalytically active surfaces; 2) Correlate the compositional and structural rigor and tunability with CO2RR electrocatalytic activity and selectivity, i.e., the relative kinetics and proximity effects in atomically precise nanoclusters

results.title: Fundamental studies of the multifunctional electrocatalysis on heteroatom-doped carbon (CNx) catalysts
results.chunk_text: . Our work plan will include varying the synthesis techniques and parameters, including chemical and electrochemical routes and use of different precursors, with different nitrogen groups and chemical structures. We plan to use selective poisons and site blockers to help identify and quantify active sites and design doping (P, B, O, halogen) strategies to enhance the CNx activity/selectivity by changing the electronic structure around the active sites. We also plan to integrate a range of new in situ/operando experimental characterization techniques, consisting of near ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (NAP-XPS), IR and Raman spectroscopy, and near-edge X-ray absorption fine-structure (NEXAFS) spectroscopy. To enable operando characterization, we will use custom built electrochemical cells designed in our labs to explore the surface restructuring under operating conditions. results.public_abstract: Semiconductor nanomaterials, including 2D nanosheets and microscopic single crystals have important technological applications ranging from fuel production to electrosynthesis. The photocatalytic activity is known to be highly heterogeneous both in an ensemble of nanomaterials and within a single particle. Despite significant research activity, the understanding of photocatalytic heterogeneity remains incomplete. We propose to use nanoelectrochemical techniques in combination with mathematical modeling to carry out quantitative, spatially resolved photoelectrochemical experiments aimed at measuring photo(electro)catalytic activity and characterizing heterogeneity of a wide range of semiconductor nanomaterials. We will perform extensive experimental studies and computer modeling aimed at probing photochemical and photoelectrochemical water splitting at single semiconductor particles. Scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) will be employed to measure hydrogen and oxygen fluxes generated at single semiconductor micro/nanocrystals. A recently developed experimental setup for photo-SECM measurements at the nanoscale, in which a glass-sealed tip simultaneously serves as a nanoelectrode and a light guide, will be used to evaluate local rates of water splitting processes on different facets and near facet edges of doped BiVO4 microcrystals and map oxygen and hydrogen evolution reaction (OER and HER) rates on Al-doped SrTiO3 cubes modified with RhxCryOz. A novel methodology will be developed for photo-electrochemical experiments at a single microcrystal attached to a nanoelectrode. Heterogeneous photoelectrocatalytic reactivity of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenide (MoS2 and others) exfoliated nanoflakes and monolayers will be mapped using two modes of photo-SECM. The generation/collection mode with small nanotips will be used to map HER active sites, and mathematical modeling and finite-element simulations will be performed to extract quantitative kinetic information from the experimental data. The tunneling mode of photo-SECM will be developed and used for ultrahigh resolution imaging of surface reactivity of 2D materials. The anticipated results will contribute to the understanding of factors influencing the activity and stability of 2D photoelectrocatalysts and help to improve these properties. We will employ nanoelectrochemical approaches to put forward new strategies for development of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis. Photo-SECM will be used to map active sites on heterogeneous photo(electro)catalytic surfaces. A new concept of voltage-driven molecular photoelectrocatalysis will be explored in which a molecular catalyst is directly (i.e., without a spacer) attached to the electrode surface, and the applied potential contributes to the driving force for the catalytic reaction. The proposed experimental studies and modeling will contribute to the molecular-level understanding of charge-transfer processes in nanostructured photoelectrocatalytic systems, which is essential for the progress in solar energy conversion, fuel generation, and energy-efficient synthesis. The expected major products of the proposed research are (1) new methodology for spatially resolved, quantitative studies of HER and OER processes at single semiconductor microcrystals; (2) nanoscale maps of photocatalytic reactivities and active sites on 2D photo(electro)catalytic surfaces; and (3) new experimental approaches to the development and characterization of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis. The anticipated results will impact the important BES technologies, including the photo(electro)catalytic splitting of water, and contribute to research efforts of other groups within Solar Photochemistry program.

results.title: Understanding Degradation Mechanisms and Rates in Acidic Metal Oxide Oxygen Evolution Electrocatalysts
results.chunk_text: Understanding Degradation Mechanisms and Rates in Acidic Metal Oxide Oxygen Evolution Electrocatalysts Dr. Christopher Rhodes1, Professor Dr. Shaun Alia2 1: Texas State University, San Marcos, TX 78666 2: National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, 80401 Green hydrogen, produced from splitting water with renewable electricity, is the most critical, not fully demonstrated technology necessary to enable a clean, sustainable energy system aligned with the DOE mission. Proton-exchange membrane (PEM) electrolysis is the favored pathway currently for green hydrogen but has significant fundamental scientific challenges in terms of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalyst used due to the complexity of materials and reactions involved. Our limited understanding of catalyst degradation, which involves surface reconstruction and metal dissolution under the highly oxidizing potentials and corrosive environments encountered during oxygen evolution under acidic conditions, remains a bottleneck to the development of improved catalysts. The project objectives are to develop new research capabilities at Texas State University, in partnership with the National Renewable Energy Laboratory, and to understand how surface reconstruction affects metal dissolution rates and degradation mechanisms in metal oxide OER electrocatalysts. The research scope involves the evaluation of how metal substituents, crystal structure, and defects affect surface reconstruction and degradation. Through this collaborative effort, the project will help advance understanding of surface structure-activity-degradation relationships and inform the development of highly active, durable OER electrocatalysts for lower cost, highly durable PEM electrolyzers while expanding knowledge and infrastructure that can applied to numerous electrocatalytic reactions. The project will also expand research capabilities at Texas State University, one of the largest Hispanic Serving Institutions in the U.S., with a large population of students from underrepresented groups and first-generation college students. This research was selected for funding by the Office of Basic Energy Sciences _____________________________________________________________________________________

results.title: Understanding Flow Cell Porous Electrodes as Active Materials for Electrochemical Transformations
results.chunk_text: The objective of this research program is to fundamentally understand flow cell porous electrodes -- such as those used in fuel cells, flow batteries, electrolyzers, and desalination systems -- as active composite materials for the electrochemical transformation of flowing liquid electrolytes. The microstructural features of macroscopically homogeneous porous electrodes will be varied and their influence on mass and charge transport processes will be visualized, measured, and analyzed. With the resulting insight, new theories and models will be developed to describe the behavior of these materials across multiple length scales. With guidance from these models, new porous electrode structures with hierarchical architectures that exhibit functionality unattainable in today’s macroscopically homogeneous electrodes will be developed. This unique scientific program is made possible by several technical advances. An extrusion-based 3D printing method, known as direct ink writing, will be used to fabricate electrode structures composed of periodic mesoscale lattices as well as those with programmed types and strengths of heterogeneities, or hierarchies across multiple length scales. The mapping of molecular concentrations and flow velocities with high spatial and temporal resolution using fluorescence microscopy will be extended from two to three spatial dimensions. Numerical solutions to the equations governing flow, diffusion, migration, advection, electrochemical conversion, and electronic conduction at the individual fiber and pore scale will be developed using a new method that permits large scale simulations at fine spatial resolution. This research program will lead to a deep fundamental understanding of electrolyte-filled porous electrodes. The scientific insights gained will enable the flow cell community to design high-performance electrodes from the bottom up, based solely on knowledge of the physical, chemical, and electrochemical properties of the electrolytes. Ultimately, this will lead to higher efficiencies and power densities, reduced costs, and increased competitiveness of electrochemical devices that rely on electrolyte-filled porous electrodes.

GSU is within about 2.5-hour drive to Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL), enabling effective and efficient outreach to underrepresented workforces and hands-on access to state-of-the-art facilities as elaborated in our Promoting Inclusive and Equitable Research (PIER) Plan. results.public_abstract: An Integrated Electrochemical Approach to the Precision Synthesis of Sustainable Catalyst Materials Michelle L. Personick, University of Virginia (Principal Investigator) Platinum group elements (PGE) such as platinum, palladium, and rhodium are key components in many energy storage technologies, including fuel cells and the sustainable production of liquid fuels using renewable electricity. However, the relative scarcity of these elements creates problems for scale up and implementation of sustainable energy technologies due to the high prices of these elements and uncertainty in their sourcing. This instability in the supply chain can also cause problems for national security. Consequently, it is imperative to replace these critical materials with more abundant materials such as copper, iron, nickel, or cobalt in these energy applications. Replacing PGE with more sustainable metals is a non-trivial challenge, in part because making materials with these other compositions requires disruptively different synthetic approaches than those used for PGE. This proposal addresses a significant fundamental knowledge gap in the synthesis of non-PGE nanoparticles with well-defined shapes. Building mechanistic understanding in this area is crucial to the establishment of catalytic structure-activity relationships that will enable non-PGE to replace and reduce the use of PGE in these important applications. The integrated electrochemical approach to be employed in this work introduces unique flexibility in synthetic design that will enable both enhanced fundamental insight into non-PGE metal nanoparticle growth mechanisms and the development of innovative synthesis approaches that move beyond the classic conditions employed in the field. Using real-time electrochemical measurements, our integrated approach allows us to define desired parameters for the selection of novel reaction conditions for nanoparticle synthesis, thus breaking the boundaries of literature precedent. In addition, we will probe the mechanistic roles of components such as surfactants and shape-directing agents in ways that are not possible using colloidal synthesis development approaches, providing a more complete understanding of the critically important role of these additives in colloidal growth. Finally, our electrochemical synthesis makes it possible to precisely tune the reaction conditions at each step of nanoparticle growth while also providing real-time insight into the impact of changing reaction conditions. It is thus a powerful tool for the precision design and implementation of nanoparticle syntheses that control the dynamics of reaction chemistry in a way that is well outside the limits of what is possible with existing methods. Coupled with these efforts, the successful development of methods for synthesizing nanoparticles of non-PGE with tailored surface facets—including high-energy stepped surfaces—will also provide a platform for a reduction in the use of PGE and noble metals without necessarily needing to replace them completely. This is an important step in moving toward materials sustainability and will be critical in situations where suitable alternatives to PGE are prohibitively difficult to identify. By epitaxially depositing a monolayer or thin multilayer of a PGE onto shaped non-PGE nanoparticles, the required arrangement of PGE atoms for a particular catalytic transformation can be achieved and stabilized while reducing the amount of the PGE required by orders of magnitude.

We propose to use nanoelectrochemical techniques in combination with mathematical modeling to carry out quantitative, spatially resolved photoelectrochemical experiments aimed at measuring photo(electro)catalytic activity and characterizing heterogeneity of a wide range of semiconductor nanomaterials. We will perform extensive experimental studies and computer modeling aimed at probing photochemical and photoelectrochemical water splitting at single semiconductor particles. Scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) will be employed to measure hydrogen and oxygen fluxes generated at single semiconductor micro/nanocrystals. A recently developed experimental setup for photo-SECM measurements at the nanoscale, in which a glass-sealed tip simultaneously serves as a nanoelectrode and a light guide, will be used to evaluate local rates of water splitting processes on different facets and near facet edges of doped BiVO4 microcrystals and map oxygen and hydrogen evolution reaction (OER and HER) rates on Al-doped SrTiO3 cubes modified with RhxCryOz. A novel methodology will be developed for photo-electrochemical experiments at a single microcrystal attached to a nanoelectrode. Heterogeneous photoelectrocatalytic reactivity of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenide (MoS2 and others) exfoliated nanoflakes and monolayers will be mapped using two modes of photo-SECM. The generation/collection mode with small nanotips will be used to map HER active sites, and mathematical modeling and finite-element simulations will be performed to extract quantitative kinetic information from the experimental data. The tunneling mode of photo-SECM will be developed and used for ultrahigh resolution imaging of surface reactivity of 2D materials. The anticipated results will contribute to the understanding of factors influencing the activity and stability of 2D photoelectrocatalysts and help to improve these properties. We will employ nanoelectrochemical approaches to put forward new strategies for development of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis. Photo-SECM will be used to map active sites on heterogeneous photo(electro)catalytic surfaces. A new concept of voltage-driven molecular photoelectrocatalysis will be explored in which a molecular catalyst is directly (i.e., without a spacer) attached to the electrode surface, and the applied potential contributes to the driving force for the catalytic reaction. The proposed experimental studies and modeling will contribute to the molecular-level understanding of charge-transfer processes in nanostructured photoelectrocatalytic systems, which is essential for the progress in solar energy conversion, fuel generation, and energy-efficient synthesis. The expected major products of the proposed research are (1) new methodology for spatially resolved, quantitative studies of HER and OER processes at single semiconductor microcrystals; (2) nanoscale maps of photocatalytic reactivities and active sites on 2D photo(electro)catalytic surfaces; and (3) new experimental approaches to the development and characterization of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis. The anticipated results will impact the important BES technologies, including the photo(electro)catalytic splitting of water, and contribute to research efforts of other groups within Solar Photochemistry program.

results.chunk_text: . Our work plan will include varying the synthesis techniques and parameters, including chemical and electrochemical routes and use of different precursors, with different nitrogen groups and chemical structures. We plan to use selective poisons and site blockers to help identify and quantify active sites and design doping (P, B, O, halogen) strategies to enhance the CNx activity/selectivity by changing the electronic structure around the active sites. We also plan to integrate a range of new in situ/operando experimental characterization techniques, consisting of near ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (NAP-XPS), IR and Raman spectroscopy, and near-edge X-ray absorption fine-structure (NEXAFS) spectroscopy. To enable operando characterization, we will use custom built electrochemical cells designed in our labs to explore the surface restructuring under operating conditions. DFT will be used to assist in interpreting the spectroscopy by predicting XPS binding energy shifts along with adsorbate vibrational spectroscopy. Electrocatalytic activity and selectivity testing combined with DFT predictions of activity for specific CNx models will establish refined structure-activity relationships. Our previous work on CNx materials as electrocatalysts have shown promising activity for many low-temperature applications in acidic media, such as ORR catalysts in proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells, direct methanol fuel cells (DMFC), as OER catalysts in regenerative fuel cells, and as oxygen depolarized cathodes in hydrochloric acid or bromic acid electrolysis. Although CNx materials as electrocatalysts have been studied for some time, there are widely differing views on the active sites and the mechanistic steps in ORR and OER. And to the best of our knowledge, other than our preliminary work, there are no reports on using CNx for BER. Any electrocatalytic system that can have multi-functional characteristics is of great practical interest. The relevance to the DOE-BES mission lies in the need to acquire a fundamental understanding of the catalytic and electrocatalytic phenomena involved in oxygen reduction, oxygen evolution and halide evolution reactions. While the questions to be addressed in the study and the approaches to be taken to answer them are fundamental, the results will have far-reaching implications for the energy future.

results.title: Electrically Driven Catalysis with Supercharged Reducing Agents
results.chunk_text: Electron transfer is a central feature of chemistry. Electrons are the world’s energy currency, and the development of sustainable reduction-oxidation (redox) processes is paramount for a world where energy management is key to a stable and secure future. To this end, the development of redox-active molecular systems that facilitate the transfer of high-energy electrons has widespread applications in fuel cell systems, flow batteries, and organic electrosynthesis. However, many reduction reactions requiring high-energy electron inputs (such as alkali metals) are not catalytic, and there has been little progress in designing redox catalysts that deliver potent electrons due to challenges with catalyst stability, characterization, and storage. This program leverages the use of new “supercharged” molecular redox agents for catalytically reducing carbon dioxide (CO2), a C1 atmospheric pollutant, into oxalate (C2O42-) – a commonly used industrial C2 reagent for actinide purification, textile processing, and wood bleaching, to name a few. This program distinguishes itself from most other CO2 research programs because the reduction of CO2 into C2 products with homogeneous (soluble) catalysts remains in its infancy. Therefore, a fundamental understanding of the molecular mechanism of CO2-to-oxalate production is necessary to gain deeper insights into more general design principles for synthesizing C2 products directly from CO2 via carbon-carbon coupling reactions. Within the purview of the DOE-FAIR framework, this research project led by Rutgers University-Newark in collaboration with Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) will: (1) pinpoint the essential structural and electronic features that facilitate CO2 reduction catalysis with manganese (Mn) molecules; (2) utilize the advanced spectro-electrochemical equipment and expertise available at PNNL; (3) advance the understanding of Mn-based redox agents transfer electrons to CO2 by modulating reaction temperatures and pressures via specialized spectroscopic equipment available at PNNL; (4) use experimental and quantum chemical methodologies to map the energy landscapes of elementary reaction steps during the reactions involving Mn, CO2, and electrons. Unlocking new modes of reactivity with CO2 in this research program will contribute to a clean and secure energy future, cementing the United States as a global leader in sustainable chemistry and catalysis.

results.title: Entanglement-Informed Translations Between AQC and QAOA
results.chunk_text: This project will determine translations between adiabatic quantum computing (AQC) and the quantum approximate optimization algorithm (QAOA) through the study of entanglement generation and its relation to computational hardness and optimal algorithmic design. The objective of this study is to draw on our team's expertise in out-of-equilibrium quench dynamics, entanglement in ground states of Hamiltonians, and optimal control to establish connections between quantum problem hardness in QAOA and AQC and develop effective ways to translate optimal controls between these computational models. The project will be split into two thrust areas focusing on quantifying entanglement in QAOA and AQC and establishing translations of optimal computation across these models. Thrust 1 will focus on identifying universal properties of entanglement growth in QAOA by examining the dynamics of bipartite entanglement entropy. We will investigate the dependence of entanglement entropy on the choice of ansatze as well as its growth during training and after optimization. Our study will utilize numerical simulation and analytical techniques drawn from out-of-equilibrium quench dynamics to shed light on entanglement growth and its relationship to the specifications of the computational problem of interest; our focus will be on Maximum Satisfiability, where the clause density directly relates to the classical computational hardness of the problem. This problem class will further facilitate studies of interplay between classical and quantum hardness, entanglement growth, and computational models. The results of Thrust 1 will inform the design of optimal QAOA parameter selection and AQC schedules in Thrust 2. Using our team’s extensive knowledge in control theory, we will develop guiding principles to translate between optimal AQC and QAOA based on the desired entanglement dynamics of the algorithm. Furthermore, we will exploit characteristics of each algorithm to inform the design of optimized controls for the other, e.g., AQC runtime will inform the QAOA depth and the optimized AQC path will be examined as an initialization for QAOA. Similar translations will be made for AQC, where QAOA paths will inform diabatic variants of AQC. This project will exploit the significant recent progress of quantum many-body physics to elucidate connections between two extensively studied models for quantum computation. Albeit intimately related, little is known about the correspondence between AQC and QAOA in regards to computational hardness and algorithmic design

Albeit intimately related, little is known about the correspondence between AQC and QAOA in regards to computational hardness and algorithmic design. Our study will provide important, broadly relevant details about these properties by (1) using entanglement growth as a proxy for problem hardness and (2) focusing on a computational problem class of practical relevance. Our work has the potential to impact quantum approaches to solving scientific problems of interest to DOE. The knowledge gained from this study can be used to inform the design and training of variational algorithms more generally, thus, extending the applicability to the variational quantum eigensolver and electronic structure calculations. In addition, our work could assist in circumventing barren plateaus, where optimal AQC schedules are used to provide near-optimal initial conditions when training large variational algorithms. More broadly, our work can supply intuition into the potential utility of a particular quantum computing model based on the specifications of the computational problem. As a result, the need for extensive empirical benchmarking utilizing costly classical and quantum computational resources could be reduced.

Great interest has been generated in recent years by a plethora of proof-of-principle demonstrations on small prototype devices. However, such demonstrations have employed methods that are unlikely to work at scales of practical interest. (2) We will develop and demonstrate kernels for quantum simulation that exploit mid-circuit measurements as new algorithmic tools for improved efficiency and robustness to hardware errors. This work directly addresses the call to “advance the research towards achievement and demonstration of quantum utility by developing new algorithms.” It does so by developing algorithms for DOE application-inspired computational kernels for near-term quantum systems and by estimating quantum resources for those algorithms. Significantly, this work will deliver successes for quantum computing while the technology matures, justifying continued Department of Energy (DOE) investments in quantum computing. These efforts will help DOE leverage quantum computing as a useful scientific tool as early as possible, with potential benefits to diverse applications such as the discovery of materials and processes for clean energy and the design and optimization of resilient distributed energy networks.

results.title: FAR-Qu: Fundamental Algorithmic Research toward Quantum Utility
results.chunk_text: . While a major barrier to sustainable quantum utility is the current lack of mature, scalable, and error-resilient quantum computing hardware, sustainable quantum utility is also hampered by equally formidable fundamental algorithmic challenges. We address such algorithmic challenges by (1) developing unconventional quantum computing models, algorithms, and advantages that consider other computational resource bottlenecks, including running time, space/memory, solution accuracy, energy expenditure, and communication costs; (2) targeting basic scientific problems that are critical components in broad applications, such as simulating quantum systems and solving differential equations, linear systems, and continuous and discrete optimization problems; and (3) engaging in the full-stack-aware design of quantum algorithms that adjust computing-stack components to pave the way to unconventional demonstrations of sustainable quantum utility.
