The entanglement is mediated by single optical photons emitted by these two disparate quantum systems. The scheme is made possible due to nearly resonant optical transitions of the two systems. With photon temporal shaping and frequency shifting, these photons will be made nearly indistinguishable. Implementing this entanglement is an important step toward realizing hybrid quantum systems in which different qubits can excel at different tasks. For example, trapped ion qubits for long-term, high-fidelity qubit storage and state readout, semiconductor qubits for fast computation, and gate teleportation to bridge the two systems.

results.title: Entanglement-Informed Translations Between AQC and QAOA
results.chunk_text: This project will determine translations between adiabatic quantum computing (AQC) and the quantum approximate optimization algorithm (QAOA) through the study of entanglement generation and its relation to computational hardness and optimal algorithmic design. The objective of this study is to draw on our team's expertise in out-of-equilibrium quench dynamics, entanglement in ground states of Hamiltonians, and optimal control to establish connections between quantum problem hardness in QAOA and AQC and develop effective ways to translate optimal controls between these computational models. The project will be split into two thrust areas focusing on quantifying entanglement in QAOA and AQC and establishing translations of optimal computation across these models. Thrust 1 will focus on identifying universal properties of entanglement growth in QAOA by examining the dynamics of bipartite entanglement entropy. We will investigate the dependence of entanglement entropy on the choice of ansatze as well as its growth during training and after optimization. Our study will utilize numerical simulation and analytical techniques drawn from out-of-equilibrium quench dynamics to shed light on entanglement growth and its relationship to the specifications of the computational problem of interest; our focus will be on Maximum Satisfiability, where the clause density directly relates to the classical computational hardness of the problem. This problem class will further facilitate studies of interplay between classical and quantum hardness, entanglement growth, and computational models. The results of Thrust 1 will inform the design of optimal QAOA parameter selection and AQC schedules in Thrust 2. Using our team’s extensive knowledge in control theory, we will develop guiding principles to translate between optimal AQC and QAOA based on the desired entanglement dynamics of the algorithm. Furthermore, we will exploit characteristics of each algorithm to inform the design of optimized controls for the other, e.g., AQC runtime will inform the QAOA depth and the optimized AQC path will be examined as an initialization for QAOA. Similar translations will be made for AQC, where QAOA paths will inform diabatic variants of AQC. This project will exploit the significant recent progress of quantum many-body physics to elucidate connections between two extensively studied models for quantum computation. Albeit intimately related, little is known about the correspondence between AQC and QAOA in regards to computational hardness and algorithmic design

As a result, the need for extensive empirical benchmarking utilizing costly classical and quantum computational resources could be reduced.

results.title: Transient Absorption and Reshaping of Attosecond Pulses
results.chunk_text: The 2023 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded for advances that facilitated the generation of attosecond pulses for the study of electron dynamics in matter. Electron dynamics does indeed unfold on the time scale of tens to hundreds of attoseconds, and to probe it one therefore needs light sources that can provide attosecond time resolution. This project studies how bright, attosecond pulses of soft-X-ray radiation from state-of-the-art light sources are reshaped in the interaction with quantum matter. Understanding this reshaping in the time, frequency, and spatial domains is important in several ways: (i) the reshaping can be a signature of the dynamics that took place during the light-matter interaction, and (ii) reshaping of light is crucial to the development, characterization and control of next-generation light sources. Our program addresses both aspects, in service of the BES AMOS goal of understanding quantum dynamics at the fastest time scales. We study atto- and femtosecond pulse reshaping using a versatile theoretical treatment that takes account of both the strong laser-matter interaction at the single-system level, by numerically solving the time-dependent Schrodinger equation (TDSE) in some approximation, and, when appropriate, the propagation of the radiation in the non-linear medium, by solving the Maxwell wave equation using the TDSE-calculated time-dependent polarization as a source term. Some studies are aimed at characterization and control of light pulses from free-electron and table-top laser sources, and other studies use the reshaping of light in gas- or condensed-phase media to learn about the ultrafast electron dynamics initiated by the short pulses.

results.title: Systems for Transducing Entanglement between Photons & Electron Spins
results.chunk_text: The scientific community is on the verge of a revolution in which quantum information science (QIS) will change the way we live, work, and understand our world. Indeed, it is also well established that QIS may have the opportunity to transform industries, create jobs, and yield great benefits for the world’s population. Transferring information between stationary (spin) qubits and propagating (photonic) qubits is a critical step in realizing these transformative technologies. Quantum transduction is the coherent exchange of information between quantum systems, such as photons and electron spins, and is essential for establishing coherent communications between quantum processing nodes. Entangled photons, also known as quantum light, have already been applied successfully to molecular spectroscopy, e.g., enhancing signal strengths, creating new control parameters to manipulate optical signals, and even creating entirely new types of signals. One promising route for realizing molecular qubits is photogeneration of entangled quintet spin states 5(TT) in organic semiconductors using singlet fission (SF). The objectives of our research are: 1) Use molecular design to determine the criteria for extending 5(TT) population and spin coherence lifetimes in single crystals of molecular chromophores. 2) Using entangled photons, determine the nature of the light-matter interactions that produce four entangled electron spins in pairs of organic chromophores that undergo SF in highly ordered single crystals. 3) Determine how information encoded in the entangled photons may result in specific spin configurations in the resultant four entangled spins produced by SF. 4) Determine how spin manipulations of the four entangled photons in the 5(TT) state can be readout using delayed fluorescence that results from decay of the 5(TT) state by triplet-triplet annihilation.

results.title: Algorithms for Quantum Utility: Intelligent, Robust, and Efficiently Distributed (AQUIRED)
results.chunk_text: Quantum computing is a new, potentially very powerful type of computing. Great interest has been generated in recent years by a plethora of proof-of-principle demonstrations on small prototype devices. However, such demonstrations have employed methods that are unlikely to work at scales of practical interest. We propose two lines of research to maximize the utility of quantum computers as they scale to larger, more powerful devices in the near future: (1) We will develop and demonstrate scalable hybrid quantum-classical algorithms for combinatorial optimization by designing problem-tailored ansätze and advancing novel methods of incorporating them into classical workflows. (2) We will develop and demonstrate kernels for quantum simulation that exploit mid-circuit measurements as new algorithmic tools for improved efficiency and robustness to hardware errors. This work directly addresses the call to “advance the research towards achievement and demonstration of quantum utility by developing new algorithms.” It does so by developing algorithms for DOE application-inspired computational kernels for near-term quantum systems and by estimating quantum resources for those algorithms. Significantly, this work will deliver successes for quantum computing while the technology matures, justifying continued Department of Energy (DOE) investments in quantum computing. These efforts will help DOE leverage quantum computing as a useful scientific tool as early as possible, with potential benefits to diverse applications such as the discovery of materials and processes for clean energy and the design and optimization of resilient distributed energy networks.

results.public_abstract: The advent of ultracold chemistry (T < 1 mK) has facilitated the exploration of bimolecular reactions in detail long sought after by chemists. Such studies are made possible by the exquisite control the experi- mentalist has over the states of molecules produced in this regime, owing to the coherent and state-selective optical process by which they are formed. The ability to completely specify the initial states of the reac- tants, when coupled with state-specific detection methods, allows for the complete mapping of state-to-state dynamics in these reactions. We have previously harnessed these capabilities to study the model KRb + KRb system to great effect, mapping the full product state distribution and determining that the reaction intermediate lives for sufficiently long times (>100 ns) to be probed and controlled optically. These studies have proven foundational to our understanding of chemistry in this regime, and the current proposal focuses on building upon this early work to establish a means to control the outcome of ultracold reactions. The focus of this work will be atom-molecule reactions, i.e. the Rb + KRb reaction, selected for their relative simplicity compared to molecule-molecule reactions while still displaying rich chemical dynamics. The facile manipulation of atomic states enables us to explore reactions where the reactants have a wide array of internal energies, spanning 10−4 to 104 cm−¹. Such studies will allow us to systematically explore the unimolecular dissociation reaction of the KRb2 collisional complex, arising from the endother- mic Rb + KRb reaction, as exit channels are opened or closed, dramatically changing its dissociation rate. Further, it may be possible to tune the energy of this complex through resonance with an exit channel using external fields, thereby allowing us to control the product distribution. Such work will be performed with state-to-state resolution of both the atomic and molecular products, made possible by the recent development of an optical Rydberg excitation apparatus in our instrument. This hardware further enables the study of highly-excited reactants, namely Rydberg Rb + KRb, which are of particular interest at these low temperatures as the collision energies are insufficient to directly ionize these atomic states, allowing for their interactions between ultracold partners to dominate. We will exploit this to explore interactions in the short range that well approximate ion-neutral reactions that can be selectively turned off by judicious choice of the molecular state. In the intermediate range, these interactions result in very weakly bound species, with binding energy ∼ 10−4 cm−¹, which have implications in low-energy electron attachment. Finally, we aim to study a coherent long-range energy transfer process between these Rydberg atoms and molecules that may overcome a number challenges currently limiting molecular qubit-based quantum computing by enabling high-fidelity molecular detection and rapid entangling gate speed.

results.title: CONTROL OF MOLECULAR DYNAMICS: ALGORITHMS FOR DESIGN, ANALYSIS AND IMPLEMENTATION
results.chunk_text: The precise manipulation of molecules is at the heart of many fundamental and applied areas of physics and chemistry. This research explores the feasibility of such manipulations using applied laser pulses tailored to this goal. A laser pulse interacting with a molecule can introduce complex molecular dynamics, and a primary objective is to alter the dynamics to meet a desirable chemical or physical goal. The computational pulse designs involving complex molecules present a particular challenge, which are addressed by using advanced numerical techniques based on combining machine learning and quantum dynamics. Additionally, the research also involves fundamental mathematical analysis to identify the quantum mechanical mechanism that is operating to control the dynamics of a molecule with a particular tailored laser pulse.

results.public_abstract: The precise manipulation of molecules is at the heart of many fundamental and applied areas of physics and chemistry. This research explores the feasibility of such manipulations using applied laser pulses tailored to this goal. A laser pulse interacting with a molecule can introduce complex molecular dynamics, and a primary objective is to alter the dynamics to meet a desirable chemical or physical goal. The computational pulse designs involving complex molecules present a particular challenge, which are addressed by using advanced numerical techniques based on combining machine learning and quantum dynamics. Additionally, the research also involves fundamental mathematical analysis to identify the quantum mechanical mechanism that is operating to control the dynamics of a molecule with a particular tailored laser pulse.

results.public_abstract: The advent of ultracold chemistry (T < 1 mK) has facilitated the exploration of bimolecular reactions in detail long sought after by chemists. Such studies are made possible by the exquisite control the experi- mentalist has over the states of molecules produced in this regime, owing to the coherent and state-selective optical process by which they are formed. The ability to completely specify the initial states of the reac- tants, when coupled with state-specific detection methods, allows for the complete mapping of state-to-state dynamics in these reactions. We have previously harnessed these capabilities to study the model KRb + KRb system to great effect, mapping the full product state distribution and determining that the reaction intermediate lives for sufficiently long times (>100 ns) to be probed and controlled optically. These studies have proven foundational to our understanding of chemistry in this regime, and the current proposal focuses on building upon this early work to establish a means to control the outcome of ultracold reactions. The focus of this work will be atom-molecule reactions, i.e. the Rb + KRb reaction, selected for their relative simplicity compared to molecule-molecule reactions while still displaying rich chemical dynamics. The facile manipulation of atomic states enables us to explore reactions where the reactants have a wide array of internal energies, spanning 10−4 to 104 cm−¹. Such studies will allow us to systematically explore the unimolecular dissociation reaction of the KRb2 collisional complex, arising from the endother- mic Rb + KRb reaction, as exit channels are opened or closed, dramatically changing its dissociation rate. Further, it may be possible to tune the energy of this complex through resonance with an exit channel using external fields, thereby allowing us to control the product distribution. Such work will be performed with state-to-state resolution of both the atomic and molecular products, made possible by the recent development of an optical Rydberg excitation apparatus in our instrument. This hardware further enables the study of highly-excited reactants, namely Rydberg Rb + KRb, which are of particular interest at these low temperatures as the collision energies are insufficient to directly ionize these atomic states, allowing for their interactions between ultracold partners to dominate. We will exploit this to explore interactions in the short range that well approximate ion-neutral reactions that can be selectively turned off by judicious choice of the molecular state. In the intermediate range, these interactions result in very weakly bound species, with binding energy ∼ 10−4 cm−¹, which have implications in low-energy electron attachment. Finally, we aim to study a coherent long-range energy transfer process between these Rydberg atoms and molecules that may overcome a number challenges currently limiting molecular qubit-based quantum computing by enabling high-fidelity molecular detection and rapid entangling gate speed.

results.title: Toward High-Mass Axion Searches with Plasma Haloscopes
results.chunk_text: This is a multi-institution, multidisciplinary pathfinder program to develop quantum sensing technologies and novel techniques to search for axion dark matter. The research program extends the axion search capabilities in HEP to a range between 80–200 µeV, corresponding to photons at 20–50 GHz. Recent calculations for a mass range predicated by post-inflationary axion generation scenarios, such as those using adaptive mesh simulations, point to axions around 40–180 µeV, corresponding to photon frequencies between 10 – 45GHz. “Illuminating the hidden universe” is one of the three scientific themes of the 2023 Particle Physics Project Prioritization Panel (P5) report, a 10-year strategic plan for US particle physics in the context of a 20-year global vision. “Determining the nature of dark matter” is the science driver for this work and one of the central goals of the cosmic frontier in HEP. The QCD axion and axion-like particles are well-motivated dark matter candidates that address the strong CP problem. These wave-like dark matter candidates possess masses less than 1 eV and require novel approaches in quantum sensing. The project will develop technologies to further axion search capabilities in HEP. The program extends and capitalizes on the advances made with support from the previous QuantISED program. This pathfinder program will bring new technologies to HEP and pave a path toward a discovery-class high-mass axion haloscope. The research program will focus on developing three key technologies that take advantage of the recent progress in quantum sensing and are crucial in extending the axion mass region up to 80–200 µeV, corresponding to 20–50 GHz. This mass region is currently not accessible by the HEP community. With this research program, we will 1) develop resonators based on tunable superconducting metamaterials; 2) develop single-photon readout using Rydberg atoms; and 3) extend the frequency range of existing superconducting circuit-based photon readout, pairing Josephson-parametric amplifiers to form a squeezed state receiver at higher photon frequencies and develop photon counting techniques with superconducting circuits. Additionally, if found to be suitable, the above technologies will be deployed in an initial science run.

results.query: How might the development of hybrid quantum systems that combine the strengths of semiconductor and trapped ion qubits inform the design of novel quantum algorithms and protocols that exploit the complementary properties of different qubit modalities to achieve enhanced computational capabilities?
results.ground_truth_title: Quantum entanglement between a semiconductor donor and a trapped ion

results.title: Quantum entanglement between a semiconductor donor and a trapped ion
results.chunk_text: Quantum entanglement between a semiconductor donor and a trapped ion. This is a renewal proposal for a project currently funded by the Department of Energy. The central goal of this research is to establish a novel hybrid entangled system consisting of an In donor spin qubit in the semiconductor ZnO and a Yb trapped atomic ion qubit. The entanglement is mediated by single optical photons emitted by these two disparate quantum systems. The scheme is made possible due to nearly resonant optical transitions of the two systems. With photon temporal shaping and frequency shifting, these photons will be made nearly indistinguishable. Implementing this entanglement is an important step toward realizing hybrid quantum systems in which different qubits can excel at different tasks. For example, trapped ion qubits for long-term, high-fidelity qubit storage and state readout, semiconductor qubits for fast computation, and gate teleportation to bridge the two systems.

results.title: Algorithms for Quantum Utility: Intelligent, Robust, and Efficiently Distributed (AQUIRED)
results.chunk_text: Quantum computing is a new, potentially very powerful type of computing. Great interest has been generated in recent years by a plethora of proof-of-principle demonstrations on small prototype devices. However, such demonstrations have employed methods that are unlikely to work at scales of practical interest. We propose two lines of research to maximize the utility of quantum computers as they scale to larger, more powerful devices in the near future: (1) We will develop and demonstrate scalable hybrid quantum-classical algorithms for combinatorial optimization by designing problem-tailored ansätze and advancing novel methods of incorporating them into classical workflows. (2) We will develop and demonstrate kernels for quantum simulation that exploit mid-circuit measurements as new algorithmic tools for improved efficiency and robustness to hardware errors. This work directly addresses the call to “advance the research towards achievement and demonstration of quantum utility by developing new algorithms.” It does so by developing algorithms for DOE application-inspired computational kernels for near-term quantum systems and by estimating quantum resources for those algorithms. Significantly, this work will deliver successes for quantum computing while the technology matures, justifying continued Department of Energy (DOE) investments in quantum computing. These efforts will help DOE leverage quantum computing as a useful scientific tool as early as possible, with potential benefits to diverse applications such as the discovery of materials and processes for clean energy and the design and optimization of resilient distributed energy networks.

results.title: Systems for Transducing Entanglement between Photons & Electron Spins
results.chunk_text: The scientific community is on the verge of a revolution in which quantum information science (QIS) will change the way we live, work, and understand our world. Indeed, it is also well established that QIS may have the opportunity to transform industries, create jobs, and yield great benefits for the world’s population. Transferring information between stationary (spin) qubits and propagating (photonic) qubits is a critical step in realizing these transformative technologies. Quantum transduction is the coherent exchange of information between quantum systems, such as photons and electron spins, and is essential for establishing coherent communications between quantum processing nodes. Entangled photons, also known as quantum light, have already been applied successfully to molecular spectroscopy, e.g., enhancing signal strengths, creating new control parameters to manipulate optical signals, and even creating entirely new types of signals. One promising route for realizing molecular qubits is photogeneration of entangled quintet spin states 5(TT) in organic semiconductors using singlet fission (SF). The objectives of our research are: 1) Use molecular design to determine the criteria for extending 5(TT) population and spin coherence lifetimes in single crystals of molecular chromophores. 2) Using entangled photons, determine the nature of the light-matter interactions that produce four entangled electron spins in pairs of organic chromophores that undergo SF in highly ordered single crystals. 3) Determine how information encoded in the entangled photons may result in specific spin configurations in the resultant four entangled spins produced by SF. 4) Determine how spin manipulations of the four entangled photons in the 5(TT) state can be readout using delayed fluorescence that results from decay of the 5(TT) state by triplet-triplet annihilation.

results.title: FAR-Qu: Fundamental Algorithmic Research toward Quantum Utility
results.chunk_text: . While a major barrier to sustainable quantum utility is the current lack of mature, scalable, and error-resilient quantum computing hardware, sustainable quantum utility is also hampered by equally formidable fundamental algorithmic challenges. We address such algorithmic challenges by (1) developing unconventional quantum computing models, algorithms, and advantages that consider other computational resource bottlenecks, including running time, space/memory, solution accuracy, energy expenditure, and communication costs; (2) targeting basic scientific problems that are critical components in broad applications, such as simulating quantum systems and solving differential equations, linear systems, and continuous and discrete optimization problems; and (3) engaging in the full-stack-aware design of quantum algorithms that adjust computing-stack components to pave the way to unconventional demonstrations of sustainable quantum utility.

results.public_abstract: Recent empirical demonstrations pointing toward quantum advantage have fueled excitement and growth in the field. However, many high-profile demonstrations suggesting quantum advantage have prompted improvements in classical algorithm design (e.g., tensor-network methods) and enlist additional classical resources (e.g., supercomputing) with surprising progress in closing quantum-advantage gaps. While quantum-inspired classical improvements are a healthy benefit of quantum-computing research, to ultimately realize quantum utility it is important to systematically identify, understand, and publicize sources of quantum advantage that are unlikely to be diminished as classical computing progresses. A demonstration of quantum utility may conjure the image of a plot indicating that a quantum computer performs better (with respect to some metric) than the best-known classical counterparts. This basic concept of quantum utility raises natural questions. Soundness: What evidence do we have that a quantum computer will continue to be the best way to solve this problem as input instances grow larger or more complex? Cost-effectiveness: Will a quantum computer be the most cost-effective way to solve the problem? Resource efficiency: Will some other resource considerations, such as energy to solution, rule out practical adoption of the quantum computing solution? While well-conceived notions of quantum utility have been suggested, none, to our knowledge, simultaneously take all of the above into account. Our goal is to identify sources of sustainable quantum utility, those that are sound, cost effective, and resource efficient. We believe that sustainable quantum utility is the best candidate for realizing the promise of quantum computing. We aim to discover examples of sustainable quantum utility through three guiding perspectives: (1) sustainable quantum utility should be backed by strong evidence or proof of asymptotic advantage — in other words, there should be some feature of quantum mechanics that continues to provide an advantage in a reasonably predictable manner as problem instances grow in size or complexity, (2) an array of resources beyond execution time should be considered to ensure that quantum advantages are indeed practical and that we are not overlooking unconventional quantum advantages, and (3) we should focus on developing quantum advantages for fundamental problems in broad domains such as simulation, optimization, and machine learning, that can be tailored to yield sustainable quantum utility for new and existing applications. While a major barrier to sustainable quantum utility is the current lack of mature, scalable, and error-resilient quantum computing hardware, sustainable quantum utility is also hampered by equally formidable fundamental algorithmic challenges. We address such algorithmic challenges by (1) developing unconventional quantum computing models, algorithms, and advantages that consider other computational resource bottlenecks, including running time, space/memory, solution accuracy, energy expenditure, and communication costs; (2) targeting basic scientific problems that are critical components in broad applications, such as simulating quantum systems and solving differential equations, linear systems, and continuous and discrete optimization problems; and (3) engaging in the full-stack-aware design of quantum algorithms that adjust computing-stack components to pave the way to unconventional demonstrations of sustainable quantum utility.

results.title: Entanglement-Informed Translations Between AQC and QAOA
results.chunk_text: . Similar translations will be made for AQC, where QAOA paths will inform diabatic variants of AQC. This project will exploit the significant recent progress of quantum many-body physics to elucidate connections between two extensively studied models for quantum computation. Albeit intimately related, little is known about the correspondence between AQC and QAOA in regards to computational hardness and algorithmic design. Our study will provide important, broadly relevant details about these properties by (1) using entanglement growth as a proxy for problem hardness and (2) focusing on a computational problem class of practical relevance. Our work has the potential to impact quantum approaches to solving scientific problems of interest to DOE. The knowledge gained from this study can be used to inform the design and training of variational algorithms more generally, thus, extending the applicability to the variational quantum eigensolver and electronic structure calculations. In addition, our work could assist in circumventing barren plateaus, where optimal AQC schedules are used to provide near-optimal initial conditions when training large variational algorithms. More broadly, our work can supply intuition into the potential utility of a particular quantum computing model based on the specifications of the computational problem. As a result, the need for extensive empirical benchmarking utilizing costly classical and quantum computational resources could be reduced.

results.public_abstract: This project will determine translations between adiabatic quantum computing (AQC) and the quantum approximate optimization algorithm (QAOA) through the study of entanglement generation and its relation to computational hardness and optimal algorithmic design. The objective of this study is to draw on our team's expertise in out-of-equilibrium quench dynamics, entanglement in ground states of Hamiltonians, and optimal control to establish connections between quantum problem hardness in QAOA and AQC and develop effective ways to translate optimal controls between these computational models. The project will be split into two thrust areas focusing on quantifying entanglement in QAOA and AQC and establishing translations of optimal computation across these models. Thrust 1 will focus on identifying universal properties of entanglement growth in QAOA by examining the dynamics of bipartite entanglement entropy. We will investigate the dependence of entanglement entropy on the choice of ansatze as well as its growth during training and after optimization. Our study will utilize numerical simulation and analytical techniques drawn from out-of-equilibrium quench dynamics to shed light on entanglement growth and its relationship to the specifications of the computational problem of interest; our focus will be on Maximum Satisfiability, where the clause density directly relates to the classical computational hardness of the problem. This problem class will further facilitate studies of interplay between classical and quantum hardness, entanglement growth, and computational models. The results of Thrust 1 will inform the design of optimal QAOA parameter selection and AQC schedules in Thrust 2. Using our team’s extensive knowledge in control theory, we will develop guiding principles to translate between optimal AQC and QAOA based on the desired entanglement dynamics of the algorithm. Furthermore, we will exploit characteristics of each algorithm to inform the design of optimized controls for the other, e.g., AQC runtime will inform the QAOA depth and the optimized AQC path will be examined as an initialization for QAOA. Similar translations will be made for AQC, where QAOA paths will inform diabatic variants of AQC. This project will exploit the significant recent progress of quantum many-body physics to elucidate connections between two extensively studied models for quantum computation. results.query: To what extent can the manipulation of mesoscale lattice structures in porous electrodes influence the electrokinetic properties of flowing electrolytes, particularly in regards to enhancing ionic conductivity and mitigating concentration polarization?
results.ground_truth_title: Understanding Flow Cell Porous Electrodes as Active Materials for Electrochemical Transformations

results.title: Understanding Flow Cell Porous Electrodes as Active Materials for Electrochemical Transformations
results.chunk_text: The objective of this research program is to fundamentally understand flow cell porous electrodes -- such as those used in fuel cells, flow batteries, electrolyzers, and desalination systems -- as active composite materials for the electrochemical transformation of flowing liquid electrolytes. The microstructural features of macroscopically homogeneous porous electrodes will be varied and their influence on mass and charge transport processes will be visualized, measured, and analyzed. With the resulting insight, new theories and models will be developed to describe the behavior of these materials across multiple length scales. With guidance from these models, new porous electrode structures with hierarchical architectures that exhibit functionality unattainable in today’s macroscopically homogeneous electrodes will be developed. This unique scientific program is made possible by several technical advances. An extrusion-based 3D printing method, known as direct ink writing, will be used to fabricate electrode structures composed of periodic mesoscale lattices as well as those with programmed types and strengths of heterogeneities, or hierarchies across multiple length scales. The mapping of molecular concentrations and flow velocities with high spatial and temporal resolution using fluorescence microscopy will be extended from two to three spatial dimensions. Numerical solutions to the equations governing flow, diffusion, migration, advection, electrochemical conversion, and electronic conduction at the individual fiber and pore scale will be developed using a new method that permits large scale simulations at fine spatial resolution. This research program will lead to a deep fundamental understanding of electrolyte-filled porous electrodes. The scientific insights gained will enable the flow cell community to design high-performance electrodes from the bottom up, based solely on knowledge of the physical, chemical, and electrochemical properties of the electrolytes. Ultimately, this will lead to higher efficiencies and power densities, reduced costs, and increased competitiveness of electrochemical devices that rely on electrolyte-filled porous electrodes.

results.public_abstract: Semiconductor nanomaterials, including 2D nanosheets and microscopic single crystals have important technological applications ranging from fuel production to electrosynthesis. The photocatalytic activity is known to be highly heterogeneous both in an ensemble of nanomaterials and within a single particle. Despite significant research activity, the understanding of photocatalytic heterogeneity remains incomplete. We propose to use nanoelectrochemical techniques in combination with mathematical modeling to carry out quantitative, spatially resolved photoelectrochemical experiments aimed at measuring photo(electro)catalytic activity and characterizing heterogeneity of a wide range of semiconductor nanomaterials. We will perform extensive experimental studies and computer modeling aimed at probing photochemical and photoelectrochemical water splitting at single semiconductor particles. Scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) will be employed to measure hydrogen and oxygen fluxes generated at single semiconductor micro/nanocrystals. A recently developed experimental setup for photo-SECM measurements at the nanoscale, in which a glass-sealed tip simultaneously serves as a nanoelectrode and a light guide, will be used to evaluate local rates of water splitting processes on different facets and near facet edges of doped BiVO4 microcrystals and map oxygen and hydrogen evolution reaction (OER and HER) rates on Al-doped SrTiO3 cubes modified with RhxCryOz. A novel methodology will be developed for photo-electrochemical experiments at a single microcrystal attached to a nanoelectrode. Heterogeneous photoelectrocatalytic reactivity of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenide (MoS2 and others) exfoliated nanoflakes and monolayers will be mapped using two modes of photo-SECM. The generation/collection mode with small nanotips will be used to map HER active sites, and mathematical modeling and finite-element simulations will be performed to extract quantitative kinetic information from the experimental data. The tunneling mode of photo-SECM will be developed and used for ultrahigh resolution imaging of surface reactivity of 2D materials. The anticipated results will contribute to the understanding of factors influencing the activity and stability of 2D photoelectrocatalysts and help to improve these properties. We will employ nanoelectrochemical approaches to put forward new strategies for development of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis. Photo-SECM will be used to map active sites on heterogeneous photo(electro)catalytic surfaces. A new concept of voltage-driven molecular photoelectrocatalysis will be explored in which a molecular catalyst is directly (i.e., without a spacer) attached to the electrode surface, and the applied potential contributes to the driving force for the catalytic reaction. The proposed experimental studies and modeling will contribute to the molecular-level understanding of charge-transfer processes in nanostructured photoelectrocatalytic systems, which is essential for the progress in solar energy conversion, fuel generation, and energy-efficient synthesis. The expected major products of the proposed research are (1) new methodology for spatially resolved, quantitative studies of HER and OER processes at single semiconductor microcrystals; (2) nanoscale maps of photocatalytic reactivities and active sites on 2D photo(electro)catalytic surfaces; and (3) new experimental approaches to the development and characterization of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis. The anticipated results will impact the important BES technologies, including the photo(electro)catalytic splitting of water, and contribute to research efforts of other groups within Solar Photochemistry program.

results.title: Nanoscale Basis of the Permeability of Fine-Grained Sedimentary Rocks
results.chunk_text: This project focuses on liquid water, a critical material shaping geochemistry and life on our planet. The overarching goal is to understand how water adopts distinct properties when placed in contact with different surfaces. Key surfaces examined are clay minerals and related solids (e.g., mica) that play central roles in soil health and subsurface energy, including in soil resilience to erosion and drought, geologic CO2 sequestration, nuclear waste isolation, and enhanced geothermal energy. The approach followed in the project uses high-performance computing, supported by atomistic-level experimental characterization, to elucidate the nanoscale properties of water in clay interlayer nanopores and in adsorbed water films on mica and silica surfaces. In particular, molecular dynamics (MD) simulations are used to reveal the behavior of individual atoms in complex systems (where spectroscopic and other experimental methods probe the average behavior of large numbers of atoms or molecules) and the manner in which the collective properties of assemblages of millions of water molecules emerge from atomistic-level interactions. A first major focus of the project is on understanding the selective transport properties of water-filled nanopores. In other words, how do nanopores selectively transport water vs. salt, or cations vs. anions? A second major focus is on understanding the stability of adsorbed water films on mineral surfaces. Finally, a third focus is on advancing MD simulation capabilities by combining simulations with synchrotron X-ray reflectivity and Terahertz spectroscopy experiments. The research relies on simulations carried out at the National Energy Research Scientific Computing Center (NERSC), a US Department of Energy facility located at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (LBNL), and on Princeton University’s high-performance computing clusters. The project involves collaborations with scientists at the Argonne National Laboratory (ANL), the Sandia National Laboratories (SNL), and the University of Ruhr-Bochum. A key projected outcome is the critical re-examination of existing models and theories used to describe the properties of water in nanopores and thin films, including models of water and solute transport in nanopores and models of disjoining pressure in adsorbed water films. Beyond the Geosciences, this research aims to generate fundamental scientific knowledge relevant to nanofiltration and reverse osmosis membranes; wettability and multiphase flow; chemical synthesis using interfacial or confined water as a green solvent; and other scientific areas

results.title: Developing Novel Electrolytes to Suppress Transition Metal Dissolution in Battery Cathodes Using Multimodal Characterization (- View Less)
results.chunk_text: Developing Novel Electrolytes to Suppress Transition Metal Dissolution Using Multimodal Characterization Lead PI: Dr. Tao Li1, Associate Professor Co-PI(s): Dr. Luxi Li2, Beamline Scientist 1: Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL 60115 2: Argonne National Laboratory, Lemont, IL 60439 Abstract: This research aims to develop innovative electrolyte formulations that prevent the dissolution of transition metals from lithium-ion battery cathodes, a key factor in battery performance degradation. By systematically varying electrolyte composition and concentration, the project seeks to understand and control the solvation structures of lithium ions. These solvation structures—how lithium ions are stabilized by surrounding molecules—are critical to how the electrolyte interacts with the cathode surface. Insights into these interactions will inform the rational design of next-generation electrolytes that minimize transition metal loss, enhancing battery stability and longevity. The research will employ a combination of advanced characterization techniques, including X-ray scattering, X-ray fluorescence microscopy, and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy. These tools will be used to investigate the atomic-level changes at the electrolyte-cathode interface, as well as map the distribution of transition metals within the battery. Understanding these dynamics will be crucial for developing electrolytes that effectively inhibit transition metal dissolution during battery operation. The collaboration between Northern Illinois University and Argonne National Laboratory combines expertise in chemistry and materials science with state-of-the-art experimental resources. This partnership will enable a comprehensive investigation of how electrolyte formulations impact battery performance, contributing to the broader goal of advancing energy storage technologies. By addressing one of the critical challenges in lithium-ion batteries, this research will help improve the performance and lifespan of energy storage systems used in electric vehicles and renewable energy applications. The outcomes will have significant implications for the development of more sustainable and efficient batteries, aligning with national priorities to reduce carbon emissions and promote energy independence. Additionally, our scientific training and outcome will be integrated into educational programs to promote STEM education and raise public awareness about energy storage.

results.ground_truth_title: Understanding Flow Cell Porous Electrodes as Active Materials for Electrochemical Transformations

results.title: Understanding Flow Cell Porous Electrodes as Active Materials for Electrochemical Transformations
results.chunk_text: The objective of this research program is to fundamentally understand flow cell porous electrodes -- such as those used in fuel cells, flow batteries, electrolyzers, and desalination systems -- as active composite materials for the electrochemical transformation of flowing liquid electrolytes. The microstructural features of macroscopically homogeneous porous electrodes will be varied and their influence on mass and charge transport processes will be visualized, measured, and analyzed. With the resulting insight, new theories and models will be developed to describe the behavior of these materials across multiple length scales. With guidance from these models, new porous electrode structures with hierarchical architectures that exhibit functionality unattainable in today’s macroscopically homogeneous electrodes will be developed. This unique scientific program is made possible by several technical advances. An extrusion-based 3D printing method, known as direct ink writing, will be used to fabricate electrode structures composed of periodic mesoscale lattices as well as those with programmed types and strengths of heterogeneities, or hierarchies across multiple length scales. The mapping of molecular concentrations and flow velocities with high spatial and temporal resolution using fluorescence microscopy will be extended from two to three spatial dimensions. Numerical solutions to the equations governing flow, diffusion, migration, advection, electrochemical conversion, and electronic conduction at the individual fiber and pore scale will be developed using a new method that permits large scale simulations at fine spatial resolution. This research program will lead to a deep fundamental understanding of electrolyte-filled porous electrodes. The scientific insights gained will enable the flow cell community to design high-performance electrodes from the bottom up, based solely on knowledge of the physical, chemical, and electrochemical properties of the electrolytes. Ultimately, this will lead to higher efficiencies and power densities, reduced costs, and increased competitiveness of electrochemical devices that rely on electrolyte-filled porous electrodes.

results.public_abstract: Semiconductor nanomaterials, including 2D nanosheets and microscopic single crystals have important technological applications ranging from fuel production to electrosynthesis. The photocatalytic activity is known to be highly heterogeneous both in an ensemble of nanomaterials and within a single particle. Despite significant research activity, the understanding of photocatalytic heterogeneity remains incomplete. We propose to use nanoelectrochemical techniques in combination with mathematical modeling to carry out quantitative, spatially resolved photoelectrochemical experiments aimed at measuring photo(electro)catalytic activity and characterizing heterogeneity of a wide range of semiconductor nanomaterials. We will perform extensive experimental studies and computer modeling aimed at probing photochemical and photoelectrochemical water splitting at single semiconductor particles. Scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) will be employed to measure hydrogen and oxygen fluxes generated at single semiconductor micro/nanocrystals. A recently developed experimental setup for photo-SECM measurements at the nanoscale, in which a glass-sealed tip simultaneously serves as a nanoelectrode and a light guide, will be used to evaluate local rates of water splitting processes on different facets and near facet edges of doped BiVO4 microcrystals and map oxygen and hydrogen evolution reaction (OER and HER) rates on Al-doped SrTiO3 cubes modified with RhxCryOz. A novel methodology will be developed for photo-electrochemical experiments at a single microcrystal attached to a nanoelectrode. Heterogeneous photoelectrocatalytic reactivity of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenide (MoS2 and others) exfoliated nanoflakes and monolayers will be mapped using two modes of photo-SECM. The generation/collection mode with small nanotips will be used to map HER active sites, and mathematical modeling and finite-element simulations will be performed to extract quantitative kinetic information from the experimental data. The tunneling mode of photo-SECM will be developed and used for ultrahigh resolution imaging of surface reactivity of 2D materials. The anticipated results will contribute to the understanding of factors influencing the activity and stability of 2D photoelectrocatalysts and help to improve these properties. We will employ nanoelectrochemical approaches to put forward new strategies for development of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis. Photo-SECM will be used to map active sites on heterogeneous photo(electro)catalytic surfaces. A new concept of voltage-driven molecular photoelectrocatalysis will be explored in which a molecular catalyst is directly (i.e., without a spacer) attached to the electrode surface, and the applied potential contributes to the driving force for the catalytic reaction. The proposed experimental studies and modeling will contribute to the molecular-level understanding of charge-transfer processes in nanostructured photoelectrocatalytic systems, which is essential for the progress in solar energy conversion, fuel generation, and energy-efficient synthesis. The expected major products of the proposed research are (1) new methodology for spatially resolved, quantitative studies of HER and OER processes at single semiconductor microcrystals; (2) nanoscale maps of photocatalytic reactivities and active sites on 2D photo(electro)catalytic surfaces; and (3) new experimental approaches to the development and characterization of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis. The anticipated results will impact the important BES technologies, including the photo(electro)catalytic splitting of water, and contribute to research efforts of other groups within Solar Photochemistry program.

results.public_abstract: An Integrated Electrochemical Approach to the Precision Synthesis of Sustainable Catalyst Materials Michelle L. Personick, University of Virginia (Principal Investigator) Platinum group elements (PGE) such as platinum, palladium, and rhodium are key components in many energy storage technologies, including fuel cells and the sustainable production of liquid fuels using renewable electricity. However, the relative scarcity of these elements creates problems for scale up and implementation of sustainable energy technologies due to the high prices of these elements and uncertainty in their sourcing. This instability in the supply chain can also cause problems for national security. Consequently, it is imperative to replace these critical materials with more abundant materials such as copper, iron, nickel, or cobalt in these energy applications. Replacing PGE with more sustainable metals is a non-trivial challenge, in part because making materials with these other compositions requires disruptively different synthetic approaches than those used for PGE. This proposal addresses a significant fundamental knowledge gap in the synthesis of non-PGE nanoparticles with well-defined shapes. Building mechanistic understanding in this area is crucial to the establishment of catalytic structure-activity relationships that will enable non-PGE to replace and reduce the use of PGE in these important applications. The integrated electrochemical approach to be employed in this work introduces unique flexibility in synthetic design that will enable both enhanced fundamental insight into non-PGE metal nanoparticle growth mechanisms and the development of innovative synthesis approaches that move beyond the classic conditions employed in the field. Using real-time electrochemical measurements, our integrated approach allows us to define desired parameters for the selection of novel reaction conditions for nanoparticle synthesis, thus breaking the boundaries of literature precedent. In addition, we will probe the mechanistic roles of components such as surfactants and shape-directing agents in ways that are not possible using colloidal synthesis development approaches, providing a more complete understanding of the critically important role of these additives in colloidal growth. Finally, our electrochemical synthesis makes it possible to precisely tune the reaction conditions at each step of nanoparticle growth while also providing real-time insight into the impact of changing reaction conditions. It is thus a powerful tool for the precision design and implementation of nanoparticle syntheses that control the dynamics of reaction chemistry in a way that is well outside the limits of what is possible with existing methods. Coupled with these efforts, the successful development of methods for synthesizing nanoparticles of non-PGE with tailored surface facets—including high-energy stepped surfaces—will also provide a platform for a reduction in the use of PGE and noble metals without necessarily needing to replace them completely. This is an important step in moving toward materials sustainability and will be critical in situations where suitable alternatives to PGE are prohibitively difficult to identify. By epitaxially depositing a monolayer or thin multilayer of a PGE onto shaped non-PGE nanoparticles, the required arrangement of PGE atoms for a particular catalytic transformation can be achieved and stabilized while reducing the amount of the PGE required by orders of magnitude.

Samer Gozem1, Nadine Kabengi1, Xuefei Li1, Rongchao Jin2, Guoxiang Hu3, Sheng Dai4, Zac Ward4, Valeria Molinero5, Henry White5 1: Georgia State University, Atlanta, GA, 30302; 2: Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburg, PA, 15213; 3: Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, 30332; 4: Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, 37830; 5: University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, 84112 Electrocatalytic conversions of CO2 into value-added chemical fuels and hydrogen production via water electrolysis are essential avenues with enormous potentials to fulfill the goals of zero net carbon emission and reduced environmental impacts, while meeting the energy demand and improving the quality of life. In a research environment where diversity is valued, equity is ingrained, and inclusion is integral, the center of Atomic Level Compositional Complexity for Electrocatalysis, Atomic -C2E, will integrate fundamental electrochemistry, ab initio quantum chemical and multi-scale simulations, and materials chemistry to develop a mechanistic understanding of the CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) and the limiting step/s during water electrolysis in O2 evolution reaction (OER). Acquiring this knowledge will directly support the goals of the Hydrogen and Carbon Negative DOE Energy Earthshots. The elucidated fundamental insights will address technological bottlenecks challenging current electrocatalysts, such as high cost, poor stability, limited efficiency and/or selectivity of value-added products. Three interconnected thrusts will be pursued with a focus on achieving an atomic-level understanding. The thrusts’ aims are to 1) Elucidate the effects of high compositional heterogeneity in electrocatalytically active surfaces, specifically high entropy oxides for OER in acidic environments. This thrust will investigate how strong compositional heterogeneity can be used to promote robust electrocatalytically active surfaces; 2) Correlate the compositional and structural rigor and tunability with CO2RR electrocatalytic activity and selectivity, i.e., the relative kinetics and proximity effects in atomically precise nanoclusters. Copper and gold will be the primary metals of interest to boost the production efficiency and selectivity of value-added products; 3) Develop and apply transferable multiscale computational models with experimental feedback, and to aid and guide experiments transcending specific material types. Atomic-C2E is led by Georgia State University (GSU), a Predominantly Black and Hispanic Serving Institution in downtown Atlanta. GSU is within about 2.5-hour drive to Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL), enabling effective and efficient outreach to underrepresented workforces and hands-on access to state-of-the-art facilities as elaborated in our Promoting Inclusive and Equitable Research (PIER) Plan. results.title: Understanding Flow Cell Porous Electrodes as Active Materials for Electrochemical Transformations
results.chunk_text: The objective of this research program is to fundamentally understand flow cell porous electrodes -- such as those used in fuel cells, flow batteries, electrolyzers, and desalination systems -- as active composite materials for the electrochemical transformation of flowing liquid electrolytes. The microstructural features of macroscopically homogeneous porous electrodes will be varied and their influence on mass and charge transport processes will be visualized, measured, and analyzed. With the resulting insight, new theories and models will be developed to describe the behavior of these materials across multiple length scales. With guidance from these models, new porous electrode structures with hierarchical architectures that exhibit functionality unattainable in today’s macroscopically homogeneous electrodes will be developed. This unique scientific program is made possible by several technical advances. An extrusion-based 3D printing method, known as direct ink writing, will be used to fabricate electrode structures composed of periodic mesoscale lattices as well as those with programmed types and strengths of heterogeneities, or hierarchies across multiple length scales. The mapping of molecular concentrations and flow velocities with high spatial and temporal resolution using fluorescence microscopy will be extended from two to three spatial dimensions. Numerical solutions to the equations governing flow, diffusion, migration, advection, electrochemical conversion, and electronic conduction at the individual fiber and pore scale will be developed using a new method that permits large scale simulations at fine spatial resolution. This research program will lead to a deep fundamental understanding of electrolyte-filled porous electrodes. The scientific insights gained will enable the flow cell community to design high-performance electrodes from the bottom up, based solely on knowledge of the physical, chemical, and electrochemical properties of the electrolytes. Ultimately, this will lead to higher efficiencies and power densities, reduced costs, and increased competitiveness of electrochemical devices that rely on electrolyte-filled porous electrodes.

results.public_abstract: Semiconductor nanomaterials, including 2D nanosheets and microscopic single crystals have important technological applications ranging from fuel production to electrosynthesis. The photocatalytic activity is known to be highly heterogeneous both in an ensemble of nanomaterials and within a single particle. Despite significant research activity, the understanding of photocatalytic heterogeneity remains incomplete. We propose to use nanoelectrochemical techniques in combination with mathematical modeling to carry out quantitative, spatially resolved photoelectrochemical experiments aimed at measuring photo(electro)catalytic activity and characterizing heterogeneity of a wide range of semiconductor nanomaterials. We will perform extensive experimental studies and computer modeling aimed at probing photochemical and photoelectrochemical water splitting at single semiconductor particles. Scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) will be employed to measure hydrogen and oxygen fluxes generated at single semiconductor micro/nanocrystals. A recently developed experimental setup for photo-SECM measurements at the nanoscale, in which a glass-sealed tip simultaneously serves as a nanoelectrode and a light guide, will be used to evaluate local rates of water splitting processes on different facets and near facet edges of doped BiVO4 microcrystals and map oxygen and hydrogen evolution reaction (OER and HER) rates on Al-doped SrTiO3 cubes modified with RhxCryOz. A novel methodology will be developed for photo-electrochemical experiments at a single microcrystal attached to a nanoelectrode. Heterogeneous photoelectrocatalytic reactivity of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenide (MoS2 and others) exfoliated nanoflakes and monolayers will be mapped using two modes of photo-SECM. The generation/collection mode with small nanotips will be used to map HER active sites, and mathematical modeling and finite-element simulations will be performed to extract quantitative kinetic information from the experimental data. The tunneling mode of photo-SECM will be developed and used for ultrahigh resolution imaging of surface reactivity of 2D materials. The anticipated results will contribute to the understanding of factors influencing the activity and stability of 2D photoelectrocatalysts and help to improve these properties. We will employ nanoelectrochemical approaches to put forward new strategies for development of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis. Photo-SECM will be used to map active sites on heterogeneous photo(electro)catalytic surfaces. A new concept of voltage-driven molecular photoelectrocatalysis will be explored in which a molecular catalyst is directly (i.e., without a spacer) attached to the electrode surface, and the applied potential contributes to the driving force for the catalytic reaction. The proposed experimental studies and modeling will contribute to the molecular-level understanding of charge-transfer processes in nanostructured photoelectrocatalytic systems, which is essential for the progress in solar energy conversion, fuel generation, and energy-efficient synthesis. The expected major products of the proposed research are (1) new methodology for spatially resolved, quantitative studies of HER and OER processes at single semiconductor microcrystals; (2) nanoscale maps of photocatalytic reactivities and active sites on 2D photo(electro)catalytic surfaces; and (3) new experimental approaches to the development and characterization of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis. The anticipated results will impact the important BES technologies, including the photo(electro)catalytic splitting of water, and contribute to research efforts of other groups within Solar Photochemistry program.

results.title: Fundamental studies of the multifunctional electrocatalysis on heteroatom-doped carbon (CNx) catalysts
results.chunk_text: . Our work plan will include varying the synthesis techniques and parameters, including chemical and electrochemical routes and use of different precursors, with different nitrogen groups and chemical structures. We plan to use selective poisons and site blockers to help identify and quantify active sites and design doping (P, B, O, halogen) strategies to enhance the CNx activity/selectivity by changing the electronic structure around the active sites. We also plan to integrate a range of new in situ/operando experimental characterization techniques, consisting of near ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (NAP-XPS), IR and Raman spectroscopy, and near-edge X-ray absorption fine-structure (NEXAFS) spectroscopy. To enable operando characterization, we will use custom built electrochemical cells designed in our labs to explore the surface restructuring under operating conditions. DFT will be used to assist in interpreting the spectroscopy by predicting XPS binding energy shifts along with adsorbate vibrational spectroscopy. Electrocatalytic activity and selectivity testing combined with DFT predictions of activity for specific CNx models will establish refined structure-activity relationships. Our previous work on CNx materials as electrocatalysts have shown promising activity for many low-temperature applications in acidic media, such as ORR catalysts in proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells, direct methanol fuel cells (DMFC), as OER catalysts in regenerative fuel cells, and as oxygen depolarized cathodes in hydrochloric acid or bromic acid electrolysis. Although CNx materials as electrocatalysts have been studied for some time, there are widely differing views on the active sites and the mechanistic steps in ORR and OER. And to the best of our knowledge, other than our preliminary work, there are no reports on using CNx for BER. Any electrocatalytic system that can have multi-functional characteristics is of great practical interest. The relevance to the DOE-BES mission lies in the need to acquire a fundamental understanding of the catalytic and electrocatalytic phenomena involved in oxygen reduction, oxygen evolution and halide evolution reactions. While the questions to be addressed in the study and the approaches to be taken to answer them are fundamental, the results will have far-reaching implications for the energy future.

results.title: Understanding Degradation Mechanisms and Rates in Acidic Metal Oxide Oxygen Evolution Electrocatalysts
results.chunk_text: Understanding Degradation Mechanisms and Rates in Acidic Metal Oxide Oxygen Evolution Electrocatalysts Dr. Christopher Rhodes1, Professor Dr. Shaun Alia2 1: Texas State University, San Marcos, TX 78666 2: National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Golden, CO, 80401 Green hydrogen, produced from splitting water with renewable electricity, is the most critical, not fully demonstrated technology necessary to enable a clean, sustainable energy system aligned with the DOE mission. Proton-exchange membrane (PEM) electrolysis is the favored pathway currently for green hydrogen but has significant fundamental scientific challenges in terms of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalyst used due to the complexity of materials and reactions involved. Our limited understanding of catalyst degradation, which involves surface reconstruction and metal dissolution under the highly oxidizing potentials and corrosive environments encountered during oxygen evolution under acidic conditions, remains a bottleneck to the development of improved catalysts. The project objectives are to develop new research capabilities at Texas State University, in partnership with the National Renewable Energy Laboratory, and to understand how surface reconstruction affects metal dissolution rates and degradation mechanisms in metal oxide OER electrocatalysts. The research scope involves the evaluation of how metal substituents, crystal structure, and defects affect surface reconstruction and degradation. Through this collaborative effort, the project will help advance understanding of surface structure-activity-degradation relationships and inform the development of highly active, durable OER electrocatalysts for lower cost, highly durable PEM electrolyzers while expanding knowledge and infrastructure that can applied to numerous electrocatalytic reactions. The project will also expand research capabilities at Texas State University, one of the largest Hispanic Serving Institutions in the U.S., with a large population of students from underrepresented groups and first-generation college students. This research was selected for funding by the Office of Basic Energy Sciences _____________________________________________________________________________________

results.title: An Integrated Electrochemical Approach to the Precision Synthesis of Sustainable Catalyst Materials
results.chunk_text: An Integrated Electrochemical Approach to the Precision Synthesis of Sustainable Catalyst Materials Michelle L. Personick, University of Virginia (Principal Investigator) Platinum group elements (PGE) such as platinum, palladium, and rhodium are key components in many energy storage technologies, including fuel cells and the sustainable production of liquid fuels using renewable electricity. However, the relative scarcity of these elements creates problems for scale up and implementation of sustainable energy technologies due to the high prices of these elements and uncertainty in their sourcing. This instability in the supply chain can also cause problems for national security. Consequently, it is imperative to replace these critical materials with more abundant materials such as copper, iron, nickel, or cobalt in these energy applications. Replacing PGE with more sustainable metals is a non-trivial challenge, in part because making materials with these other compositions requires disruptively different synthetic approaches than those used for PGE. This proposal addresses a significant fundamental knowledge gap in the synthesis of non-PGE nanoparticles with well-defined shapes. Building mechanistic understanding in this area is crucial to the establishment of catalytic structure-activity relationships that will enable non-PGE to replace and reduce the use of PGE in these important applications. The integrated electrochemical approach to be employed in this work introduces unique flexibility in synthetic design that will enable both enhanced fundamental insight into non-PGE metal nanoparticle growth mechanisms and the development of innovative synthesis approaches that move beyond the classic conditions employed in the field. Using real-time electrochemical measurements, our integrated approach allows us to define desired parameters for the selection of novel reaction conditions for nanoparticle synthesis, thus breaking the boundaries of literature precedent. In addition, we will probe the mechanistic roles of components such as surfactants and shape-directing agents in ways that are not possible using colloidal synthesis development approaches, providing a more complete understanding of the critically important role of these additives in colloidal growth. Finally, our electrochemical synthesis makes it possible to precisely tune the reaction conditions at each step of nanoparticle growth while also providing real-time insight into the impact of changing reaction conditions. It is thus a powerful tool for the precision design and implementation of nanoparticle syntheses that control the dynamics of reaction chemistry in a way that is well outside the limits of what is possible with existing methods

results.public_abstract: Developing Novel Electrolytes to Suppress Transition Metal Dissolution Using Multimodal Characterization Lead PI: Dr. Tao Li1, Associate Professor Co-PI(s): Dr. Luxi Li2, Beamline Scientist 1: Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL 60115 2: Argonne National Laboratory, Lemont, IL 60439 Abstract: This research aims to develop innovative electrolyte formulations that prevent the dissolution of transition metals from lithium-ion battery cathodes, a key factor in battery performance degradation. By systematically varying electrolyte composition and concentration, the project seeks to understand and control the solvation structures of lithium ions. These solvation structures—how lithium ions are stabilized by surrounding molecules—are critical to how the electrolyte interacts with the cathode surface. Insights into these interactions will inform the rational design of next-generation electrolytes that minimize transition metal loss, enhancing battery stability and longevity. The research will employ a combination of advanced characterization techniques, including X-ray scattering, X-ray fluorescence microscopy, and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy. These tools will be used to investigate the atomic-level changes at the electrolyte-cathode interface, as well as map the distribution of transition metals within the battery. Understanding these dynamics will be crucial for developing electrolytes that effectively inhibit transition metal dissolution during battery operation. The collaboration between Northern Illinois University and Argonne National Laboratory combines expertise in chemistry and materials science with state-of-the-art experimental resources. This partnership will enable a comprehensive investigation of how electrolyte formulations impact battery performance, contributing to the broader goal of advancing energy storage technologies. By addressing one of the critical challenges in lithium-ion batteries, this research will help improve the performance and lifespan of energy storage systems used in electric vehicles and renewable energy applications. results.title: Understanding Flow Cell Porous Electrodes as Active Materials for Electrochemical Transformations
results.chunk_text: The objective of this research program is to fundamentally understand flow cell porous electrodes -- such as those used in fuel cells, flow batteries, electrolyzers, and desalination systems -- as active composite materials for the electrochemical transformation of flowing liquid electrolytes. The microstructural features of macroscopically homogeneous porous electrodes will be varied and their influence on mass and charge transport processes will be visualized, measured, and analyzed. With the resulting insight, new theories and models will be developed to describe the behavior of these materials across multiple length scales. With guidance from these models, new porous electrode structures with hierarchical architectures that exhibit functionality unattainable in today’s macroscopically homogeneous electrodes will be developed. This unique scientific program is made possible by several technical advances. An extrusion-based 3D printing method, known as direct ink writing, will be used to fabricate electrode structures composed of periodic mesoscale lattices as well as those with programmed types and strengths of heterogeneities, or hierarchies across multiple length scales. The mapping of molecular concentrations and flow velocities with high spatial and temporal resolution using fluorescence microscopy will be extended from two to three spatial dimensions. Numerical solutions to the equations governing flow, diffusion, migration, advection, electrochemical conversion, and electronic conduction at the individual fiber and pore scale will be developed using a new method that permits large scale simulations at fine spatial resolution. This research program will lead to a deep fundamental understanding of electrolyte-filled porous electrodes. The scientific insights gained will enable the flow cell community to design high-performance electrodes from the bottom up, based solely on knowledge of the physical, chemical, and electrochemical properties of the electrolytes. Ultimately, this will lead to higher efficiencies and power densities, reduced costs, and increased competitiveness of electrochemical devices that rely on electrolyte-filled porous electrodes.

results.public_abstract: Developing Novel Electrolytes to Suppress Transition Metal Dissolution Using Multimodal Characterization Lead PI: Dr. Tao Li1, Associate Professor Co-PI(s): Dr. Luxi Li2, Beamline Scientist 1: Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL 60115 2: Argonne National Laboratory, Lemont, IL 60439 Abstract: This research aims to develop innovative electrolyte formulations that prevent the dissolution of transition metals from lithium-ion battery cathodes, a key factor in battery performance degradation. By systematically varying electrolyte composition and concentration, the project seeks to understand and control the solvation structures of lithium ions. These solvation structures—how lithium ions are stabilized by surrounding molecules—are critical to how the electrolyte interacts with the cathode surface. Insights into these interactions will inform the rational design of next-generation electrolytes that minimize transition metal loss, enhancing battery stability and longevity. The research will employ a combination of advanced characterization techniques, including X-ray scattering, X-ray fluorescence microscopy, and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy. These tools will be used to investigate the atomic-level changes at the electrolyte-cathode interface, as well as map the distribution of transition metals within the battery. Understanding these dynamics will be crucial for developing electrolytes that effectively inhibit transition metal dissolution during battery operation. The collaboration between Northern Illinois University and Argonne National Laboratory combines expertise in chemistry and materials science with state-of-the-art experimental resources. This partnership will enable a comprehensive investigation of how electrolyte formulations impact battery performance, contributing to the broader goal of advancing energy storage technologies.
