results.title: Nanoelectrochemical characterization of heterogeneous photoelectrocatalysts
results.chunk_text: Semiconductor nanomaterials, including 2D nanosheets and microscopic single crystals have important technological applications ranging from fuel production to electrosynthesis. The photocatalytic activity is known to be highly heterogeneous both in an ensemble of nanomaterials and within a single particle. Despite significant research activity, the understanding of photocatalytic heterogeneity remains incomplete. We propose to use nanoelectrochemical techniques in combination with mathematical modeling to carry out quantitative, spatially resolved photoelectrochemical experiments aimed at measuring photo(electro)catalytic activity and characterizing heterogeneity of a wide range of semiconductor nanomaterials. We will perform extensive experimental studies and computer modeling aimed at probing photochemical and photoelectrochemical water splitting at single semiconductor particles. Scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) will be employed to measure hydrogen and oxygen fluxes generated at single semiconductor micro/nanocrystals. A recently developed experimental setup for photo-SECM measurements at the nanoscale, in which a glass-sealed tip simultaneously serves as a nanoelectrode and a light guide, will be used to evaluate local rates of water splitting processes on different facets and near facet edges of doped BiVO4 microcrystals and map oxygen and hydrogen evolution reaction (OER and HER) rates on Al-doped SrTiO3 cubes modified with RhxCryOz. A novel methodology will be developed for photo-electrochemical experiments at a single microcrystal attached to a nanoelectrode. Heterogeneous photoelectrocatalytic reactivity of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenide (MoS2 and others) exfoliated nanoflakes and monolayers will be mapped using two modes of photo-SECM. The generation/collection mode with small nanotips will be used to map HER active sites, and mathematical modeling and finite-element simulations will be performed to extract quantitative kinetic information from the experimental data. The tunneling mode of photo-SECM will be developed and used for ultrahigh resolution imaging of surface reactivity of 2D materials. The anticipated results will contribute to the understanding of factors influencing the activity and stability of 2D photoelectrocatalysts and help to improve these properties. We will employ nanoelectrochemical approaches to put forward new strategies for development of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis

results.title: Nanoscale Basis of the Permeability of Fine-Grained Sedimentary Rocks
results.chunk_text: This project focuses on liquid water, a critical material shaping geochemistry and life on our planet. The overarching goal is to understand how water adopts distinct properties when placed in contact with different surfaces. Key surfaces examined are clay minerals and related solids (e.g., mica) that play central roles in soil health and subsurface energy, including in soil resilience to erosion and drought, geologic CO2 sequestration, nuclear waste isolation, and enhanced geothermal energy. The approach followed in the project uses high-performance computing, supported by atomistic-level experimental characterization, to elucidate the nanoscale properties of water in clay interlayer nanopores and in adsorbed water films on mica and silica surfaces. In particular, molecular dynamics (MD) simulations are used to reveal the behavior of individual atoms in complex systems (where spectroscopic and other experimental methods probe the average behavior of large numbers of atoms or molecules) and the manner in which the collective properties of assemblages of millions of water molecules emerge from atomistic-level interactions. A first major focus of the project is on understanding the selective transport properties of water-filled nanopores. In other words, how do nanopores selectively transport water vs. salt, or cations vs. anions? A second major focus is on understanding the stability of adsorbed water films on mineral surfaces. Finally, a third focus is on advancing MD simulation capabilities by combining simulations with synchrotron X-ray reflectivity and Terahertz spectroscopy experiments. The research relies on simulations carried out at the National Energy Research Scientific Computing Center (NERSC), a US Department of Energy facility located at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (LBNL), and on Princeton University’s high-performance computing clusters. The project involves collaborations with scientists at the Argonne National Laboratory (ANL), the Sandia National Laboratories (SNL), and the University of Ruhr-Bochum. A key projected outcome is the critical re-examination of existing models and theories used to describe the properties of water in nanopores and thin films, including models of water and solute transport in nanopores and models of disjoining pressure in adsorbed water films. Beyond the Geosciences, this research aims to generate fundamental scientific knowledge relevant to nanofiltration and reverse osmosis membranes; wettability and multiphase flow; chemical synthesis using interfacial or confined water as a green solvent; and other scientific areas

results.public_abstract: Fundamental Mechanism for Flash Sintering of Highly Conductive High Temperature Ceramics Zhe Cheng (PI), Don Radford (co-PI), Chris Weinberger (co-PI) Colorado State University (CSU), Fort Collins, Colorado High temperature ceramics (HTC) have strong bonding and high melting point, and they are generally difficult to sinter using conventional sintering techniques. On the other hand, over the past decade or so, flash sintering (FS) emerges as a relatively new sintering technique that can achieve rapid densification of ceramic materials, especially oxides (e.g., yttria-stabilized zirconia or YSZ), within ~1-2 minutes or even a few seconds. The research objective of this proposal is toinvestigate the fundamental mechanism for flash sintering of highly conductive HTC materials and reveal the interrelationships between those materials’ microstructure, defect and surface characteristics, transport properties, and their behaviors in flash sintering. To achieve this objective, technical approaches combining both experiments and theoretical calculations will be adopted. In particular, the detailed flash sintering behavior for highly conductive HTC materials (e.g., ZrN and ZrB2) will be studied including revealing the influence of processing parameters such as polarity, external pressure, sample preheating, starting relative density, and sintering aids. The samples’ microstructure, local composition, point defects, surface characteristics, as well as electrical properties at different stages in flash sintering including incubation at the beginning, the transient or the flash, and the subsequent steady-state will be studied using different bulk and surface characterization techniques. In situ synchrotron study will be used to investigate the changes in HTC materials in real time during flash sintering, while their fundamental transport properties will be studied using techniques such as stable isotope-labelled diffusion-couple experiments. For theoretical calculation, finite element modeling will be used for understanding the impacts of porosity/contact area and less conductive surface shell for the powder compacts at different stages of flash sintering, while density functional theory (DFT) calculations will be used to reveal point defects generation and evolution and establish the relationships between defects characteristics and the electrical/diffusion characteristics displayed in the flash sintering process. The fundamental understanding generated from this project may help improve the efficiency and lower the cost for manufacturing of advanced ceramic materials and related components used in various critical fields such as energy, aerospace, and electronics.

results.title: Molecular engineering control of photo-induced charge transfer and transport in donor-acceptor frameworks
results.chunk_text: Next generation photoconductive materials and photocatalysts are needed to sustainably support current and growing U.S. and global energy demands. This research project explores molecular engineering strategies for realizing new functional materials and discovering novel mechanisms for photo(electro)catalysis, particularly for solar fuels generation. Such materials should exhibit strong visible light absorption and long-lived charge separation with the capacity for charge transport (i.e. photoconductivity) while also affording a high density of accessible catalytic sites — a difficult combination of properties to implement in traditional catalytic systems. Metal organic frameworks (MOFs), as a class of porous solid-state materials composed of metal ions or clusters connected through organic/organometallic linkers, are emerging alternatives for meeting these design targets. MOFs naturally incorporate light-responsive components that provide charge transfer and transport channels while simultaneously offering unique reaction environments with high densities of catalytic sites that are tunable through both framework design and post-synthetic modification. Despite a recent flurry of MOF photocatalyst demonstrations, significant knowledge gaps remain regarding their underlying photophysics and associated catalytic reaction mechanisms that impede rational optimization. This research is therefore geared toward a fundamental understanding of both the photophysical implications of MOF material modifications and how these modifications can strategically promote efficient photo(electro)catalysis. Optical transient absorption (TA) spectroscopy techniques, as a set of laser-based pump-probe methods used to gain information on excited state electronic structure and dynamics, are employed to monitor the photophysics and photoconductivity of these MOF systems as a continuous feedback loop to material design. Characterization of photocatalytic performance involves sustainability-minded benchmark reactions, such as CO2 reduction. results.title: Exploring the effect of thermal energy by the plasmonic photothermal catalyst in hydrogen generation
results.chunk_text: Scientists are developing a method to efficiently produce hydrogen fuel from water using special photocatalyst materials that harness sunlight. Recently, they have added tiny metal nanoparticles to these materials to enhance efficiency. However, researchers disagree on how these metal nanoparticles aid the process. Some argue it results from significantly increased heating in confined spaces, while others believe it is due to very energetic carriers. This debate persists because characterizing the effect of local heating is challenging. This project aims to resolve this mystery by developing advanced imaging techniques to simultaneously measure thermal energy and gas (hydrogen and oxygen) production on a very small scale (billionths of a meter) with a controlled plasmonic nanoparticle array. By studying how tiny metal particles generate and share heat, this project will solve a key mystery: do these materials produce more hydrogen because they get hot, or because they create special high-energy particles? Understanding this will help us make better materials for turning sunlight into clean hydrogen fuel. A gold-titanium material system will be used for water splitting in a photoelectrochemical cell, and the nanoparticle array will be created using electron-beam lithography. A simultaneous temperature and gas detection technique will be developed using highly sensitive surface plasmon resonance (SPR) imaging. The imaging technique’s sensitivity will be enhanced through microscope and metamaterial design. This technique will be complemented with ultrafast spectroscopy, gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) or a gas analyzer, and computer simulation. The gas detection generated by SPR will be compared with GC-MS to establish an experimental relationship between simultaneous temperature and gas detection in SPR imaging. Ultra-fast measurements and computer simulations, incorporating advanced physics and chemistry models, will be employed to observe how rapidly these materials generate gas. The measurements will monitor the process from extremely brief moments to longer durations. This will enhance our understanding of heat transfer through the material, which is essential for improving process efficiency. The research outcome will be significant as it allows simultaneous measurement of temperature and gas generation from nanoparticles, providing a direct relationship between thermal energy and hydrogen generation. It will clarify the primary mechanism in enhanced hydrogen generation. This technique has applications in various fields, including clean energy, medicine, and chemical processes

results.title: Ultranano, Single-Atom Catalysts for Chemical Transformations
results.chunk_text: The core objective of this DOE project is to advance understanding of molecular-scale dynamics at surfaces containing ultranano (< 2 nm) scale oxide particles. The ultimate goal is to generate a molecular-level picture of interactions and transformations to support rational modification of the surface and ultimately to control the products. Ultrasmall particles are more like large molecules than extended solids; data indicates that they are extremely stable – a prime requirement for sustainability. Reducing the particle size thus solves a joint grand challenge of nanoscience: reproducible synthesis and catalyst longevity. One of the consequences of having on the order of a hundred formula units, is that minimization of energy dictates particle morphology. The same energy principles enable placement of a single defect atom in a small-area, high-energy face. The resulting engineered defect can be leveraged to capture and anchor a single noble (or not so noble) metal atom resulting in a robust, highly effective catalyst for targeted chemical transformations. One theme of this project is evolving parameters constraining identity of both the defect and the captured atom to satisfy requirements for targeted transformations. Due to their small size, it can be challenging to probe ultranano particle surfaces, particularly under reaction conditions, yet a molecular-scale probe is required to develop a picture of surface dynamics. This project addresses this challenge not only by advancing a recently invented instrument to push the frontiers for nonlinear, ultrafast spectroscopy but also by creating a novel difference phase interference, DPI, mode to track charge transport and reactivity in situ under reaction conditions. Ultrafast DPI is expected to be a generally applicable tool hence is expected to impact multiple problems involving dynamic, soft, nanoscale or irregular interfaces The specific transformation targeted in this project is reduction of CO2 to value added products. Precedent suggests that the dopant-captured metal combination determines whether the product is a one-carbon reduction, or a carbon-carbon coupled product. More specifically, reduction of CO2 requires both energy input and a source of hydrogen atoms. Sunlight is an attractive energy source; water is the most desirable hydrogen atom source. Thus, this project seeks to photochemically reduce CO2 in aqueous solution. Probing this process at the molecular level begins with particle assembly. This project seeks to develop a novel THz Raman probe to detect the nascent seed and growth process as well as the metal capture mechanism

results.title: Fundamental studies of the multifunctional electrocatalysis on heteroatom-doped carbon (CNx) catalysts
results.chunk_text: . Our work plan will include varying the synthesis techniques and parameters, including chemical and electrochemical routes and use of different precursors, with different nitrogen groups and chemical structures. We plan to use selective poisons and site blockers to help identify and quantify active sites and design doping (P, B, O, halogen) strategies to enhance the CNx activity/selectivity by changing the electronic structure around the active sites. We also plan to integrate a range of new in situ/operando experimental characterization techniques, consisting of near ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (NAP-XPS), IR and Raman spectroscopy, and near-edge X-ray absorption fine-structure (NEXAFS) spectroscopy. To enable operando characterization, we will use custom built electrochemical cells designed in our labs to explore the surface restructuring under operating conditions. DFT will be used to assist in interpreting the spectroscopy by predicting XPS binding energy shifts along with adsorbate vibrational spectroscopy. Electrocatalytic activity and selectivity testing combined with DFT predictions of activity for specific CNx models will establish refined structure-activity relationships. Our previous work on CNx materials as electrocatalysts have shown promising activity for many low-temperature applications in acidic media, such as ORR catalysts in proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells, direct methanol fuel cells (DMFC), as OER catalysts in regenerative fuel cells, and as oxygen depolarized cathodes in hydrochloric acid or bromic acid electrolysis. Although CNx materials as electrocatalysts have been studied for some time, there are widely differing views on the active sites and the mechanistic steps in ORR and OER. And to the best of our knowledge, other than our preliminary work, there are no reports on using CNx for BER. Any electrocatalytic system that can have multi-functional characteristics is of great practical interest. The relevance to the DOE-BES mission lies in the need to acquire a fundamental understanding of the catalytic and electrocatalytic phenomena involved in oxygen reduction, oxygen evolution and halide evolution reactions. While the questions to be addressed in the study and the approaches to be taken to answer them are fundamental, the results will have far-reaching implications for the energy future.

results.public_abstract: Semiconductor nanomaterials, including 2D nanosheets and microscopic single crystals have important technological applications ranging from fuel production to electrosynthesis. The photocatalytic activity is known to be highly heterogeneous both in an ensemble of nanomaterials and within a single particle. Despite significant research activity, the understanding of photocatalytic heterogeneity remains incomplete. We propose to use nanoelectrochemical techniques in combination with mathematical modeling to carry out quantitative, spatially resolved photoelectrochemical experiments aimed at measuring photo(electro)catalytic activity and characterizing heterogeneity of a wide range of semiconductor nanomaterials. We will perform extensive experimental studies and computer modeling aimed at probing photochemical and photoelectrochemical water splitting at single semiconductor particles. Scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) will be employed to measure hydrogen and oxygen fluxes generated at single semiconductor micro/nanocrystals. A recently developed experimental setup for photo-SECM measurements at the nanoscale, in which a glass-sealed tip simultaneously serves as a nanoelectrode and a light guide, will be used to evaluate local rates of water splitting processes on different facets and near facet edges of doped BiVO4 microcrystals and map oxygen and hydrogen evolution reaction (OER and HER) rates on Al-doped SrTiO3 cubes modified with RhxCryOz. A novel methodology will be developed for photo-electrochemical experiments at a single microcrystal attached to a nanoelectrode. Heterogeneous photoelectrocatalytic reactivity of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenide (MoS2 and others) exfoliated nanoflakes and monolayers will be mapped using two modes of photo-SECM. The generation/collection mode with small nanotips will be used to map HER active sites, and mathematical modeling and finite-element simulations will be performed to extract quantitative kinetic information from the experimental data. The tunneling mode of photo-SECM will be developed and used for ultrahigh resolution imaging of surface reactivity of 2D materials. The anticipated results will contribute to the understanding of factors influencing the activity and stability of 2D photoelectrocatalysts and help to improve these properties. We will employ nanoelectrochemical approaches to put forward new strategies for development of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis. Photo-SECM will be used to map active sites on heterogeneous photo(electro)catalytic surfaces. A new concept of voltage-driven molecular photoelectrocatalysis will be explored in which a molecular catalyst is directly (i.e., without a spacer) attached to the electrode surface, and the applied potential contributes to the driving force for the catalytic reaction. The proposed experimental studies and modeling will contribute to the molecular-level understanding of charge-transfer processes in nanostructured photoelectrocatalytic systems, which is essential for the progress in solar energy conversion, fuel generation, and energy-efficient synthesis. The expected major products of the proposed research are (1) new methodology for spatially resolved, quantitative studies of HER and OER processes at single semiconductor microcrystals; (2) nanoscale maps of photocatalytic reactivities and active sites on 2D photo(electro)catalytic surfaces; and (3) new experimental approaches to the development and characterization of catalysts for photoelectrosynthesis. The anticipated results will impact the important BES technologies, including the photo(electro)catalytic splitting of water, and contribute to research efforts of other groups within Solar Photochemistry program.

results.public_abstract: Understanding Surfaces and Interfaces of (Photo-)catalytic Oxide Materials with First Principles Theory and Simulations Annabella Selloni Princeton University Princeton, NJ 08544 The interaction of water with metal oxide surfaces is of fundamental importance in various scientific fields and applications, ranging from geochemistry and (photo-)catalysis to biomedical devices. In particular, the discovery that titanium oxide (TiO2) photocatalyzes the dissociation of water has triggered broad interest and intensive studies of water adsorption on TiO2 over decades. However, there is still limited information on the interfaces of TiO2 with liquid water and aqueous solutions, which are the relevant systems in most practical applications. The main goal of this project is to obtain a comprehensive picture of the surfaces and aqueous interfaces of TiO2 through first principles-based simulations, as this understanding can also help improve the ability to control their properties and those of other oxide interfaces as well. Specific systems/processes to be investigated in this renewal project include: the aqueous interface of amorphous TiO2, a widely used coating material in biomedical engineering and electrochemistry; carboxylic acid adsorption on TiO2 surfaces from dilute solution, one of the most common processes used for the functionalization of TiO2 and other metal oxide surfaces; the hydration structure of iridium oxide, which is widely considered as the current state-of-the-art anode material for the oxygen evolution reaction; and electron transfer across the aqueous interfaces of wide band gap oxides, a process affecting the production of H2 in water radiolysis. Our approach is based on quantum mechanical simulations combined with enhanced sampling and machine learning techniques, which allow us to model systems and phenomena spanning a wide range of size and time scales through accurate yet computationally efficient interatomic potentials based on deep neural networks.

Our work plan will include varying the synthesis techniques and parameters, including chemical and electrochemical routes and use of different precursors, with different nitrogen groups and chemical structures. We plan to use selective poisons and site blockers to help identify and quantify active sites and design doping (P, B, O, halogen) strategies to enhance the CNx activity/selectivity by changing the electronic structure around the active sites. We also plan to integrate a range of new in situ/operando experimental characterization techniques, consisting of near ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (NAP-XPS), IR and Raman spectroscopy, and near-edge X-ray absorption fine-structure (NEXAFS) spectroscopy. To enable operando characterization, we will use custom built electrochemical cells designed in our labs to explore the surface restructuring under operating conditions. DFT will be used to assist in interpreting the spectroscopy by predicting XPS binding energy shifts along with adsorbate vibrational spectroscopy. Electrocatalytic activity and selectivity testing combined with DFT predictions of activity for specific CNx models will establish refined structure-activity relationships. Our previous work on CNx materials as electrocatalysts have shown promising activity for many low-temperature applications in acidic media, such as ORR catalysts in proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells, direct methanol fuel cells (DMFC), as OER catalysts in regenerative fuel cells, and as oxygen depolarized cathodes in hydrochloric acid or bromic acid electrolysis. Although CNx materials as electrocatalysts have been studied for some time, there are widely differing views on the active sites and the mechanistic steps in ORR and OER. And to the best of our knowledge, other than our preliminary work, there are no reports on using CNx for BER. The relevance to the DOE-BES mission lies in the need to acquire a fundamental understanding of the catalytic and electrocatalytic phenomena involved in oxygen reduction, oxygen evolution and halide evolution reactions. results.chunk_text: The core objective of this DOE project is to advance understanding of molecular-scale dynamics at surfaces containing ultranano (< 2 nm) scale oxide particles. The ultimate goal is to generate a molecular-level picture of interactions and transformations to support rational modification of the surface and ultimately to control the products. Ultrasmall particles are more like large molecules than extended solids; data indicates that they are extremely stable – a prime requirement for sustainability. Reducing the particle size thus solves a joint grand challenge of nanoscience: reproducible synthesis and catalyst longevity. One of the consequences of having on the order of a hundred formula units, is that minimization of energy dictates particle morphology. The same energy principles enable placement of a single defect atom in a small-area, high-energy face. One theme of this project is evolving parameters constraining identity of both the defect and the captured atom to satisfy requirements for targeted transformations. results.public_abstract: An Integrated Electrochemical Approach to the Precision Synthesis of Sustainable Catalyst Materials Michelle L. Personick, University of Virginia (Principal Investigator) Platinum group elements (PGE) such as platinum, palladium, and rhodium are key components in many energy storage technologies, including fuel cells and the sustainable production of liquid fuels using renewable electricity. However, the relative scarcity of these elements creates problems for scale up and implementation of sustainable energy technologies due to the high prices of these elements and uncertainty in their sourcing. This instability in the supply chain can also cause problems for national security. Consequently, it is imperative to replace these critical materials with more abundant materials such as copper, iron, nickel, or cobalt in these energy applications. Replacing PGE with more sustainable metals is a non-trivial challenge, in part because making materials with these other compositions requires disruptively different synthetic approaches than those used for PGE. This proposal addresses a significant fundamental knowledge gap in the synthesis of non-PGE nanoparticles with well-defined shapes. Building mechanistic understanding in this area is crucial to the establishment of catalytic structure-activity relationships that will enable non-PGE to replace and reduce the use of PGE in these important applications. The integrated electrochemical approach to be employed in this work introduces unique flexibility in synthetic design that will enable both enhanced fundamental insight into non-PGE metal nanoparticle growth mechanisms and the development of innovative synthesis approaches that move beyond the classic conditions employed in the field. Using real-time electrochemical measurements, our integrated approach allows us to define desired parameters for the selection of novel reaction conditions for nanoparticle synthesis, thus breaking the boundaries of literature precedent. In addition, we will probe the mechanistic roles of components such as surfactants and shape-directing agents in ways that are not possible using colloidal synthesis development approaches, providing a more complete understanding of the critically important role of these additives in colloidal growth. Finally, our electrochemical synthesis makes it possible to precisely tune the reaction conditions at each step of nanoparticle growth while also providing real-time insight into the impact of changing reaction conditions. It is thus a powerful tool for the precision design and implementation of nanoparticle syntheses that control the dynamics of reaction chemistry in a way that is well outside the limits of what is possible with existing methods. Coupled with these efforts, the successful development of methods for synthesizing nanoparticles of non-PGE with tailored surface facets—including high-energy stepped surfaces—will also provide a platform for a reduction in the use of PGE and noble metals without necessarily needing to replace them completely. This is an important step in moving toward materials sustainability and will be critical in situations where suitable alternatives to PGE are prohibitively difficult to identify. By epitaxially depositing a monolayer or thin multilayer of a PGE onto shaped non-PGE nanoparticles, the required arrangement of PGE atoms for a particular catalytic transformation can be achieved and stabilized while reducing the amount of the PGE required by orders of magnitude.

results.chunk_text: Understanding Surfaces and Interfaces of (Photo-)catalytic Oxide Materials with First Principles Theory and Simulations Annabella Selloni Princeton University Princeton, NJ 08544 The interaction of water with metal oxide surfaces is of fundamental importance in various scientific fields and applications, ranging from geochemistry and (photo-)catalysis to biomedical devices. In particular, the discovery that titanium oxide (TiO2) photocatalyzes the dissociation of water has triggered broad interest and intensive studies of water adsorption on TiO2 over decades. However, there is still limited information on the interfaces of TiO2 with liquid water and aqueous solutions, which are the relevant systems in most practical applications. The main goal of this project is to obtain a comprehensive picture of the surfaces and aqueous interfaces of TiO2 through first principles-based simulations, as this understanding can also help improve the ability to control their properties and those of other oxide interfaces as well. Specific systems/processes to be investigated in this renewal project include: the aqueous interface of amorphous TiO2, a widely used coating material in biomedical engineering and electrochemistry; carboxylic acid adsorption on TiO2 surfaces from dilute solution, one of the most common processes used for the functionalization of TiO2 and other metal oxide surfaces; the hydration structure of iridium oxide, which is widely considered as the current state-of-the-art anode material for the oxygen evolution reaction; and electron transfer across the aqueous interfaces of wide band gap oxides, a process affecting the production of H2 in water radiolysis. Our approach is based on quantum mechanical simulations combined with enhanced sampling and machine learning techniques, which allow us to model systems and phenomena spanning a wide range of size and time scales through accurate yet computationally efficient interatomic potentials based on deep neural networks.

results.title: Ultranano, Single-Atom Catalysts for Chemical Transformations
results.chunk_text: The core objective of this DOE project is to advance understanding of molecular-scale dynamics at surfaces containing ultranano (< 2 nm) scale oxide particles. The ultimate goal is to generate a molecular-level picture of interactions and transformations to support rational modification of the surface and ultimately to control the products. Ultrasmall particles are more like large molecules than extended solids; data indicates that they are extremely stable – a prime requirement for sustainability. Reducing the particle size thus solves a joint grand challenge of nanoscience: reproducible synthesis and catalyst longevity. One of the consequences of having on the order of a hundred formula units, is that minimization of energy dictates particle morphology. The same energy principles enable placement of a single defect atom in a small-area, high-energy face. The resulting engineered defect can be leveraged to capture and anchor a single noble (or not so noble) metal atom resulting in a robust, highly effective catalyst for targeted chemical transformations. One theme of this project is evolving parameters constraining identity of both the defect and the captured atom to satisfy requirements for targeted transformations. Due to their small size, it can be challenging to probe ultranano particle surfaces, particularly under reaction conditions, yet a molecular-scale probe is required to develop a picture of surface dynamics. This project addresses this challenge not only by advancing a recently invented instrument to push the frontiers for nonlinear, ultrafast spectroscopy but also by creating a novel difference phase interference, DPI, mode to track charge transport and reactivity in situ under reaction conditions. Ultrafast DPI is expected to be a generally applicable tool hence is expected to impact multiple problems involving dynamic, soft, nanoscale or irregular interfaces The specific transformation targeted in this project is reduction of CO2 to value added products. Precedent suggests that the dopant-captured metal combination determines whether the product is a one-carbon reduction, or a carbon-carbon coupled product. More specifically, reduction of CO2 requires both energy input and a source of hydrogen atoms. Sunlight is an attractive energy source; water is the most desirable hydrogen atom source. Thus, this project seeks to photochemically reduce CO2 in aqueous solution. Probing this process at the molecular level begins with particle assembly. This project seeks to develop a novel THz Raman probe to detect the nascent seed and growth process as well as the metal capture mechanism

results.public_abstract: Catalyzing Workforce Diversity in Photocatalytic Energy Science Dr. Kristy L Mardis1, Associate Provost Co-PI(s): Dr. Jens Niklas2, Dr. Sunshine Silver3, Dr. Rakhim Rakhimov4 1: Chicago State University, Chicago, IL 60628 2: Argonne National Laboratory, Lemont, IL 60439 3: Elmhurst University, Elmhurst, IL 60126 4: Norfolk State University, Norfolk, VA 23504 This project brings together researchers and trainees from Chicago State University (CSU), a Predominantly Black Institution (PBI), Norfolk State University (NSU), a Historically Black College and University (HBCU), Elmhurst University (EU), a Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI), and the Solar Energy Conversion Group at Argonne National Laboratory (ANL). Working collaboratively, this project seeks to increase the number of historically underrepresented groups in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) fields while broadening the understanding of solar driven chemical reactions. The project will strengthen the research and scientific opportunities at the three MSIs in collaboration with ANL and provide 12 students annually opportunities to engage in high-impact research focused on questions surrounding artificial and biohybrid photosynthesis. Through a year-round training program, weekly group meetings, and an annual week-long full group meeting at ANL, participants will be provided with ample networking opportunities, culturally responsive mentoring, and professional development. By engaging students in a collaborative research project and culturally responsive mentoring, faculty will work to improve the sociocultural environment and remove obstacles for the advancement of a diverse workforce in the photochemical sciences. This project builds on complementary techniques to understand and improve hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalysts for solar fuel production. Nickel and cobalt molecular catalysts offer a promising opportunity for the development of new materials for solar fuel production as they are inexpensive, readily synthesized, and can be chemically modified to tune their properties. Computational modeling techniques will be utilized to understand the effect of structural changes on the catalysts. These results will aid in the design of improved biohybrid systems. Electron Paramagnetic Resonance spectroscopy will be utilized to characterize the charge-transfer events and electronic structure of the transition metal complexes and the biohybrid complexes. It is anticipated that the dual approach of an immersive inter-institutional research experience and culturally responsive mentoring as a means of effecting systemic change to support a diverse group of participants will lead to higher retention and persistence of a more diverse workforce. results.public_abstract: Semiconductor nanomaterials, including 2D nanosheets and microscopic single crystals have important technological applications ranging from fuel production to electrosynthesis. We propose to use nanoelectrochemical techniques in combination with mathematical modeling to carry out quantitative, spatially resolved photoelectrochemical experiments aimed at measuring photo(electro)catalytic activity and characterizing heterogeneity of a wide range of semiconductor nanomaterials. We will perform extensive experimental studies and computer modeling aimed at probing photochemical and photoelectrochemical water splitting at single semiconductor particles. MOFs naturally incorporate light-responsive components that provide charge transfer and transport channels while simultaneously offering unique reaction environments with high densities of catalytic sites that are tunable through both framework design and post-synthetic modification. Despite a recent flurry of MOF photocatalyst demonstrations, significant knowledge gaps remain regarding their underlying photophysics and associated catalytic reaction mechanisms that impede rational optimization. This research is therefore geared toward a fundamental understanding of both the photophysical implications of MOF material modifications and how these modifications can strategically promote efficient photo(electro)catalysis. Optical transient absorption (TA) spectroscopy techniques, as a set of laser-based pump-probe methods used to gain information on excited state electronic structure and dynamics, are employed to monitor the photophysics and photoconductivity of these MOF systems as a continuous feedback loop to material design. Characterization of photocatalytic performance involves sustainability-minded benchmark reactions, such as CO2 reduction. results.title: Electrically Driven Catalysis with Supercharged Reducing Agents
results.chunk_text: Electron transfer is a central feature of chemistry. Electrons are the world’s energy currency, and the development of sustainable reduction-oxidation (redox) processes is paramount for a world where energy management is key to a stable and secure future. To this end, the development of redox-active molecular systems that facilitate the transfer of high-energy electrons has widespread applications in fuel cell systems, flow batteries, and organic electrosynthesis. However, many reduction reactions requiring high-energy electron inputs (such as alkali metals) are not catalytic, and there has been little progress in designing redox catalysts that deliver potent electrons due to challenges with catalyst stability, characterization, and storage. This program leverages the use of new “supercharged” molecular redox agents for catalytically reducing carbon dioxide (CO2), a C1 atmospheric pollutant, into oxalate (C2O42-) – a commonly used industrial C2 reagent for actinide purification, textile processing, and wood bleaching, to name a few. This program distinguishes itself from most other CO2 research programs because the reduction of CO2 into C2 products with homogeneous (soluble) catalysts remains in its infancy. Therefore, a fundamental understanding of the molecular mechanism of CO2-to-oxalate production is necessary to gain deeper insights into more general design principles for synthesizing C2 products directly from CO2 via carbon-carbon coupling reactions. Within the purview of the DOE-FAIR framework, this research project led by Rutgers University-Newark in collaboration with Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) will: (1) pinpoint the essential structural and electronic features that facilitate CO2 reduction catalysis with manganese (Mn) molecules; (2) utilize the advanced spectro-electrochemical equipment and expertise available at PNNL; (3) advance the understanding of Mn-based redox agents transfer electrons to CO2 by modulating reaction temperatures and pressures via specialized spectroscopic equipment available at PNNL; (4) use experimental and quantum chemical methodologies to map the energy landscapes of elementary reaction steps during the reactions involving Mn, CO2, and electrons. Unlocking new modes of reactivity with CO2 in this research program will contribute to a clean and secure energy future, cementing the United States as a global leader in sustainable chemistry and catalysis.

results.title: Combining High Level Ab Initio Calculations with Laser Control Of Molecular Dynamics
results.chunk_text: Combining High Level Ab Initio Calculations with Laser Control Of Molecular Dynamics. This project aims to develop the understanding of how electrons and nuclei move in polyatomic molecules that are excited by laser fields. The dynamics of organic conjugated molecules are very important in chemical reactivity, and their photochemistry can be a model for chemical and biological processes such as bond breaking and formation, photoprotection of DNA, light harvesting and vision. results.public_abstract: Next generation photoconductive materials and photocatalysts are needed to sustainably support current and growing U.S. and global energy demands. This research project explores molecular engineering strategies for realizing new functional materials and discovering novel mechanisms for photo(electro)catalysis, particularly for solar fuels generation. Such materials should exhibit strong visible light absorption and long-lived charge separation with the capacity for charge transport (i.e. photoconductivity) while also affording a high density of accessible catalytic sites — a difficult combination of properties to implement in traditional catalytic systems. Metal organic frameworks (MOFs), as a class of porous solid-state materials composed of metal ions or clusters connected through organic/organometallic linkers, are emerging alternatives for meeting these design targets. MOFs naturally incorporate light-responsive components that provide charge transfer and transport channels while simultaneously offering unique reaction environments with high densities of catalytic sites that are tunable through both framework design and post-synthetic modification. Despite a recent flurry of MOF photocatalyst demonstrations, significant knowledge gaps remain regarding their underlying photophysics and associated catalytic reaction mechanisms that impede rational optimization. This research is therefore geared toward a fundamental understanding of both the photophysical implications of MOF material modifications and how these modifications can strategically promote efficient photo(electro)catalysis. Optical transient absorption (TA) spectroscopy techniques, as a set of laser-based pump-probe methods used to gain information on excited state electronic structure and dynamics, are employed to monitor the photophysics and photoconductivity of these MOF systems as a continuous feedback loop to material design. Characterization of photocatalytic performance involves sustainability-minded benchmark reactions, such as CO2 reduction. NREL’s longstanding expertise in applying these tools to problems involving photoinduced electron transfer and subsequent catalytic processes is intended to closely integrate with efforts at Rutgers-Newark on the materials-driven aspects of the project. Within the framework of the DOE-FAIR program, this mutually beneficial collaborative project involves extensive graduate student training on advanced spectroscopic and analytical tools and therefore is building crucial research capacity at Rutgers-Newark, a non-R1, minority serving (MSI) and emerging research institution (ERI).

results.public_abstract: The objective of this research is to investigate fundamental interactions between light and low-density matter to advance the knowledge of ultrafast chemistry. The aim is to understand and control the earliest time dynamics of chemical transformations after molecules absorb ultraviolet (UV) light, similar to what happens when human skin absorbs sunlight. These processes mimic the effects of sunlight on the molecules that are in either biological cells or other substances. The research seeks to measure the time evolution of these molecular transformations that occur in a one thousandth of a trillionth of a second. These molecular changes happen when the electrons that surround the molecule’s nuclei absorb the light at a million times faster than a trillionth of a second, inducing nuclear motion. This motion modifies the molecules resulting in different chemical behavior or the formation of new molecules. These processes are at the heart of ultrafast chemistry. To perform these experiments, a microscope of unprecedented power, such as the Linac Coherent Light Source (LCLS) X-ray Free Electron Laser (FEL) at SLAC National Laboratory, acts as a high-repetition rate strobe light. This X-ray laser freezes the motion of atoms, a frame at a time, to capture high-speed images of ultrafast microscopic chemical transformations, enabling the production of a molecular movie. One planned experiment will use the upgraded ultrafast LCLS-II X-rays and instrumentation to image UV-induced breaking of water molecules with the utmost precision. This study is important for not only fundamental science in chemistry, physics and biology, but also various technologies. Specifically, the experiments will measure the motion of electrons as they move across the water bonds on an ultrafast timescale by probing and characterizing the motion of the oxygen and the two hydrogen atoms in the water molecule during the initial stages of ultrafast chemical reactions. The research includes powerful calculations to provide a quantitative interpretation of the results. This area of fundamental research is crucial to chemical sciences because it probes the dynamics of electrons and nuclei in molecules and determines how these dynamics influence the transfer of energy, charge, or protons, as well as chemical bond breaking or formation of new bonds that make new molecules. The knowledge acquired is foundational to controlling charge transfer and energy transfer from light to matter. This project will contribute new data to the research identified as new scientific opportunities in the 2018 BES Report, “Opportunities for Basic Research at the Frontiers of X-ray FEL Ultrafast Science” and fall within the Priority Research Opportunity (PRO1): “Probing and controlling electron motion within a molecule”. This research also supports the 2015 DOE Basic Energy Sciences Advisory Committee mission and report on “Challenges at the Frontiers of Matter and Energy: Transformative Opportunities for Discovery Science”.

results.chunk_text: The precise manipulation of molecules is at the heart of many fundamental and applied areas of physics and chemistry. This research explores the feasibility of such manipulations using applied laser pulses tailored to this goal. A laser pulse interacting with a molecule can introduce complex molecular dynamics, and a primary objective is to alter the dynamics to meet a desirable chemical or physical goal. The computational pulse designs involving complex molecules present a particular challenge, which are addressed by using advanced numerical techniques based on combining machine learning and quantum dynamics. Additionally, the research also involves fundamental mathematical analysis to identify the quantum mechanical mechanism that is operating to control the dynamics of a molecule with a particular tailored laser pulse.

results.title: Transient Absorption and Reshaping of Attosecond Pulses
results.chunk_text: The 2023 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded for advances that facilitated the generation of attosecond pulses for the study of electron dynamics in matter. Electron dynamics does indeed unfold on the time scale of tens to hundreds of attoseconds, and to probe it one therefore needs light sources that can provide attosecond time resolution. This project studies how bright, attosecond pulses of soft-X-ray radiation from state-of-the-art light sources are reshaped in the interaction with quantum matter. Understanding this reshaping in the time, frequency, and spatial domains is important in several ways: (i) the reshaping can be a signature of the dynamics that took place during the light-matter interaction, and (ii) reshaping of light is crucial to the development, characterization and control of next-generation light sources. Our program addresses both aspects, in service of the BES AMOS goal of understanding quantum dynamics at the fastest time scales. We study atto- and femtosecond pulse reshaping using a versatile theoretical treatment that takes account of both the strong laser-matter interaction at the single-system level, by numerically solving the time-dependent Schrodinger equation (TDSE) in some approximation, and, when appropriate, the propagation of the radiation in the non-linear medium, by solving the Maxwell wave equation using the TDSE-calculated time-dependent polarization as a source term. Some studies are aimed at characterization and control of light pulses from free-electron and table-top laser sources, and other studies use the reshaping of light in gas- or condensed-phase media to learn about the ultrafast electron dynamics initiated by the short pulses.

results.chunk_text: The objective of this research is to investigate fundamental interactions between light and low-density matter to advance the knowledge of ultrafast chemistry. The aim is to understand and control the earliest time dynamics of chemical transformations after molecules absorb ultraviolet (UV) light, similar to what happens when human skin absorbs sunlight. These processes mimic the effects of sunlight on the molecules that are in either biological cells or other substances. The research seeks to measure the time evolution of these molecular transformations that occur in a one thousandth of a trillionth of a second. These molecular changes happen when the electrons that surround the molecule’s nuclei absorb the light at a million times faster than a trillionth of a second, inducing nuclear motion. This motion modifies the molecules resulting in different chemical behavior or the formation of new molecules. These processes are at the heart of ultrafast chemistry. To perform these experiments, a microscope of unprecedented power, such as the Linac Coherent Light Source (LCLS) X-ray Free Electron Laser (FEL) at SLAC National Laboratory, acts as a high-repetition rate strobe light. This X-ray laser freezes the motion of atoms, a frame at a time, to capture high-speed images of ultrafast microscopic chemical transformations, enabling the production of a molecular movie. One planned experiment will use the upgraded ultrafast LCLS-II X-rays and instrumentation to image UV-induced breaking of water molecules with the utmost precision. This study is important for not only fundamental science in chemistry, physics and biology, but also various technologies. Specifically, the experiments will measure the motion of electrons as they move across the water bonds on an ultrafast timescale by probing and characterizing the motion of the oxygen and the two hydrogen atoms in the water molecule during the initial stages of ultrafast chemical reactions. The research includes powerful calculations to provide a quantitative interpretation of the results. This area of fundamental research is crucial to chemical sciences because it probes the dynamics of electrons and nuclei in molecules and determines how these dynamics influence the transfer of energy, charge, or protons, as well as chemical bond breaking or formation of new bonds that make new molecules. The knowledge acquired is foundational to controlling charge transfer and energy transfer from light to matter

results.chunk_text: This project aims to develop the understanding of how electrons and nuclei move in polyatomic molecules that are excited by laser fields. The dynamics of organic conjugated molecules are very important in chemical reactivity, and their photochemistry can be a model for chemical and biological processes such as bond breaking and formation, photoprotection of DNA, light harvesting and vision. The current project uses a combination of time-resolved experiments (measuring electrons and ions as a function of the delay between laser pulses) and theoretical simulations of the dynamics and the observables (using semi-classical approaches that capture the essential quantum dynamics in tractable calculations) in order to determine how the structure of the molecules affects their dynamics, in particular how it affects isomerization and internal conversion. The role of electronic structure and electron correlation in strong field double ionization of small polyatomic molecules is also explored. In these studies very strong electric fields can remove more than one electron from the molecules, providing the opportunity to probe how the electrons interact with each other.

results.public_abstract: Universal and State-resolved Imaging of Chemical Dynamics Arthur G. Suits, University of Missouri, Columbia The goals of this experimental program are to develop the most detailed picture possible of the dynamics of the elementary chemical reactions that underlie gas phase chemical processes. Such studies are essential to build a deeper understanding of the chemical behavior of macroscopic gas phase systems and to permit reliable extrapolation of measured quantities from known conditions of temperature and pressure to extreme conditions­ – from interstellar clouds at 10 K to combustion systems at 2000 K – where measurements are not feasible. These investigations are conducted using state-of-the-art molecular beam machines in conjunction with velocity map ion imaging and other advanced spectroscopic techniques. A significant aspect of this work is the development of new instruments and approaches to achieve new insights. Studies include bimolecular reactions of polyatomic molecules with atomic and molecular radicals performed under single collision conditions; time-resolved investigations of photodissociation and unimolecular decomposition, and low temperature kinetics and product branching measurements obtained using rotational spectroscopy. A notable aspect of this effort is the close interplay with theoretical investigations of the structure and dynamics of the systems of interest, either performed in-house or in collaboration with theory colleagues, to develop a molecular-level understanding of chemical phenomena. The overall objectives of our program are: to extend the range of powerful dynamics studies to more complex polyatomic systems; to reveal thereby novel aspects of dynamics that arise with increasing molecular complexity; to identify novel reaction pathways; and to benchmark a range of theoretical methods. The specific objectives of this renewal project are to explore kinetics and dynamics of ground state sulfur atom reactions with unsaturated hydrocarbons and to advance the methods and applications of laboratory-based Coulomb Explosion Imaging (CEI).Three experimental avenues are pursued in the proposed studies building on current progress: Crossed-beam velocity map imaging studies of sulfur atom reactions with polyatomic targets; related studies of the low temperature kinetics and branching in these reactions; and development of the capability for time-resolved structural dynamics in molecules using CEI. The crossed-beam studies directly yield the velocity-flux contour maps for the reactions that, in combination with high-level theoretical calculations, provide deep insight into reaction pathways and dynamics, the existence of barriers and intermediate reaction complexes, and highlight systematic trends in mechanisms and energy and angular momentum partitioning as a function of target structure. Preliminary investigations have shown stark and perhaps surprising differences in the behavior of sulfur versus oxygen atoms in the reactions studied. At the same time, novel measurements coupling broadband rotational spectroscoppy in Laval flows will yield low temperature product branching and kinetics for the same systems. In the ultrafast studies the objectives include measurement of static CEI in femtosecond strong-field ionization using 3D (time-and-position) imaging combined with covariance mapping analysis.

A new concept of voltage-driven molecular photoelectrocatalysis will be explored in which a molecular catalyst is directly (i.e., without a spacer) attached to the electrode surface, and the applied potential contributes to the driving force for the catalytic reaction. results.chunk_text: . Five-membered rings annulated to a seven-membered cyclic moiety ring such as in azulene access contorted, ‘saddle-shaped’ aromatic systems with both a positive and negative curvature of the carbon backbone. This classifies benzene, phenyl, fulveneallene, and fulvenallenyl as fundamental molecular building blocks to complex PAHs and eventually carbonaceous nanoparticles. The intimate knowledge of the elementary mechanisms to synthesize these molecules is therefore critical to our understanding of the early stage chemistry in hydrocarbon- rich environments (combustion, molecular clouds) how PAHs and ultimately carbonaceous nanoparticles form. However, the elementary steps, reaction dynamics, energy flow processes, and mechanisms to form even these chemically simple building blocks on the molecular level are still highly debated as synthetic routes have not been investigated comprehensively under single collision conditions to date. To achieve these goals, we conduct state-of-the-art crossed molecular beam experiments over a wide range of collision energies from 10 to 100 kJmol-1 in a hydrocarbon-free, crossed molecular beam machine with ultra-sensitive detection schemes coupled to a universal and rotatable angular resolved time-of-flight mass spectrometric detector with soft and hard electron impact ionization and laser induced fluorescence (LIF) detection. Although crossed molecular beam experiments have been employed for almost five decades, there is a critical lack of understanding on the elementary mechanisms how to synthesize fundamental molecular building blocks carrying six- and five-membered rings due to the previously insurmountable difficulties in preparing supersonic molecular beams of radical reactants of a sufficient high intensity to detect the reaction products under single collision conditions. Considering the high reactivity of the open shell reactants, crossed molecular beam experiments, in which the reactants are prepared in separate side chambers, present a logical experimental approach. The results of the scattering experiments are combined with ab initio calculations (Mebel) and flame modeling (Frenklach). This approach not only resolves a decade old enigma of how simple aromatic building blocks are formed in combustion and extraterrestrial settings, but also how these elementary reactions drive molecular mass growth processes via two- (flat) and three-dimensional (bowl-shaped) aromatic nanostructures ultimately to carbonaceous nanoparticles.

results.title: CONTROL OF MOLECULAR DYNAMICS: ALGORITHMS FOR DESIGN, ANALYSIS AND IMPLEMENTATION
results.chunk_text: The precise manipulation of molecules is at the heart of many fundamental and applied areas of physics and chemistry. This research explores the feasibility of such manipulations using applied laser pulses tailored to this goal. A laser pulse interacting with a molecule can introduce complex molecular dynamics, and a primary objective is to alter the dynamics to meet a desirable chemical or physical goal. The computational pulse designs involving complex molecules present a particular challenge, which are addressed by using advanced numerical techniques based on combining machine learning and quantum dynamics. Additionally, the research also involves fundamental mathematical analysis to identify the quantum mechanical mechanism that is operating to control the dynamics of a molecule with a particular tailored laser pulse.

results.title: Transient Absorption and Reshaping of Attosecond Pulses
results.chunk_text: The 2023 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded for advances that facilitated the generation of attosecond pulses for the study of electron dynamics in matter. Electron dynamics does indeed unfold on the time scale of tens to hundreds of attoseconds, and to probe it one therefore needs light sources that can provide attosecond time resolution. This project studies how bright, attosecond pulses of soft-X-ray radiation from state-of-the-art light sources are reshaped in the interaction with quantum matter. Understanding this reshaping in the time, frequency, and spatial domains is important in several ways: (i) the reshaping can be a signature of the dynamics that took place during the light-matter interaction, and (ii) reshaping of light is crucial to the development, characterization and control of next-generation light sources. Our program addresses both aspects, in service of the BES AMOS goal of understanding quantum dynamics at the fastest time scales. We study atto- and femtosecond pulse reshaping using a versatile theoretical treatment that takes account of both the strong laser-matter interaction at the single-system level, by numerically solving the time-dependent Schrodinger equation (TDSE) in some approximation, and, when appropriate, the propagation of the radiation in the non-linear medium, by solving the Maxwell wave equation using the TDSE-calculated time-dependent polarization as a source term. Some studies are aimed at characterization and control of light pulses from free-electron and table-top laser sources, and other studies use the reshaping of light in gas- or condensed-phase media to learn about the ultrafast electron dynamics initiated by the short pulses.

Five-membered rings annulated to a seven-membered cyclic moiety ring such as in azulene access contorted, ‘saddle-shaped’ aromatic systems with both a positive and negative curvature of the carbon backbone. This classifies benzene, phenyl, fulveneallene, and fulvenallenyl as fundamental molecular building blocks to complex PAHs and eventually carbonaceous nanoparticles. The intimate knowledge of the elementary mechanisms to synthesize these molecules is therefore critical to our understanding of the early stage chemistry in hydrocarbon- rich environments (combustion, molecular clouds) how PAHs and ultimately carbonaceous nanoparticles form. However, the elementary steps, reaction dynamics, energy flow processes, and mechanisms to form even these chemically simple building blocks on the molecular level are still highly debated as synthetic routes have not been investigated comprehensively under single collision conditions to date. To achieve these goals, we conduct state-of-the-art crossed molecular beam experiments over a wide range of collision energies from 10 to 100 kJmol-1 in a hydrocarbon-free, crossed molecular beam machine with ultra-sensitive detection schemes coupled to a universal and rotatable angular resolved time-of-flight mass spectrometric detector with soft and hard electron impact ionization and laser induced fluorescence (LIF) detection. Although crossed molecular beam experiments have been employed for almost five decades, there is a critical lack of understanding on the elementary mechanisms how to synthesize fundamental molecular building blocks carrying six- and five-membered rings due to the previously insurmountable difficulties in preparing supersonic molecular beams of radical reactants of a sufficient high intensity to detect the reaction products under single collision conditions. The results of the scattering experiments are combined with ab initio calculations (Mebel) and flame modeling (Frenklach). This approach not only resolves a decade old enigma of how simple aromatic building blocks are formed in combustion and extraterrestrial settings, but also how these elementary reactions drive molecular mass growth processes via two- (flat) and three-dimensional (bowl-shaped) aromatic nanostructures ultimately to carbonaceous nanoparticles.

results.title: Exploring the Kinetics and Reaction Dynamics of Peroxy Radical Unimolecular Decay
results.chunk_text: . Such a vast range in unimolecular decay rates has potentially important implications for the relative importance of critical pathways in Earth's lower atmosphere and low-temperature combustion, such as autoxidation, particle formation, and autoignition. However, the predicted unimolecular decay rates of functionalized peroxy radical are largely uncharacterized due to experimental challenges. Understanding the unimolecular decay of functionalized peroxy radicals demands a holistic approach that uses multiple experimental and theoretical methods. Therefore, their chemistry will be investigated directly in separate complementary experiments at Coastal Carolina University using a new appartus to study the unimolecular decay of peroxy radicals under jet-cooled and collision-free conditions, and at Argonne National Laboratory under thermal conditions, in which the reactivity of peroxy radicals will be studied at a specific temperature and pressure. In both experiments, the peroxy radicals will be generated and stabilized under conditions that minimize unwanted side chemistry and allow direct observation of their unimolecular decay in fundamental pump-probe laser experiments. Peroxy radicals with carbonyl and carboxylic acid functionalization will be specifically targeted due to low energy barriers for their hydrogen atom migration reactions. The results from the experiments will be compared with state-of-the-art theoretical calculations of the predicted unimolecular decay reaction dynamics and kinetics using methods developed at Argonne National Laboratory. The combination of results from this multidisciplinary approach will provide a complete picture of the unimolecular decay of peroxy radicals and transform our understanding of their chemistry in oxygenated environments, such as the Earth's atmosphere and low-temperature combustion. results.title: COMBINING HIGH LEVEL AB INITIO CALCULATIONS WITH LASER CONTROL OF MOLECULAR DYNAMICS
results.chunk_text: This project aims to develop the understanding of how electrons and nuclei move in polyatomic molecules that are excited by laser fields. The dynamics of organic conjugated molecules are very important in chemical reactivity, and their photochemistry can be a model for chemical and biological processes such as bond breaking and formation, photoprotection of DNA, light harvesting and vision. The current project uses a combination of time-resolved experiments (measuring electrons and ions as a function of the delay between laser pulses) and theoretical simulations of the dynamics and the observables (using semi-classical approaches that capture the essential quantum dynamics in tractable calculations) in order to determine how the structure of the molecules affects their dynamics, in particular how it affects isomerization and internal conversion. The role of electronic structure and electron correlation in strong field double ionization of small polyatomic molecules is also explored. In these studies very strong electric fields can remove more than one electron from the molecules, providing the opportunity to probe how the electrons interact with each other.

results.title: Electrically Driven Catalysis with Supercharged Reducing Agents
results.chunk_text: Electron transfer is a central feature of chemistry. Electrons are the world’s energy currency, and the development of sustainable reduction-oxidation (redox) processes is paramount for a world where energy management is key to a stable and secure future. To this end, the development of redox-active molecular systems that facilitate the transfer of high-energy electrons has widespread applications in fuel cell systems, flow batteries, and organic electrosynthesis. However, many reduction reactions requiring high-energy electron inputs (such as alkali metals) are not catalytic, and there has been little progress in designing redox catalysts that deliver potent electrons due to challenges with catalyst stability, characterization, and storage. This program leverages the use of new “supercharged” molecular redox agents for catalytically reducing carbon dioxide (CO2), a C1 atmospheric pollutant, into oxalate (C2O42-) – a commonly used industrial C2 reagent for actinide purification, textile processing, and wood bleaching, to name a few. This program distinguishes itself from most other CO2 research programs because the reduction of CO2 into C2 products with homogeneous (soluble) catalysts remains in its infancy. Therefore, a fundamental understanding of the molecular mechanism of CO2-to-oxalate production is necessary to gain deeper insights into more general design principles for synthesizing C2 products directly from CO2 via carbon-carbon coupling reactions. Within the purview of the DOE-FAIR framework, this research project led by Rutgers University-Newark in collaboration with Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) will: (1) pinpoint the essential structural and electronic features that facilitate CO2 reduction catalysis with manganese (Mn) molecules; (2) utilize the advanced spectro-electrochemical equipment and expertise available at PNNL; (3) advance the understanding of Mn-based redox agents transfer electrons to CO2 by modulating reaction temperatures and pressures via specialized spectroscopic equipment available at PNNL; (4) use experimental and quantum chemical methodologies to map the energy landscapes of elementary reaction steps during the reactions involving Mn, CO2, and electrons. Unlocking new modes of reactivity with CO2 in this research program will contribute to a clean and secure energy future, cementing the United States as a global leader in sustainable chemistry and catalysis.

results.title: Ultranano, Single-Atom Catalysts for Chemical Transformations
results.chunk_text: The core objective of this DOE project is to advance understanding of molecular-scale dynamics at surfaces containing ultranano (< 2 nm) scale oxide particles. The ultimate goal is to generate a molecular-level picture of interactions and transformations to support rational modification of the surface and ultimately to control the products. Ultrasmall particles are more like large molecules than extended solids; data indicates that they are extremely stable – a prime requirement for sustainability. Reducing the particle size thus solves a joint grand challenge of nanoscience: reproducible synthesis and catalyst longevity. One of the consequences of having on the order of a hundred formula units, is that minimization of energy dictates particle morphology. The same energy principles enable placement of a single defect atom in a small-area, high-energy face. The resulting engineered defect can be leveraged to capture and anchor a single noble (or not so noble) metal atom resulting in a robust, highly effective catalyst for targeted chemical transformations. One theme of this project is evolving parameters constraining identity of both the defect and the captured atom to satisfy requirements for targeted transformations. Due to their small size, it can be challenging to probe ultranano particle surfaces, particularly under reaction conditions, yet a molecular-scale probe is required to develop a picture of surface dynamics. This project addresses this challenge not only by advancing a recently invented instrument to push the frontiers for nonlinear, ultrafast spectroscopy but also by creating a novel difference phase interference, DPI, mode to track charge transport and reactivity in situ under reaction conditions. Ultrafast DPI is expected to be a generally applicable tool hence is expected to impact multiple problems involving dynamic, soft, nanoscale or irregular interfaces The specific transformation targeted in this project is reduction of CO2 to value added products. Precedent suggests that the dopant-captured metal combination determines whether the product is a one-carbon reduction, or a carbon-carbon coupled product. More specifically, reduction of CO2 requires both energy input and a source of hydrogen atoms. Sunlight is an attractive energy source; water is the most desirable hydrogen atom source. Thus, this project seeks to photochemically reduce CO2 in aqueous solution. Probing this process at the molecular level begins with particle assembly. This project seeks to develop a novel THz Raman probe to detect the nascent seed and growth process as well as the metal capture mechanism

results.chunk_text: COMBINING HIGH LEVEL AB INITIO CALCULATIONS WITH LASER CONTROL OF MOLECULAR DYNAMICS. Five-membered rings annulated to a seven-membered cyclic moiety ring such as in azulene access contorted, ‘saddle-shaped’ aromatic systems with both a positive and negative curvature of the carbon backbone. This classifies benzene, phenyl, fulveneallene, and fulvenallenyl as fundamental molecular building blocks to complex PAHs and eventually carbonaceous nanoparticles. The intimate knowledge of the elementary mechanisms to synthesize these molecules is therefore critical to our understanding of the early stage chemistry in hydrocarbon- rich environments (combustion, molecular clouds) how PAHs and ultimately carbonaceous nanoparticles form. However, the elementary steps, reaction dynamics, energy flow processes, and mechanisms to form even these chemically simple building blocks on the molecular level are still highly debated as synthetic routes have not been investigated comprehensively under single collision conditions to date. To achieve these goals, we conduct state-of-the-art crossed molecular beam experiments over a wide range of collision energies from 10 to 100 kJmol-1 in a hydrocarbon-free, crossed molecular beam machine with ultra-sensitive detection schemes coupled to a universal and rotatable angular resolved time-of-flight mass spectrometric detector with soft and hard electron impact ionization and laser induced fluorescence (LIF) detection. Although crossed molecular beam experiments have been employed for almost five decades, there is a critical lack of understanding on the elementary mechanisms how to synthesize fundamental molecular building blocks carrying six- and five-membered rings due to the previously insurmountable difficulties in preparing supersonic molecular beams of radical reactants of a sufficient high intensity to detect the reaction products under single collision conditions. The results of the scattering experiments are combined with ab initio calculations (Mebel) and flame modeling (Frenklach). This approach not only resolves a decade old enigma of how simple aromatic building blocks are formed in combustion and extraterrestrial settings, but also how these elementary reactions drive molecular mass growth processes via two- (flat) and three-dimensional (bowl-shaped) aromatic nanostructures ultimately to carbonaceous nanoparticles.
