results.public_abstract: Significant uncertainties in the surface radiation budget in Earth system models (ESMs) exist over the Southern Ocean. As model output is sensitive to parameterizations of mixed-phase and ice cloud processes, and as cloud reflective properties are sensitive to liquid, mixed-phase and ice cloud properties, that in turn are influenced by aerosol properties and large scale meteorological conditions, it is critical to improve understanding of key aerosol, cloud, precipitation and radiative transfer processes. However, model parameterizations are challenged to adequately represent cloud and aerosol processes due to minimal observations existing over the Southern Ocean. Data collected in prior Department of Energy Atmospheric Radiation Measurement program (DOE ARM)-supported field campaigns over the Southern Ocean show large seasonal variations, significant supercooled liquid water, and frequent precipitation below cloud base. But the representativeness of these findings for the entire Southern Ocean is not known because data have been obtained in only a few locations and exhibit latitudinal trends and dependence on synoptic conditions. Thus, this project will use observations from the Cloud and Precipitation Experiment at kennaook (CAPE-k) project to examine controls on aerosol and cloud properties, including those of mixed-phase and ice clouds, over the Southern Ocean. Using CAPE-k data supplemented with data from the Measurements of Aerosols Radiation and Clouds over the Southern Ocean (MARCUS), Macquarie Island Cloud Radiation Experiment (MICRE), and Cold-Air Outbreaks in the Marine Boundary Layer Experiment (COMBLE) we will analyze how cloud, precipitation and radiative properties depend on season and on aerosol and meteorological conditions to test these hypotheses: 1) Given meteorological constraints, radiative biases in models are dominated by the representation of mixed-phase cloud processes over the Southern Ocean; 2) At similar surface temperatures and latitudes, systematic differences between Arctic and Southern Ocean clouds cloud properties exist and are more closely linked to environmental conditions than aerosol amount; 3) The concentrations of cloud condensation nuclei and aerosols are more correlated with precipitation presence than with surface wind speeds regardless of large scale meteorological conditions or geographic location; 4) Liquid, ice, and mixed-phase cloud and precipitation properties of boundary layer clouds are more closely correlated with cloud-base and mid-cloud updrafts and environmental conditions than to variations in accumulation mode aerosol concentrations; 5) The presence of ice in drizzle over the Southern Ocean is better correlated with cloud updraft velocity than with accumulation aerosol or ice nucleating particle concentrations; We will use data from in-situ aerosol, thermodynamic, meteorological, ground-based precipitation probes, radar, lidar, and radiometer sensors from CAPE-k and the kennaook station to derive and retrieve aerosol and cloud microphysical properties, heights, coverage and updraft speeds. We will develop a value-added product of environmental conditions including temperature, lower atmospheric stability, estimated inversion strength, cold air outbreak index, convective available potential energy, wind speed and direction, air mass origin, meteorological regime, cloud coupling to boundary layer, and closed/open cell classification. Multivariate statistical tests will determine significance of correlations between cloud, aerosol and dynamical properties and dependence on environmental conditions, and used to evaluate simulations. Simulations will examine how cloud, precipitation and radiative properties depend on the environment and aerosols, and explore how the representation of cloud microphysics, the boundary layer, and surface fluxes affects radiative fluxes in models at various scales using the DOE-supported models, Energy Exascale Earth System Model (E3SM) Single Column Model (SCM) and Doubly Periodic Simple Cloud-Resolving E3SM Atmosphere Model (DP-SCREAM). The implementation of ice multiplication processes in the Predicted Particle Properties (P3) microphysics scheme will be critical for determining controls on mixed-phase and ice-phase cloud properties.

However, the predicted unimolecular decay rates of functionalized peroxy radical are largely uncharacterized due to experimental challenges. Understanding the unimolecular decay of functionalized peroxy radicals demands a holistic approach that uses multiple experimental and theoretical methods. Therefore, their chemistry will be investigated directly in separate complementary experiments at Coastal Carolina University using a new appartus to study the unimolecular decay of peroxy radicals under jet-cooled and collision-free conditions, and at Argonne National Laboratory under thermal conditions, in which the reactivity of peroxy radicals will be studied at a specific temperature and pressure. In both experiments, the peroxy radicals will be generated and stabilized under conditions that minimize unwanted side chemistry and allow direct observation of their unimolecular decay in fundamental pump-probe laser experiments. Peroxy radicals with carbonyl and carboxylic acid functionalization will be specifically targeted due to low energy barriers for their hydrogen atom migration reactions. The results from the experiments will be compared with state-of-the-art theoretical calculations of the predicted unimolecular decay reaction dynamics and kinetics using methods developed at Argonne National Laboratory. The combination of results from this multidisciplinary approach will provide a complete picture of the unimolecular decay of peroxy radicals and transform our understanding of their chemistry in oxygenated environments, such as the Earth's atmosphere and low-temperature combustion. results.public_abstract: From forests to floodplains to functioning watersheds: Catalyzing collaborative research and inclusive training partnerships between Western Colorado University and DOE’s National Laboratory system Jonathan Coop, Western Colorado University (Principal Investigator) Kristin Boye, SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory (Co-Investigator) Amy Ellwein, Western Colorado University (Co-Investigator) David Marchetti, Western Colorado University (Co-Investigator) Vincent Noël, SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory (Co-Investigator) Micah Russell, Western Colorado University (Co-Investigator) Madelon van de Kerk, Western Colorado University (Co-Investigator) Ken Williams, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (Co-Investigator) Changing climate and disturbance regimes are driving major changes to forest ecosystems and watershed function. These in turn will facilitate the development of long-term partnerships between DOE and a rural university, to link the next generation of diverse, innovative scientists to fulfilling career opportunities addressing environmental challenges.

results.title: Electrically Driven Catalysis with Supercharged Reducing Agents
results.chunk_text: Electron transfer is a central feature of chemistry. Electrons are the world’s energy currency, and the development of sustainable reduction-oxidation (redox) processes is paramount for a world where energy management is key to a stable and secure future. To this end, the development of redox-active molecular systems that facilitate the transfer of high-energy electrons has widespread applications in fuel cell systems, flow batteries, and organic electrosynthesis. However, many reduction reactions requiring high-energy electron inputs (such as alkali metals) are not catalytic, and there has been little progress in designing redox catalysts that deliver potent electrons due to challenges with catalyst stability, characterization, and storage. This program leverages the use of new “supercharged” molecular redox agents for catalytically reducing carbon dioxide (CO2), a C1 atmospheric pollutant, into oxalate (C2O42-) – a commonly used industrial C2 reagent for actinide purification, textile processing, and wood bleaching, to name a few. This program distinguishes itself from most other CO2 research programs because the reduction of CO2 into C2 products with homogeneous (soluble) catalysts remains in its infancy. Therefore, a fundamental understanding of the molecular mechanism of CO2-to-oxalate production is necessary to gain deeper insights into more general design principles for synthesizing C2 products directly from CO2 via carbon-carbon coupling reactions. Within the purview of the DOE-FAIR framework, this research project led by Rutgers University-Newark in collaboration with Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) will: (1) pinpoint the essential structural and electronic features that facilitate CO2 reduction catalysis with manganese (Mn) molecules; (2) utilize the advanced spectro-electrochemical equipment and expertise available at PNNL; (3) advance the understanding of Mn-based redox agents transfer electrons to CO2 by modulating reaction temperatures and pressures via specialized spectroscopic equipment available at PNNL; (4) use experimental and quantum chemical methodologies to map the energy landscapes of elementary reaction steps during the reactions involving Mn, CO2, and electrons. Unlocking new modes of reactivity with CO2 in this research program will contribute to a clean and secure energy future, cementing the United States as a global leader in sustainable chemistry and catalysis.

results.chunk_text: In forests of the eastern United States, wildfire suppression policies have significantly changed the tree structure, soil composition, and moisture levels, a process known as "mesophication". “Mesic” forest soils have increased moisture content and nutrient availability. These mesophication-associated changes are expected to have a major impact on soil nitrogen (N) cycling by microorganisms. Microorganisms involved in N-cycling in forest soils are major sources of nitrogen oxides (NOx= NO + NO2) and nitrous acid (HONO) to the atmosphere. These gases are both air pollutants and greenhouse gas precursors. However, we do not know the specific microbial populations and genetic systems responsible for these emissions, making it challenging to predict their contributions to global atmospheric change. Additionally, the specific populations of microorganisms that produce these gases likely vary across ecosystems. Thus, forest ecosystems at different stages of mesophication provide a unique opportunity to study how different environmental factors like soil moisture and nutrient content influence microbial production of NOx/HONO. This research team will use a novel approach to investigate the microbial origins of these emissions across forests of varying mesophication stages. This new research is driven by several hypotheses: (1) Soil moisture and N are the primary drivers of microbial emissions of NOx/HONO in forest ecosystems. Both variables will increase alongside the degree of forest mesophication. (2) In mesic (i.e., moist) forest soils, higher N levels from more easily decomposed leaf litter and increased water runoff from trees contribute to greater NOx/HONO emissions. (3) The high moisture levels in these soil conditions create small oxygen-deprived zones where anaerobic microorganisms become the main source of NOx/HONO emissions. (4) Emissions from these microbial processes have a significant impact on regional air quality and atmospheric chemistry across the eastern United States. In Objective 1 of this project, the research team will study how biological, chemical, and physical factors affect the release of NO?/HONO from soils in forests with high to low degrees of mesophication. The team will focus on different forest plots at the Catoosa Wildlife Management Area (Crossville, TN, USA), which represent a variety of fire management practices—ranging from no burns at all (i.e., mesic, or moist, conditions) to frequent, controlled burns (i.e., xeric, or drier, conditions)

results.public_abstract: This project focuses on determining the structure of the active state of Methyl-Coenzyme M Reductase (MCR) and the enzymatic mechanism of biological methane synthesis. Methanogens are responsible for producing nearly all of earth’s methane (1 billion tons per year), the primary constituent of natural gas, which accounts for much of U.S. energy consumption. Methanogens are also maestros of methane utilization and are responsible for annual oxidation of 108 tons of methane to CO2 through reverse methanogenesis. Uncovering how nature generates methane is critical since methane is an abundant and important fuel as well as being second only to carbon dioxide as the most prevalent greenhouse gas. MCR catalyzes the formation of methane and the heterodisulfide, CoB-S-S-CoM, from methyl-Coenzyme M (methyl-CoM) and Coenzyme B (CoB). Prior work in the PI’s lab has optimized strategies to obtain high yields of the active Ni(I) state of highly oxygen-sensitive MCR, revealed its strictly ordered ternary complex mechanism of binding substrates, and demonstrated that a methyl radical along with thiyl and disulfide anion radicals form during catalysis. We have also described a novel sulfonate-Ni(I) mode by which MCR binds its first substrate methyl-CoM and determined the first room-temperature structure of this enzyme. During the next three-year contract, we will use a wide swath of approaches to fill many of the remaining gaps in understanding the MCR mechanism. Aim 1 is to reveal the structure of the active Ni(I) state of MCR using complementary methods: X-ray free electron laser serial crystallography (XFEL), X-ray diffraction (XRD), and neutron diffraction. XFEL is known to produce physiologically relevant damage-free high-resolution structures of sub-micron crystals. Our recent structural results indicate that the inactive Ni(II)-state of MCR is a “locked-in” relatively “frozen” state, while the active Ni(I) form of MCR is a highly dynamic molecule with a pentacoordinate Ni(I) active site. We have optimized conditions for XFEL measurements, as well as incorporating methods to simultaneously validate the Ni redox state. We also optimized conditions and will determine the Ni(I)-MCR structure by complementary XRD and neutron diffraction methods. To obtain detailed electronic and geometric structural information of the Ni(I) protein and active site, the crystals and concentrated solutions will be analyzed in parallel by spectroscopic and kinetic methods. Aim 2 is to make a “movie” of the MCR mechanism by revealing the detailed structures of all substrate-bound and intermediate states in the catalytic cycle. We have developed a chemical toolbox for MCR studies including in-house synthesized native substrates and various substrate analogs designed to trap the proposed intermediates. We also will use an extensive instrumental toolbox consisting of structural biology, chemical synthesis, and kinetics coupled to spectroscopy. These experiments will be complemented by computational methods to determine transition state energies and electronic structures of the intermediates. This research plan is expected to provide the long-awaited structure of the active Ni(I) state of MCR and to capture and identify the intermediates and transition states for each step in the MCR mechanism. Our research program will also shed light on the proposed MCR mechanism of C-S and S-S bond activation and cleavage involving Ni(I)-sulfonate interaction and long-distance through-bond electron transfer. We expect the work described here to help guide the design of more efficient catalysts for the use of alkanes in industrial applications and active site directed methanogenesis inhibitors.

results.title: Developing a molecular level understanding of carbon monoxide dehydrogenase/acetyl coenzyme A synthase through model metalloenzymes (- View Less)
results.chunk_text: This project will provide mechanistic insight into the bifunctional metalloprotein complex, carbon monoxide dehydrogenase (CODH)/acetyl coenzyme A synthase (ACS). CODH/ACS is the cornerstone enzyme in the Wood-Ljungdahl metabolic pathway, enabling autotrophic growth in anaerobic bacteria, methanogenesis in archaea, and numerous other processes. From a biochemical standpoint, the CODH/ACS metalloenzyme catalyzes the selective reduction of carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide and generation of new energetic carbon-carbon and carbon-sulfur bonds from one-carbon precursors. Thus, in addition to the central role that CODH/ACS plays in carbon fixation and energy conservation across diverse microorganisms, these reactions represent valuable targets for carbon dioxide utilization and the selective synthesis of liquid fuels from CO2. However, due to the complexity and extremely sensitive nature of the CODH/ACS enzyme, we lack a fundamental understanding of how these enzymes work, which has hindered efforts to synthesize catalysts that take advantage of similar strategies. In this project, we will develop and characterize protein-based models of CODH and ACS as structural, functional, and mechanistic mimics to reveal the biochemical principles by which CODH and ACS operate. In Aim 1, a robust ferredoxin scaffold will be used to construct a site-differentiated nickel-iron-sulfur cluster-containing model. Detailed electronic structure characterization will be pursued using complementary spectroscopic tools, and function will be assessed using solution-phase and electrochemical experiments. Aim 2 will build from prior work within the group that demonstrated electronic and mechanistic parallels between a modified nickel-substituted azurin model and ACS. New variants will be pursued to develop functional models of ACS, allowing resolution of the key protein-derived factors influencing reactivity. Specific contributors to substrate channeling will be investigated in Aim 3. The development of functional, robust enzymes that catalyze CO2 reduction and carbon-carbon bond formation will provide catalyst design guidelines for sustainable generation of liquid fuels from CO2, addressing one of the fundamental priority research opportunities for solar fuels identified by the DOE.

results.public_abstract: This project will provide mechanistic insight into the bifunctional metalloprotein complex, carbon monoxide dehydrogenase (CODH)/acetyl coenzyme A synthase (ACS). CODH/ACS is the cornerstone enzyme in the Wood-Ljungdahl metabolic pathway, enabling autotrophic growth in anaerobic bacteria, methanogenesis in archaea, and numerous other processes. From a biochemical standpoint, the CODH/ACS metalloenzyme catalyzes the selective reduction of carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide and generation of new energetic carbon-carbon and carbon-sulfur bonds from one-carbon precursors. Thus, in addition to the central role that CODH/ACS plays in carbon fixation and energy conservation across diverse microorganisms, these reactions represent valuable targets for carbon dioxide utilization and the selective synthesis of liquid fuels from CO2. However, due to the complexity and extremely sensitive nature of the CODH/ACS enzyme, we lack a fundamental understanding of how these enzymes work, which has hindered efforts to synthesize catalysts that take advantage of similar strategies. In this project, we will develop and characterize protein-based models of CODH and ACS as structural, functional, and mechanistic mimics to reveal the biochemical principles by which CODH and ACS operate. In Aim 1, a robust ferredoxin scaffold will be used to construct a site-differentiated nickel-iron-sulfur cluster-containing model. Detailed electronic structure characterization will be pursued using complementary spectroscopic tools, and function will be assessed using solution-phase and electrochemical experiments. Aim 2 will build from prior work within the group that demonstrated electronic and mechanistic parallels between a modified nickel-substituted azurin model and ACS. New variants will be pursued to develop functional models of ACS, allowing resolution of the key protein-derived factors influencing reactivity. Specific contributors to substrate channeling will be investigated in Aim 3. The development of functional, robust enzymes that catalyze CO2 reduction and carbon-carbon bond formation will provide catalyst design guidelines for sustainable generation of liquid fuels from CO2, addressing one of the fundamental priority research opportunities for solar fuels identified by the DOE.

results.public_abstract: This project focuses on liquid water, a critical material shaping geochemistry and life on our planet. The overarching goal is to understand how water adopts distinct properties when placed in contact with different surfaces. Key surfaces examined are clay minerals and related solids (e.g., mica) that play central roles in soil health and subsurface energy, including in soil resilience to erosion and drought, geologic CO2 sequestration, nuclear waste isolation, and enhanced geothermal energy. The approach followed in the project uses high-performance computing, supported by atomistic-level experimental characterization, to elucidate the nanoscale properties of water in clay interlayer nanopores and in adsorbed water films on mica and silica surfaces. In particular, molecular dynamics (MD) simulations are used to reveal the behavior of individual atoms in complex systems (where spectroscopic and other experimental methods probe the average behavior of large numbers of atoms or molecules) and the manner in which the collective properties of assemblages of millions of water molecules emerge from atomistic-level interactions. A first major focus of the project is on understanding the selective transport properties of water-filled nanopores. In other words, how do nanopores selectively transport water vs. salt, or cations vs. anions? A second major focus is on understanding the stability of adsorbed water films on mineral surfaces. Finally, a third focus is on advancing MD simulation capabilities by combining simulations with synchrotron X-ray reflectivity and Terahertz spectroscopy experiments. The research relies on simulations carried out at the National Energy Research Scientific Computing Center (NERSC), a US Department of Energy facility located at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (LBNL), and on Princeton University’s high-performance computing clusters. The project involves collaborations with scientists at the Argonne National Laboratory (ANL), the Sandia National Laboratories (SNL), and the University of Ruhr-Bochum. A key projected outcome is the critical re-examination of existing models and theories used to describe the properties of water in nanopores and thin films, including models of water and solute transport in nanopores and models of disjoining pressure in adsorbed water films. Beyond the Geosciences, this research aims to generate fundamental scientific knowledge relevant to nanofiltration and reverse osmosis membranes; wettability and multiphase flow; chemical synthesis using interfacial or confined water as a green solvent; and other scientific areas. Finally, the project aims to accelerate the development of advanced nanogeochemical experimental approaches for the characterization of geologic media and processes, including Terahertz spectroscopy and synchrotron X-ray reflectivity experiments.

results.public_abstract: In forests of the eastern United States, wildfire suppression policies have significantly changed the tree structure, soil composition, and moisture levels, a process known as "mesophication". “Mesic” forest soils have increased moisture content and nutrient availability. These mesophication-associated changes are expected to have a major impact on soil nitrogen (N) cycling by microorganisms. Microorganisms involved in N-cycling in forest soils are major sources of nitrogen oxides (NOx= NO + NO2) and nitrous acid (HONO) to the atmosphere. These gases are both air pollutants and greenhouse gas precursors. However, we do not know the specific microbial populations and genetic systems responsible for these emissions, making it challenging to predict their contributions to global atmospheric change. Additionally, the specific populations of microorganisms that produce these gases likely vary across ecosystems. Thus, forest ecosystems at different stages of mesophication provide a unique opportunity to study how different environmental factors like soil moisture and nutrient content influence microbial production of NOx/HONO. This research team will use a novel approach to investigate the microbial origins of these emissions across forests of varying mesophication stages. This new research is driven by several hypotheses: (1) Soil moisture and N are the primary drivers of microbial emissions of NOx/HONO in forest ecosystems. Both variables will increase alongside the degree of forest mesophication. (2) In mesic (i.e., moist) forest soils, higher N levels from more easily decomposed leaf litter and increased water runoff from trees contribute to greater NOx/HONO emissions. (3) The high moisture levels in these soil conditions create small oxygen-deprived zones where anaerobic microorganisms become the main source of NOx/HONO emissions. (4) Emissions from these microbial processes have a significant impact on regional air quality and atmospheric chemistry across the eastern United States. In Objective 1 of this project, the research team will study how biological, chemical, and physical factors affect the release of NO?/HONO from soils in forests with high to low degrees of mesophication. This will help them identify the specific microbial processes responsible for producing these gases in the field. Finally, in Objective 4, the researchers will use these findings from Objectives 1-3 to build a biogeochemical model that estimates how much NO?/HONO is released from soils under different fire conditions. This model will feed into an atmospheric model to predict how these emissions will impact the climate of the region. Key outcomes of the research include a detailed analysis of soil microbial communities across forests experiencing different levels of fire suppression and resulting mesophication. The study will describe how changes in these microbial populations are connected to the release of NO?/HONO. Researchers will also determine how specific soil microbial processes, such as denitrification and nitrification, contribute to the production of these gases. Additionally, the team will create a computer model that incorporates isotope data to simulate how nitrogen cycles through the environment and estimate the natural emissions of NO?/HONO from forest soils at various stages of mesophication. Using these results, they will run simulations to understand how changes in fire management and microbial populations affect atmospheric chemistry and, ultimately, the climate. results.public_abstract: A highly efficient deep-learning-based parameter estimation and uncertainty reduction framework for ecosystem dynamics models Chaopeng Shen, Penn State (Principal Investigator) Daniel Kifer, Penn State (Co-Investigator) Chonggang Xu, Los Alamos National Laboratory (Unfunded Collaborator) Forrest Hoffman, Oak Ridge National Laboratory (Unfunded Collaborator) Our overall goal is to better predict plant responses, such as drought-related changes in evapotranspiration and productivity, by efficiently determining proper plant trait parameters and reducing parametric uncertainties at large scales. We will utilize deep learning (DL) to improve plant trait parameterization for the Energy Exascale Earth System Model (E3SM) Land Model (ELM) coupled to a next-generation dynamic vegetation model, the Functionally Assembled TErrestrial Simulator (FATES). The project seeks to understand (i) how soil, topography, and other environmental variables influence plant hydraulics, growth, and mortality parameters; (ii) relative importance and uncertainty sources of these parameters; and (iii) characteristics of plant hydraulic parameters, such as time-dependence and identifiability. Building on our previous and preliminary work, a major contribution of the research is a novel and highly efficient parameter learning framework for estimating environment-dependent and scale-dependent vegetation trait parameters with uncertainty estimations. This framework, saving four orders-of-magnitude of computational time, can be applied instantly on large scales, and has very competitive and potentially stronger optimization metrics than current optimization algorithms. It can be said that, instead of solving one inversion problem at a time, our framework will train a tool that solves this problem with higher efficient and more robust results. Additionally, this framework opens fresh pathways to address issues and ask new questions from a data-driven perspective. We will reduce uncertainty and improve physical significance of parameters by imposing novel constraints, such as information-transfer (parameters are roughly functions of plant types and environmental covariates) and covariation (exploiting observed inter-parameter relationships). At the same time, local heterogeneities in traits can be expressed, allowing us to understand the relative importance of stochasticity and environmental controls of plant traits. By interrogating the trained parameter learning model, we will reveal the linkages between topography, grid scale, soil, climate, and plant hydraulic traits, growth, and mortality parameters. We will also use time-dependent parameters as keys to identify deficiencies in model dynamics. This framework will usher in a new era for parameter determination for land surface models.

results.public_abstract: Southwest Urban Corridor Integrated Field Laboratory (SW-IFL) Rationale: The growing urban megaregion across the state of Arizona is experiencing stresses resulting from a warming climate and population growth. Stretching from the Mexican border in the south to the Navajo (Diné) Nation in the north, the region experiences disproportionate impacts on vulnerable urban subpopulations. Decision-ready knowledge is insufficient and often unavailable to mobilize specific action in places affected simultaneously by profound climate change and rapid growth. Arizona State University leads a team that includes University of Arizona, Northern Arizona University, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Brookhaven National Laboratory, and IBM. This project will exploit the significant recent progress of quantum many-body physics to elucidate connections between two extensively studied models for quantum computation. Albeit intimately related, little is known about the correspondence between AQC and QAOA in regards to computational hardness and algorithmic design. Our study will provide important, broadly relevant details about these properties by (1) using entanglement growth as a proxy for problem hardness and (2) focusing on a computational problem class of practical relevance. Our work has the potential to impact quantum approaches to solving scientific problems of interest to DOE. The knowledge gained from this study can be used to inform the design and training of variational algorithms more generally, thus, extending the applicability to the variational quantum eigensolver and electronic structure calculations. In addition, our work could assist in circumventing barren plateaus, where optimal AQC schedules are used to provide near-optimal initial conditions when training large variational algorithms. More broadly, our work can supply intuition into the potential utility of a particular quantum computing model based on the specifications of the computational problem. As a result, the need for extensive empirical benchmarking utilizing costly classical and quantum computational resources could be reduced.

results.public_abstract: This project will determine translations between adiabatic quantum computing (AQC) and the quantum approximate optimization algorithm (QAOA) through the study of entanglement generation and its relation to computational hardness and optimal algorithmic design. The objective of this study is to draw on our team's expertise in out-of-equilibrium quench dynamics, entanglement in ground states of Hamiltonians, and optimal control to establish connections between quantum problem hardness in QAOA and AQC and develop effective ways to translate optimal controls between these computational models. The project will be split into two thrust areas focusing on quantifying entanglement in QAOA and AQC and establishing translations of optimal computation across these models. Thrust 1 will focus on identifying universal properties of entanglement growth in QAOA by examining the dynamics of bipartite entanglement entropy. We will investigate the dependence of entanglement entropy on the choice of ansatze as well as its growth during training and after optimization. Our study will utilize numerical simulation and analytical techniques drawn from out-of-equilibrium quench dynamics to shed light on entanglement growth and its relationship to the specifications of the computational problem of interest; our focus will be on Maximum Satisfiability, where the clause density directly relates to the classical computational hardness of the problem. This problem class will further facilitate studies of interplay between classical and quantum hardness, entanglement growth, and computational models. The results of Thrust 1 will inform the design of optimal QAOA parameter selection and AQC schedules in Thrust 2. Using our team’s extensive knowledge in control theory, we will develop guiding principles to translate between optimal AQC and QAOA based on the desired entanglement dynamics of the algorithm. Furthermore, we will exploit characteristics of each algorithm to inform the design of optimized controls for the other, e.g., AQC runtime will inform the QAOA depth and the optimized AQC path will be examined as an initialization for QAOA. results.title: Algorithms for Quantum Utility: Intelligent, Robust, and Efficiently Distributed (AQUIRED)
results.chunk_text: Quantum computing is a new, potentially very powerful type of computing. Great interest has been generated in recent years by a plethora of proof-of-principle demonstrations on small prototype devices. However, such demonstrations have employed methods that are unlikely to work at scales of practical interest. We propose two lines of research to maximize the utility of quantum computers as they scale to larger, more powerful devices in the near future: (1) We will develop and demonstrate scalable hybrid quantum-classical algorithms for combinatorial optimization by designing problem-tailored ansätze and advancing novel methods of incorporating them into classical workflows. (2) We will develop and demonstrate kernels for quantum simulation that exploit mid-circuit measurements as new algorithmic tools for improved efficiency and robustness to hardware errors. This work directly addresses the call to “advance the research towards achievement and demonstration of quantum utility by developing new algorithms.” It does so by developing algorithms for DOE application-inspired computational kernels for near-term quantum systems and by estimating quantum resources for those algorithms. Significantly, this work will deliver successes for quantum computing while the technology matures, justifying continued Department of Energy (DOE) investments in quantum computing. These efforts will help DOE leverage quantum computing as a useful scientific tool as early as possible, with potential benefits to diverse applications such as the discovery of materials and processes for clean energy and the design and optimization of resilient distributed energy networks.

results.public_abstract: Quantum computing technology is progressing rapidly and could provide a valuable new approach to simulating complex quantum systems. In high energy physics, there are many important problems which are likely to only be solvable with sufficiently advanced quantum simulations. Chief among these are problems related to understanding the dynamical properties of quantum chromodynamics (QCD), the strong nuclear force responsible for the structure of nuclei. To use quantum computers effectively as a tool for studying QCD will require significant research investment into different methods for modeling QCD on quantum hardware; developing classical computing tools to support the quantum simulation; and devising efficient quantum algorithms to make the most of finite resources. This grant will support research along each of these axes, building the knowledge base and infrastructure to enable groundbreaking applications of quantum simulations to high energy physics as quantum technology evolves.

results.public_abstract: Quantum Digital Twins D. Appelo, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University (Principal Investigator) M. Motamed, University of New Mexico (Co-Investigator) Y. Cheng, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University (Co-Investigator) The proposed research will develop and deploy Quantum Digital Twins (QDT), hardware emulators that are individual digital clones of existing quantum devises. The QDT framework we propose will provide the foundational glue that binds currently available software tools, data, and hardware. We consider general hardware descriptions whose properties can be modeled by the Lindblad quantum master equation but note that other models are allowed by our QDT framework. A key feature of our QDTs is the bi-directional interaction between virtual and physical siblings. In a calibration phase, a QDT’s performance is monitored and improved in a cost-efficient way by optimal experimental design. When calibrated, the QDT can be used to test any software on the quantum software stack that uses the hardware the QDT emulates. The QDTs will be realized by robust optimal transport-driven Bayesian techniques and novel, scalable numerical methods. The QDT emulators integrate the physics of quantum hardware, described by Schrödinger’s and Lindblad’s equations, using high-order accurate and structure-preserving numerical techniques. They also address the inherent complexity and incompleteness of these descriptions, known as model inadequacy, by employing robust Bayesian techniques that handle the inherent uncertainty and noise in the quantum hardware. The research program proposes to address the limitations of traditional approaches through four specific aims. The first aim is to design, analyze, and implement QDTs and algorithms using a Quantum Bi-directional Communication (QuBiC) approach. This approach first focuses on characterization tasks, employing optimal design of experiments, real quantum measurements, and statistical techniques driven by optimal transport. The second aim is to use the QuBiC approach for the optimal control tasks during the calibration phase of the QDT. This will be achieved through new arbitrary order accurate Hermite interpolation-based methods for time evolution and discrete adjoint computations, which will enable large speedups for problems of medium size. The third aim is to develop low-rank methods for Lindblad’s quantum master equations to emulate large composite open systems. The final aim is to demonstrate and disseminate the QuBiC-enhanced QDTs by hardening developed algorithms and methods into existing open-source software products. Our research has the potential to influence quantum computing methods for addressing scientific challenges relevant to the DOE. Our work can provide valuable intuition regarding the utility of specific quantum computing hardware. Additionally, the insights gained from this study can guide the design and training of general digital twins, thereby broadening their applicability to applications of relevance to the DOE.

results.title: Quantum Utility Through Advanced Computational Quantum Algorithm (QUACQ)
results.chunk_text: The QUACQ collaboration will develop mathematical algorithms and primitives to demonstrate quantum utility for quantum simulation on leading and emerging quantum architectures. The QUACQ team is motivated by the recent emergence of quantum hardware that stands at the threshold of error correction. How can we use such threshold-capable quantum hardware more generally for useful quantum simulations? How do we design the classes of target problems with viable quantum utility? What mathematical, algorithmic, and software advances are needed to reach this goal? Quantum simulation is widely anticipated as one of the most exciting applications of quantum devices. Such simulations abound across the energy sciences, and range from describing quantum dynamics in condensed matter models, to simulating lattice gauge theories, to preparing relevant quantum states for molecular and bulk chemical matter. All these problems are of major scientific and even societal impact. Despite the different domains, underlying the diverse set of simulation problems are several common quantum algorithmic challenges. These are the challenges we will address to define and improve the end-to-end complexity of quantum simulations for quantum utility. Our work in the areas of mathematical, computational, and software development focuses on three main directions: ``Co-design for quantum utility in simulation'', ``Quantum algorithms for quantum utility'', and ``Classical benchmarking and verification for quantum utility''. Our collaboration will utilize the unique experimental cold atom capabilities in our team, as well as our long-standing relationships with experimental efforts in superconducting qubit and trapped ion hardware architectures, to achieve experimental demonstrations of quantum utility for quantum simulation tasks.

results.title: Algorithms for Quantum Utility: Intelligent, Robust, and Efficiently Distributed (AQUIRED)
results.chunk_text: Quantum computing is a new, potentially very powerful type of computing. Great interest has been generated in recent years by a plethora of proof-of-principle demonstrations on small prototype devices. However, such demonstrations have employed methods that are unlikely to work at scales of practical interest. We propose two lines of research to maximize the utility of quantum computers as they scale to larger, more powerful devices in the near future: (1) We will develop and demonstrate scalable hybrid quantum-classical algorithms for combinatorial optimization by designing problem-tailored ansätze and advancing novel methods of incorporating them into classical workflows. (2) We will develop and demonstrate kernels for quantum simulation that exploit mid-circuit measurements as new algorithmic tools for improved efficiency and robustness to hardware errors. This work directly addresses the call to “advance the research towards achievement and demonstration of quantum utility by developing new algorithms.” It does so by developing algorithms for DOE application-inspired computational kernels for near-term quantum systems and by estimating quantum resources for those algorithms. Significantly, this work will deliver successes for quantum computing while the technology matures, justifying continued Department of Energy (DOE) investments in quantum computing. These efforts will help DOE leverage quantum computing as a useful scientific tool as early as possible, with potential benefits to diverse applications such as the discovery of materials and processes for clean energy and the design and optimization of resilient distributed energy networks.

results.title: FAR-Qu: Fundamental Algorithmic Research toward Quantum Utility
results.chunk_text: . While a major barrier to sustainable quantum utility is the current lack of mature, scalable, and error-resilient quantum computing hardware, sustainable quantum utility is also hampered by equally formidable fundamental algorithmic challenges. We address such algorithmic challenges by (1) developing unconventional quantum computing models, algorithms, and advantages that consider other computational resource bottlenecks, including running time, space/memory, solution accuracy, energy expenditure, and communication costs; (2) targeting basic scientific problems that are critical components in broad applications, such as simulating quantum systems and solving differential equations, linear systems, and continuous and discrete optimization problems; and (3) engaging in the full-stack-aware design of quantum algorithms that adjust computing-stack components to pave the way to unconventional demonstrations of sustainable quantum utility.

results.public_abstract: Recent empirical demonstrations pointing toward quantum advantage have fueled excitement and growth in the field. However, many high-profile demonstrations suggesting quantum advantage have prompted improvements in classical algorithm design (e.g., tensor-network methods) and enlist additional classical resources (e.g., supercomputing) with surprising progress in closing quantum-advantage gaps. While quantum-inspired classical improvements are a healthy benefit of quantum-computing research, to ultimately realize quantum utility it is important to systematically identify, understand, and publicize sources of quantum advantage that are unlikely to be diminished as classical computing progresses. A demonstration of quantum utility may conjure the image of a plot indicating that a quantum computer performs better (with respect to some metric) than the best-known classical counterparts. This basic concept of quantum utility raises natural questions. Soundness: What evidence do we have that a quantum computer will continue to be the best way to solve this problem as input instances grow larger or more complex? Cost-effectiveness: Will a quantum computer be the most cost-effective way to solve the problem? Resource efficiency: Will some other resource considerations, such as energy to solution, rule out practical adoption of the quantum computing solution? While well-conceived notions of quantum utility have been suggested, none, to our knowledge, simultaneously take all of the above into account. Our goal is to identify sources of sustainable quantum utility, those that are sound, cost effective, and resource efficient. We believe that sustainable quantum utility is the best candidate for realizing the promise of quantum computing. We aim to discover examples of sustainable quantum utility through three guiding perspectives: (1) sustainable quantum utility should be backed by strong evidence or proof of asymptotic advantage — in other words, there should be some feature of quantum mechanics that continues to provide an advantage in a reasonably predictable manner as problem instances grow in size or complexity, (2) an array of resources beyond execution time should be considered to ensure that quantum advantages are indeed practical and that we are not overlooking unconventional quantum advantages, and (3) we should focus on developing quantum advantages for fundamental problems in broad domains such as simulation, optimization, and machine learning, that can be tailored to yield sustainable quantum utility for new and existing applications. While a major barrier to sustainable quantum utility is the current lack of mature, scalable, and error-resilient quantum computing hardware, sustainable quantum utility is also hampered by equally formidable fundamental algorithmic challenges. We address such algorithmic challenges by (1) developing unconventional quantum computing models, algorithms, and advantages that consider other computational resource bottlenecks, including running time, space/memory, solution accuracy, energy expenditure, and communication costs; (2) targeting basic scientific problems that are critical components in broad applications, such as simulating quantum systems and solving differential equations, linear systems, and continuous and discrete optimization problems; and (3) engaging in the full-stack-aware design of quantum algorithms that adjust computing-stack components to pave the way to unconventional demonstrations of sustainable quantum utility.

results.title: SMART Stack: Scalable, Modular, Adaptable, Reconfigurable, error-Targeted approaches to quantum stack design
results.chunk_text: Quantum processing units (QPUs) are currently at an inflection point, where systems are reaching qubit count and quality, along with control capabilities that potentially enable scientific discovery. A key hurdle, however, is the management of rapidly accumulating errors that obstructs large-scale quantum algorithms and realizations of quantum advantage necessary for scientific applications. Error sources are diverse and highly dependent upon the technology and its supporting infrastructure. While current quantum software stacks have made strides in managing errors, they typically do not possess the versatility required to fully exploit rapidly changing hardware specifications, modes of operation, and control capabilities. Crucially, a new software infrastructure is required to bridge the gap between application requirements and hardware characteristics. SMART Stack proposes to address this critical gap through the development quantum software stack strategies that are SMART: Scalable, Modular, cross-platform Adaptable, dynamically Reconfigurable, and error-Targeted. SMART Stack builds on the work of the DOE funded Tough Errors are No Match (TEAM) project, where key strides were made to enhance error management (EM) through the development of a compilation toolbox. Utilizing TEAM’s highly successful, low-level EM methods as a foundation, SMART Stack aims to design a software stack balances the fundamental tension between low-level, error-characterization-informed EM and the goals of scalability, modularity, and adaptability to emerging and developing quantum technologies. SMART Stack’s approach involves tightly integrating the software stack with hardware to enable error resilience, and subsequently, improved algorithm performance in current and future quantum computing systems. Our approach involves designing scalable, modular error characterization and management (ECM) approaches that will be combined to achieve dynamic, cross-stack-orchestrated error resilience. In addition, through the design of new error-aware stack integration approaches and compiler passes, we will devise a flexible quantum software stack for current centralized quantum computing systems and future distributed heterogeneous quantum-classical computing models. The proposed research comprises three thrust areas: (1) scalable error characterization and management, (2) hardware-aware compilers, and (3) cross-layer integration and evaluation. The first thrust focuses on the development of cross-stack error management strategies that exploit error characterizations at various layers in the stack. Importantly, the SMART Stack approach seeks to leverage classical high-performance resources to enable ECM design and evaluation. Protocols developed in the first thrust will be used to develop hardware-aware compilation passes and software tools. The integration and evaluation of the devised methods is the focus of the third thrust

results.title: Quantum Utility Through Advanced Computational Quantum Algorithm (QUACQ)
results.chunk_text: The QUACQ collaboration will develop mathematical algorithms and primitives to demonstrate quantum utility for quantum simulation on leading and emerging quantum architectures. The QUACQ team is motivated by the recent emergence of quantum hardware that stands at the threshold of error correction. How can we use such threshold-capable quantum hardware more generally for useful quantum simulations? How do we design the classes of target problems with viable quantum utility? What mathematical, algorithmic, and software advances are needed to reach this goal? Quantum simulation is widely anticipated as one of the most exciting applications of quantum devices. Such simulations abound across the energy sciences, and range from describing quantum dynamics in condensed matter models, to simulating lattice gauge theories, to preparing relevant quantum states for molecular and bulk chemical matter. All these problems are of major scientific and even societal impact. Despite the different domains, underlying the diverse set of simulation problems are several common quantum algorithmic challenges. These are the challenges we will address to define and improve the end-to-end complexity of quantum simulations for quantum utility. Our work in the areas of mathematical, computational, and software development focuses on three main directions: ``Co-design for quantum utility in simulation'', ``Quantum algorithms for quantum utility'', and ``Classical benchmarking and verification for quantum utility''. Our collaboration will utilize the unique experimental cold atom capabilities in our team, as well as our long-standing relationships with experimental efforts in superconducting qubit and trapped ion hardware architectures, to achieve experimental demonstrations of quantum utility for quantum simulation tasks.

Cheng, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University (Co-Investigator) The proposed research will develop and deploy Quantum Digital Twins (QDT), hardware emulators that are individual digital clones of existing quantum devises. The QDT framework we propose will provide the foundational glue that binds currently available software tools, data, and hardware. We consider general hardware descriptions whose properties can be modeled by the Lindblad quantum master equation but note that other models are allowed by our QDT framework. A key feature of our QDTs is the bi-directional interaction between virtual and physical siblings. In a calibration phase, a QDT’s performance is monitored and improved in a cost-efficient way by optimal experimental design. When calibrated, the QDT can be used to test any software on the quantum software stack that uses the hardware the QDT emulates. The QDTs will be realized by robust optimal transport-driven Bayesian techniques and novel, scalable numerical methods. The QDT emulators integrate the physics of quantum hardware, described by Schrödinger’s and Lindblad’s equations, using high-order accurate and structure-preserving numerical techniques. They also address the inherent complexity and incompleteness of these descriptions, known as model inadequacy, by employing robust Bayesian techniques that handle the inherent uncertainty and noise in the quantum hardware. The research program proposes to address the limitations of traditional approaches through four specific aims. The first aim is to design, analyze, and implement QDTs and algorithms using a Quantum Bi-directional Communication (QuBiC) approach. This approach first focuses on characterization tasks, employing optimal design of experiments, real quantum measurements, and statistical techniques driven by optimal transport. The second aim is to use the QuBiC approach for the optimal control tasks during the calibration phase of the QDT. This will be achieved through new arbitrary order accurate Hermite interpolation-based methods for time evolution and discrete adjoint computations, which will enable large speedups for problems of medium size. The third aim is to develop low-rank methods for Lindblad’s quantum master equations to emulate large composite open systems. The final aim is to demonstrate and disseminate the QuBiC-enhanced QDTs by hardening developed algorithms and methods into existing open-source software products. results.title: Toward Lattice QCD on Quantum Computers
results.chunk_text: Quantum computing technology is progressing rapidly and could provide a valuable new approach to simulating complex quantum systems. In high energy physics, there are many important problems which are likely to only be solvable with sufficiently advanced quantum simulations. Chief among these are problems related to understanding the dynamical properties of quantum chromodynamics (QCD), the strong nuclear force responsible for the structure of nuclei. To use quantum computers effectively as a tool for studying QCD will require significant research investment into different methods for modeling QCD on quantum hardware; developing classical computing tools to support the quantum simulation; and devising efficient quantum algorithms to make the most of finite resources. This grant will support research along each of these axes, building the knowledge base and infrastructure to enable groundbreaking applications of quantum simulations to high energy physics as quantum technology evolves.

We aim to discover examples of sustainable quantum utility through three guiding perspectives: (1) sustainable quantum utility should be backed by strong evidence or proof of asymptotic advantage — in other words, there should be some feature of quantum mechanics that continues to provide an advantage in a reasonably predictable manner as problem instances grow in size or complexity, (2) an array of resources beyond execution time should be considered to ensure that quantum advantages are indeed practical and that we are not overlooking unconventional quantum advantages, and (3) we should focus on developing quantum advantages for fundamental problems in broad domains such as simulation, optimization, and machine learning, that can be tailored to yield sustainable quantum utility for new and existing applications. While a major barrier to sustainable quantum utility is the current lack of mature, scalable, and error-resilient quantum computing hardware, sustainable quantum utility is also hampered by equally formidable fundamental algorithmic challenges. We address such algorithmic challenges by (1) developing unconventional quantum computing models, algorithms, and advantages that consider other computational resource bottlenecks, including running time, space/memory, solution accuracy, energy expenditure, and communication costs; (2) targeting basic scientific problems that are critical components in broad applications, such as simulating quantum systems and solving differential equations, linear systems, and continuous and discrete optimization problems; and (3) engaging in the full-stack-aware design of quantum algorithms that adjust computing-stack components to pave the way to unconventional demonstrations of sustainable quantum utility.

Cheng, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University (Co-Investigator) The proposed research will develop and deploy Quantum Digital Twins (QDT), hardware emulators that are individual digital clones of existing quantum devises. The QDT framework we propose will provide the foundational glue that binds currently available software tools, data, and hardware. We consider general hardware descriptions whose properties can be modeled by the Lindblad quantum master equation but note that other models are allowed by our QDT framework. A key feature of our QDTs is the bi-directional interaction between virtual and physical siblings. In a calibration phase, a QDT’s performance is monitored and improved in a cost-efficient way by optimal experimental design. When calibrated, the QDT can be used to test any software on the quantum software stack that uses the hardware the QDT emulates. The QDTs will be realized by robust optimal transport-driven Bayesian techniques and novel, scalable numerical methods. The QDT emulators integrate the physics of quantum hardware, described by Schrödinger’s and Lindblad’s equations, using high-order accurate and structure-preserving numerical techniques. They also address the inherent complexity and incompleteness of these descriptions, known as model inadequacy, by employing robust Bayesian techniques that handle the inherent uncertainty and noise in the quantum hardware. The research program proposes to address the limitations of traditional approaches through four specific aims. The first aim is to design, analyze, and implement QDTs and algorithms using a Quantum Bi-directional Communication (QuBiC) approach. This approach first focuses on characterization tasks, employing optimal design of experiments, real quantum measurements, and statistical techniques driven by optimal transport. The second aim is to use the QuBiC approach for the optimal control tasks during the calibration phase of the QDT. This will be achieved through new arbitrary order accurate Hermite interpolation-based methods for time evolution and discrete adjoint computations, which will enable large speedups for problems of medium size. The third aim is to develop low-rank methods for Lindblad’s quantum master equations to emulate large composite open systems. The final aim is to demonstrate and disseminate the QuBiC-enhanced QDTs by hardening developed algorithms and methods into existing open-source software products. This project will exploit the significant recent progress of quantum many-body physics to elucidate connections between two extensively studied models for quantum computation. Albeit intimately related, little is known about the correspondence between AQC and QAOA in regards to computational hardness and algorithmic design. Our study will provide important, broadly relevant details about these properties by (1) using entanglement growth as a proxy for problem hardness and (2) focusing on a computational problem class of practical relevance. Our work has the potential to impact quantum approaches to solving scientific problems of interest to DOE. The knowledge gained from this study can be used to inform the design and training of variational algorithms more generally, thus, extending the applicability to the variational quantum eigensolver and electronic structure calculations. In addition, our work could assist in circumventing barren plateaus, where optimal AQC schedules are used to provide near-optimal initial conditions when training large variational algorithms. More broadly, our work can supply intuition into the potential utility of a particular quantum computing model based on the specifications of the computational problem. As a result, the need for extensive empirical benchmarking utilizing costly classical and quantum computational resources could be reduced.

results.public_abstract: This project will determine translations between adiabatic quantum computing (AQC) and the quantum approximate optimization algorithm (QAOA) through the study of entanglement generation and its relation to computational hardness and optimal algorithmic design. The objective of this study is to draw on our team's expertise in out-of-equilibrium quench dynamics, entanglement in ground states of Hamiltonians, and optimal control to establish connections between quantum problem hardness in QAOA and AQC and develop effective ways to translate optimal controls between these computational models. The project will be split into two thrust areas focusing on quantifying entanglement in QAOA and AQC and establishing translations of optimal computation across these models. Thrust 1 will focus on identifying universal properties of entanglement growth in QAOA by examining the dynamics of bipartite entanglement entropy. We will investigate the dependence of entanglement entropy on the choice of ansatze as well as its growth during training and after optimization. Our study will utilize numerical simulation and analytical techniques drawn from out-of-equilibrium quench dynamics to shed light on entanglement growth and its relationship to the specifications of the computational problem of interest; our focus will be on Maximum Satisfiability, where the clause density directly relates to the classical computational hardness of the problem. This problem class will further facilitate studies of interplay between classical and quantum hardness, entanglement growth, and computational models. The results of Thrust 1 will inform the design of optimal QAOA parameter selection and AQC schedules in Thrust 2. Using our team’s extensive knowledge in control theory, we will develop guiding principles to translate between optimal AQC and QAOA based on the desired entanglement dynamics of the algorithm. Furthermore, we will exploit characteristics of each algorithm to inform the design of optimized controls for the other, e.g., AQC runtime will inform the QAOA depth and the optimized AQC path will be examined as an initialization for QAOA. results.title: Toward Lattice QCD on Quantum Computers
results.chunk_text: Quantum computing technology is progressing rapidly and could provide a valuable new approach to simulating complex quantum systems. In high energy physics, there are many important problems which are likely to only be solvable with sufficiently advanced quantum simulations. Chief among these are problems related to understanding the dynamical properties of quantum chromodynamics (QCD), the strong nuclear force responsible for the structure of nuclei. To use quantum computers effectively as a tool for studying QCD will require significant research investment into different methods for modeling QCD on quantum hardware; developing classical computing tools to support the quantum simulation; and devising efficient quantum algorithms to make the most of finite resources. This grant will support research along each of these axes, building the knowledge base and infrastructure to enable groundbreaking applications of quantum simulations to high energy physics as quantum technology evolves.
